title: watch boris ambitious liz truss manoeuvres already
story: Word reaches me that the Foreign Secretary, Liz Truss, held a dinner for five Tory MPs at 5 Hertford Street, the £1,800 a year Mayfair club, on Tuesday night. Guests at the eve of Budget dinner included Marco Longhi and Gareth Davies, both elected as part of Boris Johnson’s landslide in 2019.Truss has form here. Last month she held a drinks party for MPs just as Chancellor Rishi Sunak was about to announce a hike in National Insurance Contributions, telling them she wanted “to start standing up for Conservative values and be unashamed to do so”.Truss’s advisers tell me: “I wouldn’t read anything into it. Just a standard meeting between a minister and MPs discussing foreign policy.”That’s not what Tory backbenchers are saying.Just in time for the start of Cop26, Allegra Stratton, the Prime Minister’s spokesman on the Glasgow summit, announced this week that she has ditched her third-hand diesel car, citing messages she received from the public. But I can reveal there was more to her choice than she may have let on, namely the decision by Labour mayor Sadiq Khan to expand London’s Ultra Low Emission Zone (ULEZ).The extension of the zone to the edge of the north and south circulars means it now covers Stratton’s north London home, which would have left her facing the extortionate £12.50 daily charge for motorists with polluting vehicles.A friend of Stratton told me that while there were a “number of factors” in her choice – including emissions, her son’s love of electric cars and a ruptured Achilles’ tendon she suffered earlier this year – the ULEZ was indeed one of them.MEPs and Brussels officials have been scratching their heads about how to get to Glasgow in the greenest way possible. Eurostar has put on a special train service for delegates, starting at Amsterdam this morning, passing through Rotterdam, Brussels and the Channel Tunnel before arriving in London. Once at St Pancras they are planning a “well-being walk” to Euston station to catch the train to Glasgow.Even by Brussels’ standards, expecting a pat on the back for strolling half a mile is a shameless bit of virtue signalling.The Forward Prizes (known as the “poetry Oscars”) descended into La La Land-style farce on Sunday night as their founder, William Sieghart, mixed up his cue cards and forgot to announce the winner of the main £10,000 award.He instead went straight to his closing script, telling the baffled audience: “Thank you all for coming out, and let’s give another round of applause for our winner, Luke Kennard”.Kennard is famous for writing poems of Larry David-ish awkwardness. It all felt strangely apt.Now that Kabul has fallen, government planners are scratching around to find a location for the PM’s traditional pre-Christmas trip to British troops overseas.The last one was in 2019, shortly before the pandemic hit, when Boris Johnson flew to Estonia to serve Christmas lunch to 850 soldiers from the Queen’s Royal Hussars.One idea being put about this year is for the PM to make a proper trip of it and fly 8,000 miles to visit the garrison on the Falkland Islands. They may feel they are owed a visit. Theresa May went to Buenos Aires in 2018, but declined to pop in on the way home.Michael Gove was adamant that he does not keep a diary when he appeared on a panel on the subject at the Cliveden literary festival last week. Asked several times whether he was plotting his memoirs, he insisted he lacked the “perspicacity or the humility”.But doth the Housing Secretary protest too much? Gove noted there was “something of the confessional” about keeping a private record, a hint that all may not be as it seems. Could he be following the advice of Sasha Swire, who kept the existence of her diary secret for 20 years?He certainly has the credentials to be a fine diarist. Gove, a journalist before he was a politician, started his career on the Peterborough column. “Newspaper diaries always have something in them which is true, something in them which is libellous, and something in them which is salacious,” he said.You can make your own mind up where the libels might be.Edited by Tony Diverpeterborough@telegraphMore from NewsPrince Andrew&#39s accuser to use &#39shocking&#39 Newsnight interview against himBBC to analyse all of its programmes for signs of potential biasThe hounding of Kathleen Stock and what it means for our freedom of speechLockdown fanatics should be ashamed of themselvesRevealed: how the Queen turned to male role model to mentor Prince CharlesCop26: rather than crippling our industries to no purpose, let’s make the world’s polluters payMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: uk covid infection rate europe
story: Article bookmarkedFind your bookmarks in your Independent Premium section, under my profileDon&#x27t show me this message again✕✕CloseRelated video: UK Covid-19 cases surge, hospitals strained Cases of Covid-19 in the UK are currently among the highest in Europe and are higher than they were this time last year, when parts of England were under local lockdowns.The vaccine has meant that although case numbers are elevated, there are fewer cases of people with serious illness having to be treated in hospital. However, the more that the virus is able to spread, the more chance there is of it finding a way to break through vaccine defences. Follow Covid news - live: NHS chiefs urge government to implement winter ‘plan B’Figures show that the number of people testing positive for coronavirus currently stands at more than 40,000 per day. Hospital admission numbers are still below levels seen last autumn, although they are rising gradually.According to Professor Neil Ferguson, a member of the Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (Sage) from Imperial College London, there are “a number of reasons” why the UK currently has higher infection levels than many other European countries.Speaking on BBC Radio 4’s Today programme, the professor suggested that the UK has “lower functional immunity in our population than most other western European countries” for a number of reasons.According to Professor Ferguson these reasons include the vaccine rollout starting earlier in the UK than elsewhere and the fact that “we relied more on the AstraZeneca vaccine”.There are other suggestions that less mask wearing, more relaxed rules around mixing and a slowing vaccine rollout could also be behind the surge in figures. But why exactly are cases of Covid rising in the UK?Waning immunity?The UK was one of the fastest countries in the world to rollout the Covid-19 vaccine, meaning that immunity of some of those who were first vaccinated may be lower now.A study of Covid test results of vaccinated people who logged their symptoms in an app, suggested that after about five or six months, the protection against catching the virus wanes significantly.Join our new commenting forumJoin thought-provoking conversations, follow other Independent readers and see their repliesView  comments

title: covid stop spread tips winter
story: simple ways to stop the spread of Covid - including new -minute ruleThe future looks a lot brighter than it did this time last year thanks to the vaccination rollout, but Covid is still here so we must do our bit to prevent its transmissionAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct Cold and flu season always puts pressure on the NHS, and although the Covid vaccines are the best line of defence against the virus, you can still catch it evenyou’re fully vaccinated. You can spread it to others too, and what might be no worse than a cold for you could spell danger to more vulnerable people. Cases are already high after theto school and university, and as peopleto the workplace and socialise indoors, they could rise further. But there are some simple steps you can take to stay safe... Let fresh air in  You’re much more likely to catch Covid- indoors, especially in a confined space with no ventilation. The risk isn’t just about being near other people – mixing indoors can lead to a build-up of the virus in the atmosphere. Meeting outdoors is safer, but that’s not always possible when it’s cold and raining. So whether you’re at home or at work, let fresh air in wherever you can. Leave vents open and windows ajar. If you’re having visitors round, open the windows for ten minutes before, during and after. Don’t worry about losing heat from the houseyou give it a good blast of fresh air – it will soon build up again. Wear a face covering One in three people with Covid- has no symptoms – and you can still get ityou’re fully vaccinated, so it makes sense to wear a face covering indoors whenever you can. Although the rules no longer require you to do so in some indoor settings, you’re protecting others when you wear it. Make sure it covers both your mouth and nose becauseyou do have Covid-, you can release contagious droplets every time you breathe out. So next time you hop on the bus or pop to the shop, think about wearing a face covering to protect those around you – and hopefully they’ll be doing the same. Get testedTaking regular rapid lateral flow tests gives you peace of mind – they’re free, easy to do and give results within  minutes. Go to nhs.uk get-tested or call  to order a pack. They’re also available at some pharmacies: first visit gov.uk get-collect-code to get a code that you will need to show when you collect them.You may also wish to consider taking a testyou’re likely to be in a higher-risk situation that day – for example, mixing in a crowded indoor space such as a nightclub, or visiting vulnerable people. Doing a test will reassure you that you are unlikely to be infectious with Covid-. If you do test positive, you can take action to help stop the virus spreading. Let’s send our children back to school safely. “It is a very good test,” says Public Health England’s Susan Hopkins. “Rapid lateral flow devices are effective at finding people with high viral loads who are most likely to transmit the virus to others.”It’s important to report all test results, whether they’re positive, negative or void, because that helps identy outbreaks early – you can do this at gov.uk report-covid-result, or call  free from your mobile or landline.Take a testyou think you have Covid  If you have symptomsyou must take a PCR test immediately, which you can book online. Evenyour symptoms are mild or you’re not sure, it’s worth getting tested. You can either go to a local test centre or you will be sent a PCR test to do at home. Don’t leave home until you get the result, andyou test positive you’ll need to self-isolate from the day your symptoms startedfor ten days. NHS Test and Trace will continue to protect the public this winter, by helping to break the chains of transmission – and they will inform youyou’ve been in close contact with someone who’s tested positive for Covid. If they contact you, they’ll tell you exactly what you need to do, so just follow their advice.Keep up to date with your jabs  Vaccination is the best defence against serious Covid-related illness. You can still get Covid and pass it onyou’re vaccinated, but it’s a vital step to keep yourself safe. Make sure you book your Covid and flu jabs when invited. This autumn, Covid booster jabs are being offered to more vulnerable groups such as people over , over-s with certain health conditions and frontline health and social care workers, including those who work in care homes.“As we approach winter, everyone should keep following the simple steps to protect themselves and others. “Avoid mixing with othersyou feel unwell, get a PCR test straight awayyou have any Covid symptoms andyou’re meeting people indoors, make sure you let fresh air in. “Remember, the best way to protect yourself and others against Covid- is to get the vaccine, so please do come forwardyouare eligible.”

title: angela rayner apologises unreservedly tory
story: Exclusive: Angela Rayner apologises unreservedly for Tory scum commentsLabour Deputy Leader Angela Rayner said she had thought hard about threats and abuse in political le as she issued an apology for her comments at the Labour Party conferenceLabours deputy leader Angela Rayner Image: PAByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct  Angela Rayner has apologised for her comments about Tory scum in a late-night event at the Labour Party conference. Labouraposs Deputy Leader said she had reflected on her language during a recent period of bereavement leave after losing a close loved one.Ms Rayner said she unreservedly apologised for her remarks and she would be more careful about the language she uses in future. In the wake of the murder of Tory MP Sir David Amess, which police are treating as a terrorist incident, Ms Rayner said she had thought hard about the threats and abuse that feature in political le. In a statement shared with the Mirror, she said: I was angry about where our country is headed and policies that have made le harder for so many people I represent. But I would like to unreservedly apologise for the language I used, and I would not use it again. I will continue to speak my mind, stand up for Labour values and hold the government to account. But in the future I will be more careful about how I do that and in the language that I choose. Angela Rayneraposs full statement is at the bottom of this article  All of us in positions of leadership have a responsibility for our language and rhetoric, whether towards political opponents or anyone  in society, especially those already most vulnerable. As Deputy Leader of the Labour Party I take this responsibility with the utmost seriousness and I am sure that politicians from all parties, the media and others with a prominent role in our public le will also reflect on this shared responsibility. The row centred on comments Ms Rayner made to Labour members from the North West of England at last monthaposs conference in Brighton.In an informal speech, she joked about the quality of food at conference and slapped down a heckler who apparently urged her to challenge Keir Starmer, saying: Youaposve had all the wine that I havenapost had mate!She told members weaposre at a cross roads like in , saying: We face a global threat again. Many of our comrades havenapost made it. Everyone in this room will know somebody whoaposs been seriously ill or died from Covid. Weaposve been through so much and deserve so much better than what weaposve got. She added: I’m sick of shouting from the sidelines and I bet youse lot are as well. We cannot get any worse than a bunch of scum, homophobic, racist, misogynistic, absolute vile [inaudible] Banana Republic, vile, nasty, Etonian [inaudible] piece of scum.” Ms Rayner originally stood by her remarks despite furious demands from Tory MPs for an apology. Keir Starmer distanced himself from the remarks, saying he would not have used them.  Askedshe was talking about Tories in general, Ms Rayner said last month: No, let me be clear, I am talking about members of the Cabinet. She told Sky News last month: I am not saying that anyone who voted for the Conservatives are racist, scummy and homophobic… I’m saying the Prime Minister has said those things and acted in that way. If the Prime Minister wants to apologise and remove himself from those comments he’s made that are homophobic, racist and misogynistic then I will apologise for calling him scummy. Boris Johnson has faced criticism over his past comments, including when he dubbed gay men tank-topped bum boys and described black people as piccaninnies with watermelon smiles. In a  Spectator column, Mr Johnson described children of single mothers as ill-raised, ignorant, aggressive and illegitimate”. In her statement today, Ms Rayner also spoke out over the terrying threats she has received in the wake of the row over her comments.They have had a devastating impact on me, my children and others close to me, she said.It shakes you when you get these threats. You worry about the safety of your home, your office and everything in your le. And it takes its toll on the people who work for me too. She said her staff should not be required to deal with death threats on a day-to-day basis. Two men have been arrested since yesterday in South Yorkshire and Halax as part of a police investigation into “threatening and abusive phone calls, emails and letters” to Ms Rayner. It is understood further enquiries are still ongoing across multiple police forces. A third man, Benjamin Ilfe, , of Chatteris, Cambridgeshire, today pleaded guilty to sending a threatening email to Ms Rayner, and also pleaded guilty to possessing a quantity of cannabis on Wednesday when he was arrested. The former delivery driver warned Ms Rayner to watch your back and your kids and said I already found your personal home address in the threatening email on October , Huntingdon Magistratesapos Court heard. Ilfe was sentenced to  weeks in prison suspended for  months. A probation officer told the court Ilfe had felt Ms Rayner was partially responsible for the attack on Sir David following her use of language. He was later apologetic and remorseful for sending the threatening e-mail, the court heard.  Angela Rayneraposs statement in full I have been off work over the last couple of weeks after losing a close loved one. Grief is the burden we bear for love and losing someone close is something that we all experience at some point in our lives, but that knowledge doesn’t make it any easier when it happens to you. So I can’t imagine what the family of Sir David Amess are going through, but I know they will be hurting. I send my heartfelt condolences to them. Sir David was a fine parliamentarian, a proud advocate for his constituents and above all such a kind, generous and warm-hearted man. He will be missed on all sides of the House. As a society we need to offer better support to people who are going through bereavement, loss and other traumatic or dficult experiences in their personal lives. I hope that the fact that I took time to deal with a bereavement will encourage other people to do the same when they are going through grief or trauma. While I have been away from the cut and thrust of Parliament I have reflected on our political debate and the threats and abuse that now seem to feature all too often. I have also reflected on what I said at an event at Labour Party conference. I was angry about where our country is headed and policies that have made le harder for so many people I represent. But I would like to unreservedly apologise for the language I used, and I would not use it again. I will continue to speak my mind, stand up for Labour values and hold the government to account. But in the future I will be more careful about how I do that and in the language that I choose. All of us in positions of leadership have a responsibility for our language and rhetoric, whether towards political opponents or anyone  in society, especially those already most vulnerable. As Deputy Leader of the Labour Party I take this responsibility with the utmost seriousness and I am sure that politicians from all parties, the media and others with a prominent role in our public le will also reflect on this shared responsibility. I want to address the threats I have received recently. In the past I have been reluctant to speak out about the abuse that I receive because I fear that doing so will only make the situation worse. However, in recent weeks the threats that I have received against my le and the lives of close family have been so terrying and explicit that I could not stay silent and simply continue to take it as ‘part of the job’. They have had a devastating impact on me, my children and others close to me. It shakes you when you get these threats. You worry about the safety of your home, your office and everything in your le. And it takes its toll on the people who work for me too. My staff come to work and do their jobs with dedication and professionalism. They bear the brunt of much of this abuse and then get on with their working day. Dealing with death threats and liaising with the police about their safety should not be a standard part of the day-to-day working le of a Member of Parliament or their staff. So I want to thank the police officers from Greater Manchester, South Yorkshire and Cambridgeshire Police who have arrested a number of people in recent days and demonstrated the utmost professionalism, courtesy and kindness both in carrying out their investigations and in supporting me, my family and my staff during what has been a very dficult time. I and my team will continue work with them to ensure that the perpetrators of these crimes are brought to justice After attending a funeral on Monday I will be back to work, rolling my sleeves up and standing up for my brilliant constituents in Ashton-under-Lyne, Droylsden and Failsworth – along with everyone who needs a Labour government. title: conversion therapy legal uk abhorrent
story: Is conversion therapy legal in the UK  Abhorrent practice could result in prisonWomen and Equalities minister Liz Truss is taking steps to restrict the practice of conversion therapy on unwilling adults. Here’s what you need to know about the proposed bill Image: BPM MediaByMalvika Padin:,  Oct | comments Conversion therapy is a practice that aims to change peopleaposs sexual orientation or gender identity.In May this year, Liz Truss announced her intention to introduce a bill that bans conversion therapy.On October , the government has progressed the bill with Truss launching a six-week consultation on the best way to legislate for such a ban. The consultation which will run till December  is meant to allow iniduals to express their views on these proposals, make any amendments and decide the most effective way to impose the ban. A bill will be then drawn up by next spring, with the aim of putting it on to the statute book by May .  Besides the consultation a research report on the impact of conversion therapy, completed by Coventry University, will also be published. Will conversion therapy be banned in UK  Under the government’s proposals, all kinds of conversion therapy will be banned in England and Wales for anyone under the age of  as well as adults who are vulnerable and not able to properly consent. But the Government Equalities Office said though they plan to crack down “coercive and abhorrent” practices they don’t “intend to ban adults from seeking such counselling freely.” This means that the proposed bill will only restrict conversion therapy and not completely ban it with non-vulnerable adults being allowed to seek out the therapythey consent to it.  What will the proposals to ban conversion therapy include  The government’s proposals which are being consulted includes :Ensuring that physical conversion therapy acts are sentenced appropriately and introducing a new offence for so-called talking conversion therapies. Clamping down on conversion therapy by making it a potential aggravating factor for a longer jail sentence Holding anyone found guilty of conversion therapy offences accountable and making sure that any profit they obtained from those crimes are removed, as well as strengthening the case for iniduals to be disqualied from holding a senior role in a charitythey are convicted of a conversion therapy offence Introducing Conversion Therapy Protection Orders to protect potential victims from undergoing the practice, including abroad with measures including removing passports of potential victims, who are at risk of being taken overseas for conversion therapy Exploring further measures to prevent the promotion of conversion therapyThe government will make funding available to support victims of conversion therapy practices. A competitive tendering process for a new government-funded support service for victims and those at risk of conversion therapy will also be launched in November. title: covid lockdowns left kids vulnerable
story: England lockdowns left kids vulnerable to exploitation as social service referrals droppedMore than half of those in need by the end of March this year were male, seven in  were white, and children aged  and over accounted for the majority Image: Getty ImagesByAletha Adu:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsVulnerable children in England fell off the radar for much of last year, leaving more than , children at risk of gang exploitation. Teachers are often the first to spot the need for children to be referred to social services to assess a child. But over the two lockdowns last year, school referrals fell by %, leaving thousands at risk of criminal exploitation, according to figures from the Department for Education. Kids in London appear to be most at risk with  children with the potential of being lured into gang crime and  children identied as being at risk as a result of sexual exploitation. In the East of England,  children were identied as being at risk as a result of involvement with gangs and  were identied as being at risk as a result of child sexual exploitation. And when assessed by a social worker, more than half of the children in need were experiencing abuse or neglect. . The most common additional factors identied in assessments during the year included concerns about a parent or carer being a victim of domestic violence. A child begins an episode of need when they are referred to children’s social care services.  Anne Longfield, Chair of the Commission on Young Lives and former Children’s Commissioner for England, responding to the figures, said: Even though schools were open for vulnerable children, many did not attend, and it is very concerning that many have dropped off the radar since. “We need to ask why we are still losing thousands of marginalised teenagers to the ruthless criminals who are so adept at spotting and exploiting vulnerable children and how we can find better solutions to stop it from happening. “The number of children being referred to social services because of fears of gang exploitation is extremely troubling and likely only the tip of the iceberg. During a period when the country was in lockdown twice, thousands of vulnerable children were still being sucked into gangs, serious violence and crime or sexually exploited. “I am particularly worried about the very sharp drop in referrals during the two school lockdowns.  “It is clear these problems are not going to solve themselves and we are still giving too many abusers and exploiters a free pass to use and harm children. “The systems that are supposed to be there to help vulnerable children are under pressure and badly need reforming. It is time to find new ways of bringing hope and success to young people who fall through the gaps and end up in danger. Earlier this year, the Childrenaposs Society said more than , children in England are thought to be involved in gangs. In the Autumn Budget, Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £m cash injection for youth services and the funding of ‘family hubs’ and £m to support , families who face complex issues that could lead to family breakdown. He claimed it was enough to fund up to  youth clubs across the country. Ms Longfield added: “I welcome the announcements of funding for children and families in the Budget. But this needs to be the start of something much bigger to enable all children and young people to be part of this new era, and so that the most vulnerable children are given the same chances to level up as any other child.” Comment MORE ON PoliticsEducationSchoolsSocial servicesCrimeTeenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: rishi sunaks budget no inspiration
story: Rishi Sunaks Budget had no inspiration, no insight, and no hope for the futureBridget Phillipson, Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury, on what Rishi Sunaks bankers budget should have contained - and what Labour would do dferentlyBridget Phillipson writes in the Mirror tonight Image: Getty ImagesopinionByBridget Phillipson, Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWednesdayaposs Budget was not what Britain needed. There was no plan to tackle the growing cost of living crisis. No plan to reduce the tax burden on working people and small businesses. No plan to grow our economy in the years ahead or to create the high-wage high skilled jobs of the future. No plan to deal with the huge challenge of climate change for the years ahead. A Labour budget would have been very dferent, because Labour wants a brighter and better future for our country. We’d have invested in dealing with the challenge of climate change and fitting our country for the future - starting with proper insulation for millions of homes to reduce emissions and drive down soaring heating bills.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section We’d have changed the way the government does business to ensure we buy, make, and sell more in Britain, supporting manufacturers and our amazing small businesses. Growing our economy is the best route to better services and a better future for everyone. It means more jobs and higher tax revenues to invest in our services. Instead, after a decade of weak growth, Wednesday’s budget saw taxation go up to the highest level for seventy years. Working people are paying an ever higher price for eleven years of Tory economic failure. We’d have invested in the future of our public services, especially for children, as we recover from the pandemic, with a properly funded education catch-up plan so every child has the chance to succeed. We only get one chance as a country to get these calls right, and the Tories are getting it wrong. We’d have cancelled the Prime Minister’s new yacht, and spent the money on policing hubs and more special constables.  And we’d have reformed our tax system, as Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves set out at conference. We’d make it fair, so those with the broadest shoulders make the bigger contribution. We’d bring it up to date, so high street family firms face a level playing field with tech giants like Amazon. We’d make it more efficient too, by removing unfair tax breaks, like the one that benefits private schools - and spend that money on giving every child a better start. What we needed was a Budget for our future, for growth, and for our public services. The Tories failed again to deliver what we need. Labour would be building a brighter and better future. title: sunaks budget more proof hes
story: Sunaks budget more proof hes out of touch but Labour would put working people firstShadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves on how Boris Johnsons government and Rishi Sunaks budget leave working people paying more for less for three reasons - economic mismanagement, an unfair tax system and wasteful spendingShadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves responds to the Budget opinionByRachel Reeves:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWe needed a Budget for a secure economy. Instead, we got a Chancellor disconnected from the reality of a growing cost of living crisis. As energy bills soar, the Chancellor piled the biggest tax burden in peacetime on working people. As businesses on our high streets are held back by outdated business rates, the Chancellor gave bankers a tax cut. A decade of sluggish growth. Public services cut to the bone. Billions of pounds of taxpayer money wasted. But still, no plan to boost our economy. The Government will always blame others for its failures. But the reality is that working people are paying more for less for three simple reasons. Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  Economic mismanagement. An unfair tax system. And wasteful spending. Our country deserves better. But they’ll never get it under a Chancellor who gives with one hand, but takes so much more with the other. People are getting wise to this. Every month they feel the pinch. They are tired of the smoke and mirrors, of the bluster, of the  dawns, of the promises of jam tomorrow. Use our autumn Budget tax calculator to see how it will impact your money - The solution starts with growth. Labour would put working people first. The Government is caught in a bind of its own making. Low growth leads to less money for public services, unless taxes rise. Labour would use the power of government and business to create the next generation of quality jobs right here, in Britain. We’d tax fairly, spend wisely and after a decade of faltering growth, we’d get Britain’s economy firing on all cylinders. That is what a Labour budget would have done today. title: tory dwp ministers no research
story: Tory DWP ministers do no research on how cost of living crisis hits kids hungerAn MP asked a new welfare minister for any research on the effect of the £ Universal Credit cut and spiralling food and energy bills - and got the answer: We have not undertaken research of this kind" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Cute-blonde-boy-shows-empty-plate-hunger-concept.jpg" width"" "" Child hunger is a worryImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Oct | comments Tory welfare ministers have not done a single piece of research on how rising energy bills, food costs and the £ Universal Credit cut will hit hungry kids. Lib Dem MP Munira Wilson hit out at the admission after millions were left out of a rise in benefits in the Budget - despite fears inflation could hit % next year.The Chancellor announced a taper rate boost for .million benefit claimants who work - weeks after cutting UC by £ a week. But the IFS think tank warned millions of claimants who don’t or can’t work will not see an extra penny. They include .million Brits who are not required to work at all due to sickness, disability and caring responsibilities. The IFS said UC looks set to rise by around % next April - but that could be wiped out by % inflation at the same time. Ahead of the Budget, Ms Wilson asked “what research and preparation” the Department for Work and Pensions had done “on the impact ofrising energy prices,rising fuel bills,potential food shortages andthe removal of the £ uplt to universal credit on familiesapos ability to fund their childrensapos meals while at school”.  But DWP minister David Rutley replied: “We have not undertaken research of this kind.” He added the £ uplt was temporary and the government had invested in a plan for jobs, higher Healthy Start food vouchers, a £ million Household Support Fund and the Covid vaccine rollout. Ms Wilson said: “For the government to not commit any research on the impacts of their own damaging policies is complacent at best and heartless at worst. The Tories think they can impose dreadful policies and get away with it, they’re taking the good faith of people across the country for granted. The budget does nothing to help those households petried by spiralling energy prices, and the Chancellor’s announcement on Universal Credit is giving just a third of what he snatched away. Millions of families will not be helped at all but this government. Read more While the public face multiple crises at their doorsteps this winter, the government have plugged their ears and not bothered to do their homework.” DWP officials pointed out the department was not formally responsible for issues like energy prices and food supply. Mr Rutley wrote: We are also investing up to £m in the Holiday Activities and Food programme, which has been expanded to every Local Authority across England. Participating children are benefitting from a range of support, including healthy and nutritious meals as well as fun and engaging activities covering the Easter, summer and Christmas holidays in . title: without lowest paid workers vital
story: Without lowest-paid workers to do the vital "menial" jobs we are all screwedBrian Reade witnesses Brexit coming home to roost as restaurant waiting staff become overwhelmed and the dirty dishes pile up - and no p rise in the minimum wage is going to cure thatRishi Sunaks p rise in minimum wage wont cure our labour shortage Image: Getty ImagesopinionByBrian Reade:,  Oct | comments I pent last weekend in the lovely city of Bristol and came away with a few observations. The Edward Colston statue that was torn down by protesters last summer and now lies in a museum next to factual information that puts the controversial figure in context, is in a far better place.In the majority of pubs, restaurants and cafes, signs hung in windows saying “staff needed”. A grim reality echoed at my hotel, which was happy to charge £. for a gin and tonic but took so long trying to get guests seated for their £ breakfasts, many gave up and left. It wasn’t the fault of the few, virtually all European, staff who were working extremely hard, but the chronic shortage of them. It meant dirty dishes sat on deserted tables as hungry faces frowned in y queues. Someone I spoke to later that day said it had been the same at his hotel so he went back to his room, stuck the kettle on and nibbled on a complimentary biscuit.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Four days later, at a restaurant in Liverpool, it was a similar picture. People walking out because they’d waited  minutes for the only waiter to take their drinks order while used plates piled up on the bar. The lie that our expanding ­hospitality sector would cope without EU workers is being brutally exposed. The myth that there was a huge reserve of unemployed Britons crying out to do their jobs, even more so. It didn’t need the Office of Budget Responsibility to tell us this week the UK economy will be twice as badly hit by Brexit than by Covid because we’re seeing the evidence with our own eyes. If you tell foreign workers that they’re no longer welcome here, most won’t come. If you offer British workers the bare minimum to do the dirtiest jobs for long hours at zero hours’ notice, most won’t take them. Get the latest news direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters So crops lie rotting in our fields and plates lie unwashed in our restaurants.No p rise in the minimum wage is going to cure that. The most simplistic hood about Brexit was that the solution to our economic woes was giving British jobs to British workers. The answer to our woefully poor productivity was always about creating well-paid jobs for all people who want to work, regardless of their birthplace. The one good thing that may come out of our self-inflicted economic ­sabotage is that it might make society realise that without the lowest-paid workers doing what are classed as menial jobs, we’re screwed. That the workers who do the dirty tasks for the worst pay are as vital to ­companies as all other employees. That you can keep a hotel running when a few highly-paid ­executives are off sick but when you’ve got nobody to wash your dishes and reset the tables you can’t . Because the capitalist machine collapses when some of the cogs don’t turn. Multi-millionaire Chancellor Rishi Sunak may have cut the price of ­champagne to make his chums in their gentleman’s clubs feel better. But when there’s no one around to pour it they may as well be sat outside swigging scrumpy from a can.Comment MORE ON Boris JohnsonTory GovernmentConservative PartyPoliticsPetrol pricesAfter BrexitBrexit" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: your family could eligible part
story: Your family could be eligible for part of a huge £ million support packageHundreds of thousands could be set to benefit following the chancellors budget announcement that a £ million fund will be made available to help the UKs most vulnerable familiesThe programme aims to help families who are working through complex challenges Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByHarry Thompson:,  Oct | comments As part of his budget on Wednesday, chancellor Rishi Sunak announced he would be making available £ million in additional funding for families.It is understood the fund will split across four broad areas: £ million to go into Family Hubs , £ million to support new and expecting parentsapos mental health, and £ million into dfering family support programmes. A further £ million is expected to become available over the next three years as part of the Supporting Families Programme which aims to help vulnerable families working through challenging issues. It is believed that , families in the UK are set to benefit from this boost. The Treasury reports that by the end of the three years the new funding will take investment in the Supporting Families Programme to almost £ million. Am I eligible for the Supporting Families Programme fund   The exact details of the how Supporting Families funding will be vied out are yet to be fully disclosed, and so at this stage it is hard to tell exactly who is set to benefit. However, a government report published in March this year providing guidance to local authorities on how to enact the Supporting Families Programme prior to the budgetaposs new cash injection identied six key aposproblemsapos that each potential recipient must exhibit at least two of. It adds that recipients must have dependent children or have a child on the way. The six aposproblemsapos that would make families eligible are: Staying safe in the community: Parents or children involved in crime or anti-social behaviour Getting a good education and skills for le: Children who have not been attending school regularly Improving children’s le chances: children who need additional support, from the earliest years to adulthood  Improving living standards: families experiencing or at risk of worklessness, homelessness or financial dficulties Staying safe in relationships: families affected by domestic abuse Living well, improving physical and mental health and wellbeing: Parents and children with a range of health needs While it remains to be see whether the latest bump to the Supporting Families budget will change the criteria, it is likely it wonapost stray too far from the previous stipulations. How is the £ million boost been regarded my MPs  Chancellor Rishi Sunack said: “I passionately believe that we have a duty to give young families and their children the best possible start in le. I’m thrilled that this investment will guarantee that thousands of families across England are given support to lead healthy and happy lives.” Discussing the package ahead of the budget Labouraposs shadow education secretary, Kate Green said: This supposed commitment rings hollow after  years of Conservative cuts have forced the closure of over , children’s centres – cutting off the early learning that sets children up for le. She added: “This has come alongside the government stripping away early intervention children’s services, allowing problems to escalate into crises. This is a smokescreen for the Conservatives’ failure to deliver for families.” Comment MORE ON Conservative PartyMental healthPoliticsThe Budget" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ive spent 150k pets eat
story: Ive spent £k on my pets - they eat luxury food and exercise on treadmillsOnlyFans model Camila Elle, , from Florida, says she spends more on her pets than she does on herself, splashing out on top quality food and grooming bills for her fur babiesCamila Elle spends thousands every month on her pets Image: Jam Press @camilaelleByEve WagstaffJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct | commentsA model who adores her pampered pets says sheaposs spent more than £, treating them to the very best in le. Camila Elle, , from Florida in the US, considers her pets children and spends thousands of pounds every month spoiling them. The model, who owns three cats Yuumi, Miso and Tigger, and a dog called Zed, said she loves her fur babies more than anything in the world. She added: They are my le. Of course I buy them the best of everything.Camila, who has more than , followers on her Instagram account, @camilaelle, said her pets take priority over her.I spend far more on them than I do on myself each month, she explained.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here I’ll think nothing of dropping  on something really tasty for their dinner but I’ll only have cheap noodles. Two of the cats are pedigree breeds and the other is an adopted black cat. Miso is a Persian and she cost ,, and Yuumi is a British Longhair, and she was also ,. “The most expensive was my dog Zed, who cost ,. He’s so gorgeous, an Italian greyhound-whippet-mix, or “Whippig” for short.  The -year-old can afford to splash out on her pets because she makes seven figures every year on OnlyFans. In comparison to pet owners in the UK, Camila spends far more on her cats and dog - with the average owner splashing out between £, and £, over the course of their fur babyaposs le. Each month, Camila estimates she spends the equivalent of £ on grooming, food and medication for Miso, Yuumi, Tigger and Zed. She said: “My fluffy kitties need to be groomed twice a month because of their long hair, which costs each time. “Miso is on Prozac because sheaposs an anxious girl and that costs a month for her prescription.  “When it comes to their diets I make sure they all eat raw food as it’s the best thing for them and their coats. “I make sure they get the best delicate cuts, beef liver, chicken hearts, duck liver, minnows and mussels, greek yogurt. She added the food bill comes to nearly £ per week - butone of the pets has a birthday coming up theyaposre treated to something even more special. “I also know the cats hate feeling dirty so I’ve put three automatic litter trays in each room so they’re never caught out,” she said. But a healthy lestyle is all about balance, and Camila ensures her pets are in tip-top condition by making sure they get regular exercise.  Sheaposs splashed out on two treadmills for her cats and dog, so they can burn off excess calories. She added: I also have five cat towers around the house for them to play on and at the moment I’m having a custom-made cat tree being built. The model estimates the tree - which will be six feet wide and  feet tall - will cost around £, to build. And she makes sure itaposs not just her cats who have plenty to keep them busy, ensuring she buys a new toy for Zed every week. She said: “He’s so clever he gets bored of them very quickly. We go to the beach every day for walks and playing with the ball, which he loves. “If I can’t take him because of work I’ll pay for a walker to take him out. Every week I also take Zed to see a police trainer so he can learn new tricks.” Camila admits one of her biggest costs when it comes to her babies is the vet bills, explaining sheaposs a health conscious mum.Do you pamper your pets  If so, we want to hear from you! Email jessica.taylor@reachplc“I would say they go every six weeks, which costs around  each time, she said. “I definitely take better care of my pets than I do myself! “I know I want to have children one day but Miso, Yuumi, NAME and Zed will always be my first babies.” Comment MORE ON Animals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news -things-tesco-employees-want-"Martin Lewis explains deals on Christmas shopping at TescoByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsOver the last  months, weaposve come to appreciate supermarket workers more than ever before as they bravely continued to go to work every single day during lockdown. But pandemic aside, itaposs never been an easy job - with workers having to stack shelves, work on tills, mop up spillages, check stock, and deal with members of the public. While weaposd like to hope all customers are polite and kind to supermarket staff, itaposs likely not everyone is particularly understanding of their dficult job. According to one former Tesco employee, some people can be downright rude.Speaking to Kent Live, the ex-worker lted the lid on things theyaposd love to say to shoppers - butthey want to keep their job, theyaposd best keep quiet.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here While some quips are funny, and probably something we can all relate to, others are very insightful.. I know we open in three minutes, but I canapost unlock the doors just because youaposre standing thereYouaposre early, and thataposs great. But we open at am, and that means opening at am. I know it might be raining and cold outside, and Iaposm sorry about that. But looking at me with a face like thunder isnapost going to speed this process up. . Huffing and puffing in the queue wonapost make me go any quicker on the checkouts Itaposs a busy shop and it takes time to get through all the customers. Iaposm not doing this on purpose.. The dread of having to ID someone - before finding out theyaposre Please take it as a compliment that Iaposm asking you to prove your age, rather than an insult. Iaposm not doing this for fun, itaposs just my job.. The Tesco fleeces are so incredibly comfortableThey might not be the most flattering item of clothing, but theyaposre incredibly warm for when we have to work in the freezer section - not to mention walking to work in the winter.  . Feeling like watched prey as you take the reduced stickers to the packs of minceItaposs almost asshoppers have a radar for the yellow stickers - hunting for bargains and pennies off full-price items. . The mindless game you play trying to squeeze another box of dolly mix on the shelf so you can finally get it out of the cageWe all know those huge cages can get in the way, but getting the products off them is the real task. . Trust me, I donapost have free Tesco Meal Deals for lunch More often than not, we end up opting for Tesco Value Everyday Value thick sliced bread that was left over in the staff room by the managers.  . The eye roll when a customer begs with you to knock pennies off an item The last box of  pack fish fingers has been opened - itaposs probably just a damaged box but hey, Iaposll knock  per cent off to avoid the drama. . We donapost have any responsibility over the decision to charge p for carrier bags Charging for carrier bags is saving the planet, and not something we should be complaining about. But evenyou are annoyed about the charge, thereaposs nothing I can do about it.  . Clocking onto loyal customersapos routines Thataposs right, Barbara. I see you doing the weekly shop at pm every Wednesday. I saw you last week, and the week before that, and the week before that... . Trust me, no one hates the self service tills more than me And impatiently waving your product in front of the scanner isnapost going to make my le any easier. I hold the power to unlock these bad boys, and the red light flashing above you has already told me you need my help. news uk-news british-skipper-faces-trial-huge-"France seizes British boat amidst Brexit fishing rowByAndy LinesChief reporterPeter Allen:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments The skipper of a British trawler seized by the French during an escalating row over fishing licences is to go on criminal trial and faces a fine equivalent to more than £,.Prosecutors in Le Havre on Friday confirmed that the captain of the Cornelis Gert Jan will appear before judges on August .He has been charged with ‘acts of unauthorised sea fishing in French maritime salt waters by a third party vessel to the European Union ’. It comes after Catherine Colonna, France’s ambassador to the UK, was summoned to the Foreign Office in London to explain ‘disappointing and disproportionate’ threats of retaliation by Paris over what it claims is a lack of licences for French boats to fish in UK waters.The skipper of the Cornelis, who had not been publicly identied, is specically accused of having fished , kg of scallops in the French exclusive economic zone without holding a valid licence.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  He now faces a fine of €,as well as administrative sanctions, said le Havre deputy prosecutor Cyrille Fournier. Mr Fournier said: The captain of the Cornelis Gert Jan was given a summons by maritime police to appear at the hearing of the Criminal Court of Le Havre on August , . The prosecutor added: After verication, the captain of the vessel did not have the authorisation required to fish in the French exclusive economic zone.This was despite claims by the owners of the Cornelis that the boat had been fishing legally when it was detained on Wednesday night.Andrew Brown, director of Scottish firm MacDuff Shellfish, said she was being used as a apospawnapos by angry French ministers. Mr Brown said before news of the court action: MacDuffaposs fishing activity is entirely legal. We are looking to the UK government to defend the rights of the UK fishing fleet and ensure that the fishing rights provided under the Brexit fishing agreement are fully respected by the EU.On Friday morning, the Cornelis was still moored in Le Havre - still banned from leaving the port. The French ambassador has been summoned the Foreign Office in London later today to explain why the boat was detained. The crew of the Cornelis Gert Jan are still onboard as the legal battle rumbles on. It is moored up in a quiet area of the harbour with a sign saying “no unauthorised entry” on the gangplank. Boat owner Andrew Brown insisted they had all the right paperwork and the vessel should be allowed to leave as soon as possible. The boat had headed out from Shoreham, Sussex, early on Tuesday morning, and had expected to spend five days catching scallops in the English Channel.  Her seizure is the latest move by France in an ongoing row with the UK over who has rights to fishing grounds in the Channel now Britain has left the EU. The Cornelis’s haul has been thrown back overboard by the French, while her skipper spoke to an examining magistrate with the help of a French lawyer. Gendarmes on board the Athos – the police boat named after one of the Three Musketeers which detained the Cornelis– also fined a second, unidentied British boat on Wednesday. Her skipper was dealt with for initially refusing police permission to board, but then left toto the UK. Clement Beaune, Franceaposs Europe minister, has said we need to speak the language of force to Britain because it is the only thing this government understands. He was immediately accused of sabre rattling by British critics, as was Annick Girardin, the Maritime Minister in Paris, who said: It’s not war, but it is a fight. Referencing Brexit, Ms Girardin said: We are going to ask the European Commission to tell the United Kingdom that it is not respecting its agreement and therefore that retaliatory measures can be put in place. Before Brexit, French fishermen had free rights to fish in UK waters under EU law and only had to apply to their own government for a licence. But earlier this year the new Brexit Agreement came into force, meaning French fishermen now need to apply to the UK for a licence. All vessels that fished in UK waters aposfor at least four years between  and apos should be granted the same level of access until at least , when it will be up to the UK and France to negotiate new deals. The UK is asking French boats to provide tracking and fishing quota data for those years to qualy for a permit. The French have protested, saying smaller vessels under m do not collect this data and are being unfairly punished. The Brexit Agreement makes no mention of such data, they argue. British environment minister George Eustice told Parliament the seizure of the boat is being aposurgentlyapos looked into, but ruled out any apostit for tatapos retaliation. UK vessels with their licence to fish in EU waters should be allowed to do so uninterrupted, he said. title: cop26 climate conference held uk
story: COP climate conference to be held in UK city voted worlds friendliest placeThe upcoming COP summit is expected to be a historic moment in humanitys fight to save the planet from disastrous atmospheric heating. But where is COP being held and why is it being hosted in the UK Glasgow Image: GettyByHarry Thompson:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsCOP is set to take place in one of the UKaposs most adored cities - Glasgow. The likes of the USA, China and India are all expected to come to the talks, as are key faces such as Greta Thunberg and Sir David Attenborough. COP, which stands for aposconference of the partiesapos and  signies that this is the th meeting of its kind.It is set to begin this Sunday  October and will run to Friday  November.The event is hoped to produce a global route forward to tackle climate change through international cooperation, with  countries expected to take part in the conversation in how to best cope with man-made heating from the use of fossil fuels. It is also expected Glasgow will see the arrival of protesters who are expected to cause disruption during the summit. The event is potentially the biggest environmental milestone since aposs Paris Agreement, drawn up during COP and is regarded as many as the last real chance to create a meaningful solution to the heightening climate crisis. Where is COP being held  COP is set to take place in the UK, with some , people and over  world leaders to due descend on Glasgow in what will be the largest summit ever hosted by the UK. The event was supposed to take place last year, but was pushed back due to the pandemic. Her Majesty the Queen has been forced to pull out of the opening reception of the agreement due to a night spent in hospital earlier this month. Glasgow, which was recently labelled the worldaposs friendliest city, was chosen by the COP Bureau to host the event.The UK and Italy are the joint presidents of the event—something that changes each time the event takes place—and they in turn selected Glasgow to be the setting for the crucial talks. It is understood they selected Glasgow due to prior success hosting international events, its reputation as one of the worldaposs more sustainable cities alongside high quality facilities capable of handling large crowds. In  the Global Forum on Human Settlements awarded Glasgow the status of Global Green City, with the city itself holding a target of carbon neutrality by . It is understood the event will be held across two dferent zones. The Blue Zone will be where main talks between powers will be held and willas a place to bring together delegates to discuss. The Green Zone will be run by the British government and will be a place for the public, as well as artists and grassroots organisations to participate in the events. title: dad 37 who fell lake
story: Dad, , who fell into lake at family park died after finding blister on his legBen Smith-Crallan, , had toppled into a lake at Botanic Gardens, in Southport, before developing rare infection Necrotising Fasciitis Ben Smith-Crallan died after developing an infection from falling in a lake Image: Southport VisiterByBenjamin Roberts-Haslam:,  Oct " data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Ben-Smith-Crallan.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top"" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Ben-Smith-Crallan.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top"" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Ben-Smith-Crallan.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsA dad died from a rare bacterial infection after falling into a lake and cutting his leg. Ben Smith-Crallan noticed a blister before his health deteriorated and he was placed in a coma after accidentally taking a splash at Botanic Gardens, in Southport.The -year-old had developed Necrotising Fasciitisfollowing the freak incident and had to have his leg amputated before his death in June .More than three years later, the park is set to make changes to the lake following a campaign by Benaposs family and friends, reports the Liverpool Echo. Two aeration fountains are set to be installed as part of the first phase of the lakeside improvements at the attraction which sees hundreds of thousands of people visit the each year.  The costs for the changes will be covered by recent fundraising efforts from the Make a Change for Ben group. It has donated all funds raised in his memory to date to the Botanic Gardens Community Association, a long-standing voluntary group overseeing maintenance and activities at the park. At the end of August, Sefton Council met with members of the two groups and outlined ideas for up to £, in improvements for the lake and lakeside area.  At the meeting, the groups agreed to prioritise the aerating fountains as the first phase, with the equipment now on order and works expected to be completed this autumn.Cllr Ian Moncur, Cabinet Member for Health and Wellbeing, said:“I’m really pleased to be able to say that we are moving forward with the initial improvements to the lake area at the Botanic Gardens and I do want to pass on a huge thank you to everyone in the community who has contributed to the local fundraising efforts to date.“I know that fundraising activities continue and the generosity of our communities that know and love this park is unwavering. “Our Green Sefton officers have a long-standing partnership with the Botanic Gardens Community Association and will continue to work with them and all community partners to drive forward further improvements for the whole park. This is in line with our longer-term vision to source a multi-million-pound investment to ensure this historic site can be enjoyed for generations to come.” David Rawsthorne, Make a Change for Ben Campaign Founder, said: “I am absolutely delighted that our campaign and Sefton Council have worked hand-in-hand over the last three months to secure local contractors to carry out works on the aeration fountains. Huge thanks to all the people who have got involved and helped to get us where we are now.” Comment MORE ON Sefton Council" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dad tells cops i effectively
story: Dad tells cops I effectively killed my son after boy, , dies of head injuryThomas Hughes, , and Emma Tustin, , are accused of murdering Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, who died after suffering horric head injuries at their home in Solihull.A dad whose son died from a horric head injury told police I effectively killed my son Image: BPM MediaByCarl JacksonKate Buck:,  Oct A dad whose son died from a horric head injury told police I effectively killed my son after the six-year-old was battered to death, a court has heard. Thomas Hughes, , and Emma Tustin, , are accused of murdering Arthur Labinjo-Hughes at their home in Solihull, West Midlands.The schoolboy, six, suffered fatal brain damage from an alleged bang to the head and shaking injury on June , , reports Birmingham Live. Coventry Crown Court was told Hughes gave a series of police interviews in the aftermath of Arthuraposs death, and in one told cops: I effectively killed my son. It was not intentional.  Jurors have been hearing horric details of Arthuraposs le, and were told he lived through a campaign of cruelty before his death that matched the “medical definition of child torture”. On Friday, they were told how Arthur told Hughes he was the worldaposs worst dad and recalled the little boy saying he only loved his grandparents and his uncle Blake. Hughes told the court: He said I was the worldaposs worst dad. Said he hated me. Itaposs all words. But words play on people sometimes. He has never been as nasty to me as what he was towards Emma. At times I walked through the door and found Emma in the kitchen crying. Yes she did get snappy. She hated herself for biting back. A post-mortem revealed  bruises on Arthuraposs body, and doctors said he had so much salt in his system he was unable to put up a fight before his death.  Birmingham Crown Court was told he had over six spoons worth of salt in his body - the highest level a medic had ever seen. The little boy was also allegedly segregated and isolated for up to  hours a day - and was deprived of food, a bed and clothes. Hughes admitted in court he could account for most of the bruises on Arthuraposs body, Birmingham Live reports. He said he knew where all of the pressure points were and would pinch Arthuraposs neck for around  seconds with a force of six or seven out of . Hughes said: When he was lying on his back I didnapost want to keep picking him up. I put my foot on his stomach almost to take the wind out of him. It paints me in a dferent light altogether. Three or four out of . Just so I didnapost have to keep picking him up. It paints me as a monster Iaposm aware. Iaposm  years old, nearly , for nearly all of those years Iaposve never been in trouble with the police.  Nobody would have a bad word to say. But the last few weeks they would have lots of bad things to say. That last few months I effectively turned into a monster. Thataposs how Iaposm going to be seen now. Iaposm not going to be the dad whose boy worshipped the ground he walked on. Hughes added: I never intended to hurt him. Itaposs a case of discipline gone too far. Gone horribly wrong.The court was told this week that Arthuraposs grandmother called social services weeks before he died and said she would send them pictures of the bruises but they didnapost want to see them.Tustin and Hughes are accused of multiple counts of child cruelty, which include claims they fed him salt and forced Arthur to endure systematic, cruel behaviour of physical and psychological abuse in the weeks before he died. Prosecutor Jonas Hankin QC said: Both defendants participated in a campaign of cruelty intended to cause Arthur signicant harm and suffering. Violence and intimidation, both physical and verbal, were routine.  “Arthur’s visible injuries, his miserable physical condition and obvious despair provided each defendant with a daily reminder of the s to which the other would go to cause him harm.” Arthuraposs death came only three months after his father had moved into Tustinaposs home, whereas before he lived with Hughes and his extended family, in an annexe in the garden of Hughesapos parents. Arthur had been placed into his dadaposs care after his mother was jailed for  years for stabbing her boyfriend to death. Hughes, , of Stroud Road, Shirley, and Emma Tustin, , of Cranmore Road, Shirley, have both pleaded not guilty to murder. Tustin admitted one count of child cruelty, but has denied further charges of the same offence. Hughes also denies child cruelty offences. The trial - held at Coventry Crown Court - continues.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON PoliceCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: family horrified giant house spider
story: Family horried by giant house spider so big it looks like rat with legsA dad said he was called by his teenage daughter who was having a shower at the time when the hairy eight-legged intruder made its appearance in their Coventry homeThe huge spider found in the Coventry home Image: Facebook Spotted Coventry CityByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  Oct | comments A family were horried after finding a giant house spider in their shower - which was so big some said it looked more like a rat with legs.A father said he was called by his teenage daughter who was having a shower at the time when the hairy eight-legged intruder made its appearance in their Coventry home.After safely capturing the creature, he placed it on a plate under a plastic bowl - before sharing images of the mini beast on Spotted Coventry City Facebook page.He wrote: Daughter was having a shower and this spider decided to share it with her. I assume itaposs a giant house spider , correct meIaposm wrong. Daughter is still recovering.Have you ever caught a bigger creepy-crawly in your home  Get in touch at webnews@mirrorThousands of Brits have been reporting an increased number of apossex-crazedapos spider sightings in their homes as we head into Autumn.Autumn marks the start of spider mating season and numerous arachnids invade our homes in search of a mate. They begin to show themselves when the first leaves fall - usually from the start of September to mid-October.The Mirror reported earlier this month that female spiders are known to stay in one place throughout their lives and establish themselves in our homes, but male of the species are always wandering.During mating season, they search for females, which are often found residing in our homes.  Ecologist Dr Chris Terrell-Nield of Nottingham Trent University says house spiders can be up to cm long and can be as big as a hand. They descend from species that come from the Mediterranean or North Africa, which is why they invade our warm homes.Chris told the Mirror: They have biting fangs. These things have been breeding and started their le span in the spring.He added: This time of the year, August and September, the male spiders have the urge to mate and start wandering and looking for females. When they find them they mate and she lays eggs and the male usually dies. title: first ever black mr miss
story: Exclusive: First ever black Mr and Miss England survived abuse and racism to change perceptionsThe first black Mr and Miss England winners Liam Ulla and Rehema Muthamia want to spur future generations - here they tell of the adversity they have overcome to inspire othersLiam Ulla and Rehema Muthamia triumph Image: HandoutByNaimah Archibald-Powell:,  Oct | commentsForget the idea of parading around in a swimsuit in front of a desk full of judges, when it comes to being Miss – and Mr – England these days, it takes much more than a pretty face. Contestants have to show public speaking skills, talents, sportsmanship and intelligence. But for Liam Ulla and Rehema Muthamia, who were crowned Mr and Miss England this summer, there was an extra achievement on top of the tiara – they became the first winners of the competition who were both of black heritage. Rehema, , said: “To have myself and Liam as the faces of that will change perceptions hopefully and influence the younger generations.”Join the discussion in the comment section  Born in North West London, Rehema comes from a traditional Kenyan family. Having spent time in both countries, Rehema embraces both cultures. She is also a linguist – speaking four languages. Liam, , of Sandbanks, Dorset, is of mixed race heritage with a white mother and black Jamaican father. He said: “It’s nice to see that we’re starting to get the recognition we should be getting already. “Becoming a mixed race Mr England is nice. I feel proud.” Get the latest news direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newslettersRehema came out on top of  women competing for the Miss England crown. She said surviving an abusive relationship motivated her to enter in order to raise awareness about domestic abuse. “I’m mostly working on my charity work with One Woman at a Time, Elle for Elle, Women’s Aid and teaching young girls and boys about healthy relationships and signs to look for in terms of domestic abuse. “I am a black woman with a genetics master’s degree and there aren’t very many of us. That I was able to achieve that has to be the proudest thing I’ve ever done.” Through his not-for-profit organisation Coacoara, keen kite surfer Liam, who cites his mother Sharon Green as his biggest inspiration, sells eco-friendly products and has organised beach and river clean-ups. Unfortunately Rehema’s win led to horric abuse on social media. “There was definitely some racism that I faced,” she said. “There are people in this country that aren’t happy that I’m a black woman representing England and it’s unfortunate that that’s the case.The UK began celebrating Black History Month, an idea first spawned in the United States and then also adopted by European countries including Ireland and the Netherlands, in October . Black History Month helps give context to modern le and the countryaposs history, while championing the experiences and celebrating the contributions of Black Britons here in the UK. The observation was first organised through the leadership of Ghanaian-born analyst Akyaaba Addai-Sebo. He served as a coordinator of special projects for the Greater London Council. Consequently, Akyaaba created a plan aiming to recognise the contributions of African, Asian and Caribbean people to the economic, cultural and political le in the UK. “Hopefully by me being here, I can change some viewpoints of those that don’t maybe understand or are ignorant towards it.” Speaking about racism in society, Liam says: “It’s crazy, with the [Euros] football, all the way up to the finals, everyone’s so supportive, they love the [England] players but as soon as they lose, the amount of racism is disgusting.” Comment MORE ON Black CommunitiesMiss EnglandRacism" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news greta-thunberg-holds-defund-climate-"Greta Thunberg joins climate change protesters in LondonByClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsGreta Thunberg has descended on the streets of central London on Friday to join thousands in protesting against carbon emissions. The Swedish teenage climate star joined protesters calling on big banks to stop funding fossil fuels.Greta,  and who is renown for holding world leaders to account over their failure to do more to tackle the climate crisis, joined the rally outside Standard Chartered. She appeared with a face mask as she stood side by side with other climate activists holding a banner saying aposDefund Climate Chaosapos.The demonstration, which is taking place in the City of London, is one of many being held across  dferent countries ahead of Cop on Sunday. What do you think of this  Let us know in the comments belowThe Day of Action has been tipped to be the largest climate finance protests in history with demonstrations happening in financial hubs across major cities, including New York, San Francisco and Nairobi.The Lloyds of London branch in Bank was the first location targeted by protesters on Friday morning as they where called on the global financial system to stop putting money into the use of fossil fuels. Campaigners also want the banks to cut their support for the building and maintenance of the Silvertown Tunnel under the Thames in east London. Activists chanted Ensure our future, not pollution as they made their way from Lloydaposs of London to Macquarie Capital.  The specic targeting of banks comes after campaigners revealed how they have reportedly paid £. trillion into fossil fuel extraction since the  Paris agreement. The UNaposs th annual conference on climate change will see leaders from all over the world come together to discuss solutions to the climate crisis. The main aim will be to find ways of ensuring temperatures donapost rise beyond the .C limit that countries signed up to at the Paris summit in . World leaders will also discuss strategies to cut carbon emissions to net zero by .  Protesters in central London on Friday morning included Greenwich teacher Kevin Wright, who spoke about the Silvertown Tunnel, saying: We cannot afford it environmentally or financially. There are no grounds that makes it good. It will draw large traffic into the most densely populated parts of the UK. All I see I self-interest in this tunnel, all I see is harm, but to some itaposs big money and toKhan it probably is his pension. A vigil is also set to take place at .pm at the Bank of England. Similar demonstrations against climate change are expected to happen in  cities, including Glasgow, Berlin, Brussels and Paris. Joseph Sikulu, from Pacic Climate Warriors, said: “Financial institutions that continue to invest in dirty fossil fuel projects are also investing in the destruction of our islands and our homes. “It’s time for the corporations who have caused this crisis to be held accountable. “The science is clear. We need to do everything we can to limit global warming to .C, the survival of our islands depends on that. To get there we need to defund the climate chaos.” The International Energy Agency says there can be no further exploration of oil and gas after this year.
