title: how can you e cigarette
story: How can you get an e-cigarette prescription through the NHS  Everything we know so farFollowing a change in advice from an NHS regulator, you could be able to get an e-cigarette prescription to help you quit smoking, but it wont be this week – heres everything you need to knowE-cigarettes could be brought as a prescription to help people quite smoking Image: Getty ImagesByHarry Thompson:,  Oct | comments In a major update in the battle against smoking related diseases, an NHS regulator has paved the way for the taxpayer-funded health service to begin prescribing e-cigarettes as a means to help people quit smoking.The move comes as part of the governmentaposs plan to make the UK smoke free by . It is thought , people die of smoking in England in , with it the largest cause of premature death in the country.The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Industry , is updating its guidance relating to medically licensed E-cigarettes as a tool for people who wish to stop smoking tobacco, paving the way to see them introduced as a legitimately licensed health-care solution.The update could make England the first country in the world to introduce a scheme that would see e-cigarettes used as a fully licensed method to help people quit smoking.  The government has claimed that in - up to % of people who attempted to quit smoking used e-cigarettes alongside Stop Smoking services.Health secretary Sajid Javid said: Opening the door to a licensed e-cigarette prescribed on the NHS has the potential to tackle the stark disparities in smoking rates across the country, helping people stop smoking wherever they live and whatever their background.How could you get an e-cigarette prescription  Getting your hands on an e-cigarette prescription will hinge on a few factors, and most of it wonapost depend on what you do yourself. As it stands, the biggest barrier is whether or not a manufacturer can convince the MHRA they can make a product safe and effective enough to be prescribed through the NHS. All medicines that the NHS uses go through the same regulator process and e-cigarettes are no dferent - what the change of guidance does is provide the opportunity for companies to work with them to produce a suitable product in the first place—before this wasnapost an option. If and when a product receives approval from the MHRA, it will then be down to doctors to decided on a case-by-case basis whether they believe that an e-cigarette is the most appropriate way to help the patient quit. Non-smokers are advised not to use start using e-cigarettes under the scheme people clinicians donapost regard as in need of quitting, i.e they donapost smoke, will not be able to get an e-cigarette through the NHS. Chief executive of the MHRA, Dr June Raine said: The updated guidance on licensing requirements we have published today is a strong first step towards availability of safe and effective licensed e-cigarette products.” A spokesperson for the NHS said: “The NHS will not be prescribing e-cigarettes unless Nice [the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence] recommends them for use.” E-cigarettes will not be prescribed by the NHS until Nice recommends them. news uk-news kate-middletons-jewellery-princess-diana-"Prince William and Kate discuss their engagement ringByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Oct | comments As a royal, the Duchess of Cambridge has access to a beautul and vast collection of jewellery.And when carrying out her duties, we often see Kate wearing gorgeous earrings, stunning necklaces and sometimes even sparkling tiaras.But not every time she steps out do we see her in brand new jewels - sometimes she wears pieces that used to belong to her late mother-in-law Princess Diana. After her untimely death in , it is believed her personal jewellery was ided up between her sons Prince William and Prince Harry.And this means Kate now has the ultimate privilege of wearing some of Dianaaposs dazzling pieces from time to time. Here we look at some of the amazing jewellery both women have worn... Diamond and South Sea Pearl Earrings  One of Dianaaposs favourite pieces of jewellery was said to be her stunning diamond and South Sea pearl earrings. She first wore them in  at a coronation banquet for Emperor Akihito of Japan and sported them many times after this.Then almost  years after their first appearance, Kate wore the earrings to the  Baftas in London alongside a beautul Alexander McQueen dress.Pearl bracelet Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Diana seemed to be a huge fan of pearls and in  acquired a stunning three-strand pearl and diamond bracelet designed by Nigel Milne. It was designed as part of a collection that was being sold to help support the charity Birthright, of which Diana was a patron. She famously wore the bracelet in Hong Kong in , teaming it with her famous Elvis dress designed by Catherine Walker. Kate was seen wearing the same bracelet during a tour of Germany in . Collingwood Pearl Earrings Before marrying Prince Charles in , Diana was gted an incredible pair of pearl earrings from jewellers Collingwood as a wedding present. And the earrings appear to have became firm favourites with her as she wore them many times, including on royal tours of Australia, Canada and Italy. Now it appears they have been passed on to Kate, who has worn them at least twice.The first time was at a Spanish state banquet in  and then weeks later at commemorations for the centenary of the Battle of Passchendaele during the First World War.Queen Mary Loveraposs Knot Tiara  Although strictly owned by the Queen and not Diana, the Queen Mary Loveraposs Knot tiara was a favourite of the late princess. She wore it several times to state occasions, the last time in , even though she reportedly said it gave her a headache wearing it.Fast-forward  years, Kate wore it for the first time in  at the annual diplomatic reception at Buckingham Palace. She also wore it to the same event the following three years and to a state banquet in  in honour of then US President Donald Trump.Sapphire Earrings  Dianaaposs sapphire earrings were among her favourites and were a wedding gt from Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia. She was spotted wearing them many times and they have deep blue sapphires surrounded by glistening diamonds. William is believed to have given the earrings to Kate after he proposed and theyaposve been given a slight tweak and are now a drop design. Kate first wore them in public in  on a visit to the VA Museum in Dundee. Engagement ring  Of course, the most famous piece of jewellery worn by both Diana and Kate is their engagement ring.After Charles proposed, he presented Diana with a selection of rings by Garrard of Mayfair, the Crown Jeweller at the time.After looking through the stunning collection, each suitable for the future Queen, she selected a white gold ring with  solitaire diamonds surrounding the famous sapphire. It is believed to have cost £, at the time - although its now said to be priceless.After her death, the ring is said to have been given to Prince Harry, while Dianaaposs gold Cartier watch went to William.In Amazon Prime show The Diana Story, the princessapos former butler Paul Burrell explained that shortly before William proposed to Kate in , Harry offered his brother the chance to give his bride-to-be their motheraposs ring. In the documentary, Paul says: Harry said to him [Wiliam]: aposWouldnapost it be fittingshe had mummy’s ring  Paul added of Harryaposs selfless act of kindness: Then one day that ring will be sat on the throne of England. Harry gave up his precious treasure. His one thing he kept from his mother, he gave to his brother. Thataposs selfless, kind and exactly who Diana was. Speaking in an interview on announcing their engagement, William revealed how special the ring was to him.He said: It is my motheraposs engagement ring. It is very special to me and Kate is very special to me now as well. It is only right the two are put together. It is my way of making sure my mother didnapost miss out on today. title: man who messaged woman saying
story: Man who messaged woman saying OK I raped you is cleared of all charges in courtBryan Sheridan, , went on trial charged with attacking the woman while she was asleep after a party before sending a WhatsApp message saying: "Ok, I raped you."Bryan Sheridan has walked free from court Image: Worcester News   SWNSByJack Evans:,  Oct A man accused of raping a drunk woman before sending her a WhatsApp message saying Ok, I raped you has walked free from court after being acquitted by a jury. Bryan Sheridan, , went on trial charged with attacking the woman while she was asleep after a party. A court heard Sheridan had talked to her about having a threesome with a friend before they went home together on Boxing Day . She claimed she was woken by Sheridan having sex with her but he maintained she was awake the whole time and the sex was consensual. Sheridan told the court he sent the message because it was what she wanted to hear after she threatened to go to the police. He denied two counts of rape, assault by penetration and attempting to assault by penetration and went on trial at Worcester Crown Court. Sheridan, of Evesham, Worcestershire, was unanimously cleared of all charges by a jury after just under three hours of deliberation yesterday.  Giving evidence, Sheridan said everything sexual that took place between him and the alleged victim that night had been consensual. He said the woman was drunk but was able to walk and communicate when they discussed having a threesome. When asked how he knew that the woman was consenting, he told the court: Because she pulled me on top of her. Michael Anning, defending, asked him: How did she seem  Sheridan replied: Perfectly happy. Mr Anning asked: Who initiated   Sheridan replied: She did. Mr Anning asked: Was she awake  Sheridan replied: Yes. He said later in conversations - on the phone, and in messages - the woman said she thought he had done something to her and raped her while she was asleep. She later sent Sheridan a WhatsApp message which said: Would you admit it is rape to me  I canapost feel anything, I just feel numb. Sheridan replied: Ok, I raped you. Mr Anning asked Sheridan why he sent the WhatsApp message admitting the rape. He replied: She basically saidI didnapost say it she was going to ring the police and Iaposd be arrested. This was what she wanted to hear. Under cross-examination, prosecutor Caroline Goodwin QC asked him: Why did you need to admit something you hadnapost done  Sheridan replied: She said she wanted me to say it so she could move on. The prosecutor also read out a message sent by the woman to Sheridan in which she wrote: Trust me Bryan I would ruin your le, like you did mine. She denied being in a sexual mood that night as she told the court she was raped but the jury of eight men and four women rejected her claims and found Sheridan not guilty.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON WhatsAppCourt caseCrown courtCrimeRape" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news meghan-markle-ides-opinion-after-"Meghan Markle reading The Bench is torture says hostByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsMeghan Markle has ided opinion by introducing herself with her royal title in a reading to children. The former actress appeared in a video to read aloud her kids book The Bench, filmed for Brightly Storytime.Meghan began by introducing herself by saying I am Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex. She then went on to read her popular story while showing viewers the illustrations. But the use of her title at the start has ided opinion.In the video, Meghan said: Hi and welcome to Brightly Storytime.I am Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, and today I am going to read you my book called The Bench.Get our daily newsletter for the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up  This is illustrated by Christian Robinson and I asked him to do something special for me and use watercolours, which isnapost the normal medium he works with but he did it to make this extra special. I hope you love the pictures as much as you love the words.I wrote this as a poem for my husband and our son, Archie and then turned it into a book so you can enjoy it too.One commenting on a tweet with a news piece about Meghanaposs reading of The Bench wrote: And of course she introduces herself as the duchess of sussex. She wonapost let the title go will she   Another said: Have either Catherine or Sophie ever done that  Like, Hey, I’m Catherine Sophie, The Duchess of Cambridge Countess of Wessex  And introduces herself as Meghan the Duchess of Sussex. Like kids have a clue who she is...Wow, one tweeted. But many fans thought it made sense for her to introduce herself with her title. One, defending Meghan, said: Not being working members doesn’t mean they aren’t royal.  They are still very much royals, Harry is still a prince by blood and Meghan a princess and duchess by marriage. Another made the point: It’s literally their name. Many also commended the reading itself: She did such a wonderful job with the reading. Relaxing tone and perfect pace and balance. title: meghan markle prince harry urge
story: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry urge G leaders to get Covid jabs to poorer countriesThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, joined with World Health Organization and Save the Children in an appeal to G leaders meeting this weekendPrince Harry and Meghan Markle have demanded that the hold pharmaceutical companies have over access to vaccines must be broken Image: GC ImagesByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Meghan Markle and Prince Harry have urged the worldaposs richest countries to send le-saving coronavirus vaccines to poorer nations. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have joined the World Health Organization and Save the Children in an appeal to G leaders meeting this weekend.Theyaposve urged them to honour promises to get Covid- vaccines to low-income countries where just % of people have had a jab.In a two-page letter, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Save the Children International CEO Inger Ashing and other leading voices in global health called for the world’s wealthiest countries to accelerate long-promised donations of vaccines.They coalition has demanded that the hold pharmaceutical companies have over access to vaccines must be broken.  “Among countries represented at the G, there are a handful with millions of surplus vaccines that are destined to be wasted once they expire,” the letter said. “Every discarded dose of a Covid- vaccine, when there are the mechanisms to donate them, should outrage us all. Each dose represents a real person—a mother, father, daughter, or son—who could have been protected.”  They pointed out that seven billon doses of Covid vaccines have been administered globally but Covax, the initiative designed to help fair achieve global access to vaccines, had only received .% of the promised . billion doses. Global targets have been set to vaccinate % of the population of every country by the end of  and % by the mid-. Decisions made at the G leaders’ summit in Rome this weekend could make or break those targets.  “By delivering already-pledged doses, helping countries manufacture their own vaccines, and prioritizing vaccines for nations in need, the G can help ensure the world delivers on these promises,” said the letter that was also signed by the Vaccine Alliance, UNAIDS, Clinton Foundation, Global Citizen and the Rockefeller Foundation. “We can’t simply hope for the pandemic to end on its own. As the virus progresses through unvaccinated populations, we risk new and more deadly strains sweeping the planet.”In the Spring Prince Harry urged people to “look beyond ourselves with empathy and compassion” during a speech at Vax Live.Harry, appearing without the Duchess of Sussex who was then expecting their second child, praised the world’s frontline medical workers at the concert. “Tonight is a celebration of each of you here, the vaccinated frontline workers in the audience and the millions of frontline heroes around the world,” he said. “You spent the last year battling courageously and selflessly to protect us all. You served and sacriced, put yourselves in harm’s way, and acted with bravery, knowing the costs. We owe you an incredible debt of gratitude. Thank you.” Comment MORE ON World Health OrganizationSave the ChildrenMeghan MarklePrince HarryRoyal FamilyCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum 5 waiting 7 years
story: Mum-of- waiting  years for council to clear mould and repair broken furnitureMum-of-five Leona Christie, from Sheffield, South Yorkshire, claims she and her family have had to live with mould and broken furniture since  and that every room needs work doneMum-of-five Leona Christie, from Sheffield, claims to have been waiting five years for her local council to fix repairs in her home Image: Sheffield Star   SWNSByAshley PembertonRyan FaheyReporter:,  Oct | commentsA mum-of-five claims sheaposs been waiting seven years for her local council to clear her home of mould and repair broken furniture. Leona Christie claims her home in Sheffield, South Yorkshire, is infested with mould and needs work done in every room. She has accused the council of failing to keep their promises, which were made by the large number of inspectors who have attended in recent years. Workmen did turn up at one point in August , but she turned them away fearing Covid could be spread among her family members. Leona and her partner moved in to the flat in , and claim to have been chasing the council ever since. Issues include a hole in the wall of one daughteraposs bedroom and mould in her other girls’ room.  The house also has cracked bathroom tiles and a draft coming from under the bathtub. She also claims the front door poses a fire hazard because it has slumped in its frame, and her kitchen appliances are being held up by bricks. Leona said: It’s just rubbish. I look around every single day and think about the safety of my kids.  Moving into this flat was the worst decision of my le. It feels like nothing will ever be done. Part of me just wants to blow it up and start again.” She claims she has had to deal with sewage coming up through her bathtub, mould and a hole in the wall in her childrenaposs bedroom, and rotten cladding outside the windows. Leona claims  inspectors have carried out assessments, but the council has not attended her Fox Hill flat to help resolve the issues in almost eight years.  Workmen did turn up in August  - but the mother did not feel it was safe to let them in due to the pandemic. She added: I’ve had about  inspectors come in the past two years. “They come, look around, say they will be in touch and nothing happens. The last was about a month ago. It’s just been hard for me. I’m so tired of it. I’m shipping my kids off to my dad’s this weekend so I can empty the rooms and take pictures to show how bad it is.  It’s just not a place to raise someone.” Councillor Paul Wood, executive member for housing at Sheffield City Council, said: “The Covid pandemic has caused a repairs backlog and we’re working through it as quickly as we can. We carry out , repairs and respond to  emergency repairs in our council homes every week. We have , outstanding repairs and  officers to carry out these repairs. Urgent and emergency work remains our priority and we are working within time limits for these call-outs. Our operations manager is contacting the tenant today to discuss the outstanding work.” Comment MORE ON " data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum gets touching tattoo remember
story: Mum gets touching tattoo to remember exact spot where her boyfriend proposedCharlene Machin, , was gobsmacked when partner Graham Marchant, , got down on one knee at their favourite beauty spot. To mark the occasion, Charlene got the coordinates tattooedCharlene had the numbers inked to her forearm earlier this month, to commemorate her engagement Image: Charlene Machin   SWNSByLeigh Mcmanus:,  Oct | commentsA mum was so stunned when her boyfriend proposed while they were hiking she got the geographic coordinates of the exact spot tattooed on her arm.Charlene Machin, , was gobsmacked last July when her partner Graham Marchant, , got down on one knee at their favourite beauty spot, Dovedale mountain, in Derbyshire.Her tattoo shows an outline of the landmark together with the coordinates .N, .W. The couple, who live in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, have five children between them and plan to marry in . Charlene, a special educational needs teacher, said: We were walking the path at Dovedale and looking for a place for lunch.  We did find somewhere but I thought it was too busy and said Iaposd prefer somewhere quieter. It was on the edge of the mountain and we sat down on a white plinth. I remember taking my phone out to take a video of the view, there was a  degree view from the top. Then when I turned around Graham was down on one knee. I was gobsmacked and obviously I said yes. Charlene decided to get the tattoo because they remind her of meaningful things.  She said: I thought it was a little bit dferent. Itaposs a bit of talking point, isnapost it  The coordinates make me giggle because when Graham and I go hiking we very rarely stick to the path. We like to see what others havenapost by going off track and itaposs always like aposwhere will we end up apos and we look up the coordinates afterwards. Quite a few people have said itaposs a lovely original idea and friends have said they absolutely love it. Some people have messaged asking aposwhat does that actually mean apos and Iaposve had to explain it. Charlene had the numbers inked to her forearm earlier this month. news uk-news pride-britain-brave-officers-ran-"British Transport Police release bodycam footage of Mahdi Mohamud arrestByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Oct | comments Four fearless British Transport Police officers who took down a kne-wielding terrorist have been nominated for a Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Award. The story of the courageous group, who mayor Andy Burnham said the city of Manchester was “indebted” to, is more than worthy of inclusion on the shortlist of four for the awardsapos Emergency Services honour.The show, in partnership with TSB, will be broadcast on ITV on November  at pm. Ahead of the big day, Matt Roper hears how the officers bravely ran towards the danger as panic-stricken crowds fled. Four British Transport Police officers were patrolling Manchester’s Victoria railway station on a busy New Year’s Eve when they heard terrying screams from a nearby tram . Have your say on this story in the comment section  Mahdi Mohamud, , had launched a frenzied attack on commuters, shouting ‘Allahu Akbar’ as he attacked one couple from behind, stabbing the man repeatedly in the back, shoulders and head and slashing the woman across her face. As panic-stricken crowds fled, the officers bravely ran towards the danger, putting their lives on the line as they formed a barrier between him and members of the public.  Sgt Lee Valentine, , remembers: “It was a scream I’d never really heard before. Seeing what had happened, and seeing a bloke there brandishing a kne, dancing round, lunging towards people instinct took over.” PC Ashleigh Williams recalls: “When I saw that kne I knew that we needed to get the couple away from that male. Me and Marsha did that by creating almost a barrier between the two.”  Sgt Valentine was stabbed in the shoulder before the kneman was wrestled to the ground and arrested by himself, PC Williams, PC Marsha Selby and PC Tom Wright. Sgt Valentine says: “We all stood our ground he just charged towards me with the kne in his hand like a dagger. He jumped quite high in the air and landed on me with the kne.”  Mohamud later pleaded guilty to three counts of attempted murder and was sentenced to le and detailed at a secure mental hospital. Det Supt Will Chatteron, Head of Investigations for Counter Terrorism for the North West, said: “If the police officers hadn’t been able to respond so quickly then without doubt the injuries would have been a lot lot worse.”  And Manchester mayor Andy Burnham said the city was “indebted” to them: “On behalf of the people of Greater Manchester a huge thank you to those brave officers.The Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards, in partnership with TSB, will be shown on ITV on November , at pm.Comment MORE ON British Transport PolicePride of Britain AwardsTerrorismCrimeKne crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news pride-britain-le-saver-pc-"Carol Vorderman posts pictures from Pride of Britain photoshootByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Oct | commentsHero PC Andrew Dear has been nominated for a Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Award for an incredible act of selfless bravery. Described by Warwickshire Police and Crime Commissioner Philip Seccombe as the bravest of the brave, PC Dearaposs story is more than worthy of inclusion on the shortlist of four for the awardsapos Emergency Services honour. The show, in partnership with TSB, will be broadcast on ITV on November  at pm. Ahead of the big day, PC Dear tells Matt Roper of how, while he is very proud to be nominated for an award, he doesnapost see himself as brave or heroic. PC Dear was the first on the scene of a horric road crash in which a car had been ripped in half and the driver trapped underneath after being thrown through an open sun roof. Have your say on this story in the comment section  But despite fuel leaking from the wreckage which could have caught fire at any moment, the Warwickshire Police officer crawled underneath, then bore its weight on his back to enable the badly injured driver to breathe. He remembers: “We were met with a scene of devastation really, bits of car over both carriageways, an upturned car, the rear axle had been ripped from the car and traveled around  metres and demolished a garden wall. A high speed impact and probably somebody was seriously injured.”  PC Dear, , scrambled into a -inch gap under the roof of the flipped car to ensure an airway was maintained, while also taking some of the weight of the car on his back. And despite being in grave danger himself, he stayed talking to the driver, who was drting in and out of consciousness, refusing to leave the man until a paramedic arrived to stem the bleeding. The policeman said he was driven by “what his family would probably be thinking had he not made it, knowing somebody was there with him when he was injured, trapped – that means everything.”  His actions were even more remarkable given that he was himself suffering PTSD after being in a fatal car crash while off duty nine years earlier, and was seriously injured in another crash while working a sht in , suffering facial injuries and a broken leg. Philip Seccombe, Warwickshire Police and Crime Commissioner, described the policeman as “the bravest of the brave, stepping forward heroically to protect a member of the public without a second thought to his own safety.” Modest PC Dear says: “I’m very proud to be nominated for a Pride of Britain award, although I don’t consider myself brave or heroic. I did my duty. It’s a team effort.The Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards, in partnership with TSB, will be shown on ITV on November , at pm.Comment MORE ON Pride of Britain AwardsWarwickshire PoliceCar crashes" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: shocked woman discovers diamond almost
story: Shocked woman discovers diamond she almost threw in bin is worth £ millionThe pensioner in her s bought the diamond at a car boot sale and thought it was worthless until a neighbour convinced her to get it valued when she went to bin itA diamond bought by a woman in her s at a car boot sale is actually worth £ millionByTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsAn amazed pensioner has found that a piece of jewellery she was about to bin during a clearout is in fact a diamond worth £ million. The stone was bought at a car boot sale many years ago by the woman in her s who had dismissed it as being worthless. But she was convinced to get it valued by a neighbour where she was given the incredible news that the diamond was an “off the scale” in terms of its wealth.Mark Lane, of Featonby’s Auctioneers in North Shields, told the BBC that the woman came off the street into his shop saying “she just thought she would bring it in as she was passing”.He continued: It had been in a box along with her wedding band and a number of low-value costume jewellery items.  We saw quite a large stone, bigger than a pound coin, and I thought it was a CZ [cubic zirconia, a synthetic diamond lookalike]. It sat on my desk for two or three days until I used a diamond tester machine. We then sent it off to our partners in London before it was certied by experts in Antwerp, Belgium, who confirmed it is  carat. The diamond is larger than a £ coin and Mr Lane said it is the biggest that he has seen in five years running the business.  He said that the woman wanted to remain anonymous but she told him she enjoyed going to car boot sales and never for a minute thought it was a real diamond. He added: She told us sheaposd been having a clear out and that it nearly went in the bin before her neighbour suggested bringing her items to us to get valued. The colour, the clarity, the size... to find a -carat diamond is off the scale. The diamond is now being held at a secure location in Hatton Gardens, London, before it goes under auction on November . title: sir david amess dog wins
story: Sir David Amess dog wins Westminster Dog of the Year in moving tributeThe MP entered his French bulldog into the competition before he was tragically killed as he attended a constituency surgerySir David Amess French Bulldog, Vivienne is announced as the winner of the Westminster Dog of the Year competition Image: David Parry PA WireByCatherine Swan:,  Oct Sir David Amessapos dog has been crowned the Westminster Dog of the Year winner, in a touching tribute to the late MP who entered his pet into the competition before his death. Organisers of Westminster Dog of the Year, the Kennel Club and Dogs Trust, said that French bulldog Vivienne was a fitting winner of this yearaposs competition. In second place was Stanley, a Border Terrier owned by Eddisbury MP Edward Timpson, and Henry, a Labrador owned by North Devon MP Selaine Saxby, came in third. Sir David, the Conservative MP for Southend West, was stabbed to death on October  when meeting constituents at Belfairs Methodist Church in Leigh-on-Sea, in Essex.  Following Sir David’s death, fellow MPs called on the public to cast their votes for his dog to win the esteemed title. The campaign led to a “staggering number” of votes pouring in for Vivienne, according to the Kennel Club. Mark Beazley, chief executive at The Kennel Club, said: “Today we pay tribute to Sir David and all he has done for dog welfare, and hope to honour his legacy to protect and improve the lives of the nation’s pets, who make such a dference to so many.“Crowning Vivienne as Westminster Dog of the Year and the public’s winner is testament to Sir David’s commitment and his passionate campaigning for animals.” The three-year-old dog wore a neckerchief which read “City of Southend”, a nod to Sir David’s long-standing campaign to make Southend a city. She was accompanied at the competition by friends and colleagues of Sir David, MPs Mark Francois and Andrew Rosindell. Andrew Rosindell said: “No one loved animals like David, and no one loved their dog like David. I could not feel more sadness at the fact that it will be me chaperoning Vivienne, his dog, at the Dog of the Year, instead of him, but I also could not feel more pride to be able to pay tribute to him in this small way.” Sir David and his dogs were regulars at Westminster Dog of the Year, with the MP having entered with his pets more than a dozen times. TeamDogs is a community for dog lovers who want to get the most out of their relationship with their best pal. Make sharing the cutest photos of your dog your first job on the website and after youaposve done that, leave a tip to help fellow dog owners live their best lives as a proud pooch parent. Search through hundreds of recommended walks, treats, toys and places to stay when youaposre on an adventure together. From dog-friendly pubs to product reviews and the latest news, you can snf it all out at TeamDogs. The annual competition aims to raise awareness of what is being done to help canine welfare in Parliament. Renowned for the support he gave to animal welfare issues, in previous years Sir David had used Westminster Dog of the Year as a  to raise awareness about the impact of fireworks on pets, lobbying for a ban on electric shock collars, and pet theft. When entering Vivienne in the competition, Sir David talked about his love of Vivienne: “If I am feeling down, the dog lts my spirits as she is always pleased to see me and she makes me smile.” Sir David added: Every time I walk into the room Vivienne throws herself at me, lies on her back with her legs in the air to be tickled. But before that she always brings a toy so she is of a generous, giving nature.” Sir David Amess was stabbed to death at his constituency surgery in Belfairs Methodist Church in Leigh-on-Sea, Essex, on October . news uk-news stubborn-meghan-markle-soon-realise-"Meghan has disowned both sides of family says Thomas MarkleByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle have built an isolated world for themselves and are desperate to control the narrative, a royal author has claimed.The couple stepped down as senior royals last year and are now living in Calornia with their two children Archie and Lilibet.Harry is seemingly at odds with both his older brother Prince William and father Prince Charles, who he accused of cutting him off financially and said he stopped taking his calls.Meanwhile, Meghan has a rocky relationship with her father Thomas, who has never met his two grandchildren.The pair have not spoken for almost four years after it emerged he staged a photoshoot with paparazzi just before her wedding to Harry.In a recent interview on Good Morning Britain, Thomas branded her aposchildishapos and apossillyapos and said he would keep speaking to the media until he hears from her.And now biographer Tom Bower, who is currently researching and writing a book about Meghan claims they are alienating their families.He told Closer magazine : Harry and Meghan have totally isolated themselves. They seem to think they will be stronger by cutting people out, but they’re really just alienating their families. I think it’s very sad for them both and their children. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. “I believe Meghan is a very stubborn person, but I think eventually even she’ll realise that this isolated world she and Harry have built for themselves was a poisonous choice.They seem so desperate to control the narrative that they can’t risk anyone  influencing it – but this will simply cause more damage to them in the future, when their children grow up with no family around them.” It was announced earlier this year that Bower was writing a book about Meghan that he says will tell the truth. He is one of the countryaposs most well-known biographers, having released in-depth unauthorised le stories of famous figures like Richard Branson and Boris Johnson.Bower also isnapost a stranger to writing about royal figures as he released Rebel Prince: The Power, Passion and Defiance of Prince Charles in . A source previously told the Sun : This is the book Meghan will be dreading.Tom doesnapost pull his punches and is terryingly thorough in his research. No stone will be left unturned.The announcement of his book about Meghan came just shortly after Harry revealed he would be releasing a tell-all memoir about his le next year.The memoir is set to be the definitive account of the experiences, adventures, losses, and le lessons that have helped shape him, according to publisher Penguin Random House. title: teenager reduced tears job interview
story: Teenager reduced to tears in job interview after being told outfit was inappropriateDionne Kidd, , was being interviewed for a waitressing job at The Stockton Hotel in Hartburn on Tuesday when she says the landlady made comments about her dress, which the pub claims was inappropriately shortTeenager reduced to tears in job interview after being told outfit was inappropriate Image: UGCByJade McElweeRyan FaheyReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe furious mum of a teenage girl brought to tears during a job interview is disgusted at how her daughter was treated. Dionne Kidd, , had an interview for a bar role at The Stockton Hotel in Hartburn on Tuesday, which was cut short because of an alleged dress code violation. Dionneaposs mum Donna Williams, , has shared how the teen was left sobbing after the landlady made comments about her skirt. The comments - which Donna says were flagrantly inappropriate - came as the proprietor questioned the teen on her previous waitressing experience.But the Stockton hotel has hit back, claiming the teenaposs outfit was more suited to nightclubbing than waiting tables, Teeside Live reports.“It wasn’t appropriate for an interview - it was very, very short,” licensee Andrew Mark said. Although, he admitted: “Maybe we could have handled it a bit better.”  Mum Donna said the interviewers should have raised their issue earlier.If you didn’t like what she was wearing as you mentioned, as soon as she walked in, why not just end the interview there,” Donna, from Thorpe Thewles, said.Dionne found the job through employment site Indeed and received an interview confirmation at the hotel in Hartburn. Donna dropped her off at the pub, but not long after her daughter called her in tears. She continued sobbing throughout their car journey as she explained to her mum what had happened during the interview and the comments about her skirt. Dionne - who just came to the end of her art and fashion college course - wore a brown skirt with flowers on, black tights, Dr Martens boots, high neck black top with an oversized leather jacket.  But during the interview Dionne said she felt uncomfortable and wrapped her coat around her legs. When questioned about her previous experience, Dionne told licensee Jane Darby she had worked in a café. But when prompted for more information Donna said she was “panicking and forgot the name of the café”. “She was flustered and confused,” the mum said, as she explained the café was “portable”. However, after the interview concluded, Donna banged on the door and asked Jane what the problem was. The mum admits she lost her temper outside the pub while her daughter sobbed in the car. She added: “My daughteraposs confidence has been truly knocked. “If anything you could have advised her and helped hershe was not what you were looking for. “You shouldn’t be judged on what you’re wearing or how you look.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Interview tipsEmployment rights" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: two words passengers should never
story: Two words passengers should never tell flight attendants - even as a jokeWillis Orlando, senior product operation specialist at Scotts Cheap Flights, urged passengers not to tell airplane staff they are drunk as it could have serious consequencesAn expert shared two words passengers should avoid telling airplane staff Image: Getty Images CaiaimageByJames RodgerRegional Content EditorChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsAn expert has shared two words airline passengers should never tell flight attendants. Willis Orlando, senior product operation specialist at Scottaposs Cheap Flights, said passengers should never get to the stage where they are telling staff on their flight: Iaposm drunk.He said the two words should never be said evenintended as a joke due to safety issues on airplanes, Birmingham Live reports.He told Yahoo: Certainly a lot of us get very convivial with flight attendants and we want to pal around with them and make these kinds of jokes and we feel light-hearted - and maybe we make a joke about being intoxicated.  Mr Orlando said flight attendants have the right to kick passengers off a planethey are drunk. He explained: They have to make a decision whether youaposre safe to stay on board. There are also things that they can do to penalise you. They could put you on a list of problem passengers - and this could all be misunderstandingyou make a simple joke. The warning comes as international travel begins to resume, with more flights being operated by airlines across the entire globe. Whether it is done deliberately or not, being drunk on a plane is a criminal offence and is considered one of the main reasons for aircraft ersions. Acts of drunkenness on an aircraft face a maximum fine of £, and two years in prison.The prison sentence for endangering the safety of an aircraft is up to five years, according to the Civil Aviation Authority.Disruptive passengers may also be asked to reimburse the airline with the cost of the ersion, typically ranging from £, to £, depending on the size of the plane and where it erts to. title: uk covid cases 70 times
story: UK Covid cases  times higher than red list destination amid ban fearsCoronavirus infection data shows the UK has nearly  times more cases per million than Haiti, which will be on the red list until Monday morningWorrying figures show the UK has the th highest infection rate in the worldByDave BurkeSenior reporter:,  Oct | comments The UK is one of the worldaposs worst Covid hotspots, with an infection rate nearly  times higher than one of its aposred listapos countries.Latest figures reveal that the UKaposs Covid rate dwarfs its neighbours, while deaths are at least three times higher than in Italy, Spain, France, Germany and Ireland. It also has nearly  times the infection rate of Haiti, which until Monday will be on the travel red list.Last night the government announced that the seven countries that remain on the list - all of which have much lower coronavirus rates than the UK - will be removed after the weekend.It means double jabbed people arriving from Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Haiti, Panama, Peru and Venezuela will not have to quarantine in a hotel at a cost of more than £,. Last week Morocco banned Brits from travelling as a result of soaring coronavirus cases, sparking fears that other nations could follow suit.  It comes after the government announced it was removing the final seven countries from the travel red list from Monday - meaning vaccinated travellers will no longer need to quarantine. High case numbers last week prompted the Moroccan government to ban Brits from travelling there, sparking fears other countries could do the same. Latest data from the Johns Hopkins University shows the UK is registering , cases per million people, the th highest figure on the planet. Only the USA, which has a far higher population, is confirming more daily cases, while several Eastern European countries are now experiencing high infection numbers.  Infection rates in the countries which will be removed from the red list on Monday are:Colombia - , cases per million The Dominican Republic - ,. cases per million Ecuador - ,. cases per million Haiti - ,. cases per million Panama - ,. cases per million Peru - ,. cases per million Venezuela - ,. cases per millionOf all the countries that will be removed from the red list at am on Monday, Panama has the highest case rate. But it works out at  per cent of the UKaposs figure, while lowest-placed Haiti is recording just . per cent of the case rate. Travel industry insiders say conversations have taken place in some countries about banning Brits because of the high infection rate.Paul Charles, chief executive of travel consultants firm PC Agency, told the i: “I don’t think countries will follow Morocco immediately, especially as they want to protect their half-term tourism revenues.“But several are starting to ask for reassurances over UK Covid rates and the strategy to contain it. “As Morocco has shown, other countries can put in place their own restrictionsthey are worried about higher UK rates.”Eastern Europe has emerged as the world Covid epicentre, with six countries - Montenegro, Andorra, Georgia, the Czech Republic, Serbia and Slovenia - among the  coronavirus hotspots. The  countries with the highest infection rate in the world are:Montenegro - ,. cases per million Seychelles - ,. cases per million Andorra - ,. cases per million Georgia - ,. cases per million Czech Republic - ,. cases per million Serbia - ,. cases per million San Marino - ,. cases per million Males - ,. cases per million Bahrain - ,. cases per million Slovenia - ,. cases per million Israel - ,. cases per million Lithuania - ,. cases per million Estonia - ,. cases per million Cyprus - ,. cases per million United States - ,. cases per million United Kingdom - ,. cases per million Luxembourg - ,. cases per million Netherlands - ,. cases per million Belgium - ,. cases per million Argentina - ,. cases per millionIn the past seven days more , people in the UK have tested positive for Covid, although this does represent a week-on-week fall of . per cent. Today the Office for National Statisticssaid that around one in  people in England were estimated to have the virus in the week to October  - the highest rate since January. Latest Department of Health data shows , lives were lost to Covid in seven days across the UK. According to the Johns Hopkins University, the UK is recording . Covid deaths per million people each day - outstripping Germanyaposs rate of . and Franceaposs .. Just  countries have a higher Covid death rate, according to latest figures.  The  countries with the highest daily level of coronavirus fatalities are:Romania - . deaths per million people Bulgaria - . deaths per million people Latvia - . deaths per million people Armenia - . deaths per million people Barbados - . deaths per million people Ukraine - . deaths per million people Lithuania - . deaths per million people St Lucia - . deaths per million people St Vincent and the Grenadines - . deaths per million peopleGeorgia - . deaths per million peopleYesterday Transport Minister Grant Shapps announced that all remaining aposred listapos countries were being downgraded - but warned that countries could be addedthey are deemed a danger.Health Sajid Javid warned that quarantine rooms are being kept on standby in case they are needed.He said: I am glad we are able to reduce the travel list even further, giving a huge boost to businesses, families and friends wanting to travel. The red list and quarantine remain vital in protecting our borders - we are keeping a small number of quarantine rooms on standby and will not hesitate to take swt action by adding countries to the red listthe risk increases again. The Cabinet minister announced that the Latin American countries of Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Haiti, Panama, Peru and Venezuela will be taken off the list at am on November . This means arrivals will no longer need to spend  nights in a quarantine hotel at a cost of £,.Mr Shapps wrote on Twitter : We will keep the red list category in place as a precautionary measure to protect public health and are prepared to add countries and territories backneeded, as the UKaposs first line of defence.He added that from Monday, the Government will recognise coronavirus vaccines for arrivals from more than  new countries and territories including Peru and Uganda. The Welsh Government confirmed that it will adopt the same changes to the red list and vaccine recognition. No announcement has been made by the devolved administrations in Scotland or Northern Ireland, but in recent months they have mirrored Westminsteraposs changes to travel rules. The end of hotel quarantine would bring the UK into line with most of the rest of Europe. title: wetherspoons bans pub goers bringing
story: Wetherspoons bans pub goers from bringing own salt to dinner amid national shortagePunters up and down the country have noticed a lack of salt over the past couple of weeks - but a spokesperson has said customers cant take their ownWetherspoons has banned customers from bringing their own salt to pubs as the chain experiences shortages. Image: Getty ImagesByKate Buck:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWetherspoons has banned customers from bringing their own salt to pubs as the chain experiences shortages. Punters up and down the country have noticed a lack of salt over the past couple of weeks - but a spokesperson has said customers canapost bring their own to dinner.When askedpeople could bring some from home to the pub, a spokesperson told Cornwall Live : “There is a shortage in most pubs – not sure regarding Cornwall.“Wetherspoon is working with a supplier to resolve this. “No, people can’t bring their own into the pubs.” Diners have taken to social media this week complaining about the lack of sachets containing the popular condiment.The Tim Martin-founded chain reportedly blamed supplier disruption for the absent condiment, according to the Sun. One Twitter user ranted that no salt at a Spoons means the country has gone to the dogs and another bemoaned having to eat their fish and chips unseasoned.The punter, at a branch in Piccadilly, Manchester, added: I had to settle for vinegar instead. It just wasn’t the same — my chips were ruined. A third said after one customer became outraged at a pub in Rochester, Kent, they were told it hasnapost been on the lorry for two weeks. They then questioned: “No one could go to a local supermarket to fill up. Corporate firms huh ” A fourth person said their brother had spotted a sign outside his local Wetherspoons also informing people there was no salt.  It comes after firm chiefs said they were looking for new providers for certain food products in August.And last month ran out of certain types of beer - confirming a nationwide shortage due to a lack of delivery staff fuelled by Britainaposs withdrawal from the EU. The pub chain was forced to issue a public apology after admitting a number of its  outlets had run short of popular brands, including Carling, Coors and Heineken. The shortage was linked to both a , shortfall in lorry drivers triggered by Brexit and industrial action.Mirror has contacted Wetherspoons for further comment. news uk-news whatsapp-stop-working-thousands-phones-"Twitter reacts to Instagram, Facebook and WhatsApp outagesByKate Buck:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsApple and Android users with older models have just days until WhatsApp will prevent them from accessing messages, photos and videos. The messaging  is removing support for a number of old smartphone models, meaning that from November  many must do without the popular app which offers free picture sharing across the world. On Monday,  smartphone models - both on Android and iOS - will stop working. Users will lose the ability to send messages and snaps, or make video calls to family and friends, using the encrypted messaging service. Smartphone models with Android .. or earlier installed will become incompatible with WhatsApp, as well as iPhones with iOS  or earlier installed. Is your phone on the list iPhone iPhone SE iPhone S iPhone S Plus Samsung Samsung Galaxy Trend Lite Galaxy Trend II Galaxy SII Galaxy S mini Galaxy Xcover  Galaxy Core Galaxy Ace  LG Lucid  LG Optimus F LG Optimus F Optimus L II Dual Optimus F Optimus L Optimus L II Optimus L Dual Optimus L II Optimus L Optimus L II Dual Optimus L II Optimus F, Enact Optimus L II Dual Optimus F Optimus L II Optimus L II Optimus Nitro HD and X HD Optimus FQ Huawei Ascend G Ascend Mate Ascend D Quad XL Ascend D Quad XL Ascend P S Ascend DSonyXperia Miro Sony Xperia Neo L Xperia Arc S ZTE ZTE Grand S Flex ZTE V Grand X Quad V ZTE Grand Memo Others The Alcatel One Touch Evo  Archos  Platinum HTC Desire  Caterpillar Cat B Wiko Cink Five Wiko Darknight Lenovo A UMi X Faea F THL WWhat should you doyou have one of these phones Sadlyyou want to continue using WhatsApp, you may need to consider upgrading your phone. However,youaposre holding off buying a new phone and want to save your chat history there is a way of doing it.You can back up your message history to Google Drive or iCloud depending on which  you use .Alternatively, you can export your chat history as an email attachment. If you have a younger phone but are running it on outdated software, now is probably a good time to update your phone. To do so, you need to look in the general settings to download and install the upgrade. It is ideal to have WiFi enabled when doing so unless you are ok with using your phone data, butit is a large download then it could be costly.  If your phone is too old to update the software then you may want to think about upgrading to a newer model in order to continue to use the app. WhatsApp has lost a lot of users over the last year due to ongoing privacy concerns around its new terms of service. WhatsApp has traditionally marketed itself on offering secure, encrypted messaging, but announced wildly unpopular changes to the way it handles user data. These changes would have seen user data handed to private companies to aid in marketing. WhatsApp U-turned drastically on the plans following a major backlash which has seen competitors Telegram surpass one billion downloads. These changes would have seen user data handed to private companies to aid in marketing. WhatsApp U-turned drastically on the plans following a major backlash which has seen competitors Telegram surpass one billion downloads. It seems big tech companies are closing in on anyone who doesnapost want to buy the latest kit every year.  Google announced that it plans to completely end sign-in support for older Android devices this month. That means anyone with a device older than Android .. will no longer be able to access basic Google services that make their phones al.If you own one of the phones above, maybe itaposs time to get down the shops. title: woman who caught man taking
story: Woman who caught man taking naked photo of her says its unfair he only got cautionChloe James, from Fleet, was getting changed in a tanning salon cubicle when she saw a phone and a hand above her, taking a photoChloe James was getting changed in a tanning salon cubicle when she saw a phone and a hand above her Image: Mollie EmertonByEmma PengellyAlice Peacock:,  Oct A woman who had a man reach over a cubicle wall and take a photo of her when she was naked has spoken out about the lasting impact the incident has had on her. Chloe James, from Fleet, was getting changed in a tanning salon cubicle when she saw a phone and a hand above her. The perpetrator, a -year-old man from Aldershot, was arrested but later released with a conditional caution. Chloe said it feels unfair he can carry on with le as normal while she continues to feel the effects. Chloe has waived her right to anonymity, wanting to tell her story to raise awareness and change peopleaposs attitudes towards voyeurism. The -year-old said she sometimes has flashbacks of the incident, the memory of which “sends shudders” through her.“Itaposs not a nice feeling at all,” she toldSurrey Live.I thought I would get over it, but it happened in August. It still upsets me, itaposs an invasion of my privacy completely. Iaposm never going to get that back.A conviction of voyeurism, as defined underSection of the Sexual Offences Act , carries a maximum prison sentence of two years.It was August  when Chloe arrived at Tantastic in North Lane, Aldershot, for her appointment. She recalled: I walked in and the guy was talking to the owner. He kind of looked at me and we exchanged an aposare you alrightapos kind of look you do to someone you donapost know. He saw me walk into the cubicle, and then walked into the one next to me. I was just waiting for the bed to heat up, just standing there. Luckily, I just looked up and then I saw a phone. I just panicked. For him to get his phone over he would have had to have stood on a stool or sunbed or something. Theyaposre high walls. Chloe wasnapost wearing anything at the time and described her initial feeling of disbelief. I doubted myself, aposdid I just see that apos I went out and told the owner and had a complete panic attack and started crying, she said. She said the owner brought the man out and demanded to see his phone, but he refused.Chloe managed to get hold of his name and contacted him on Facebook. Over the app, in a message seen bySurreyLive,he then admitted wrongdoing.Chloe went to police the same day with this evidence. On October , the man was arrested and questioned, but the outcome was not what Chloe had hoped for. After admitting the offence to police, the man was given a conditional caution, ordered to pay £ in compensation to Chloe and attend a Victim Awareness Course by January , . Chloe tried to appeal the conditional caution decision on October , but police said it was not eligible for the Right to Review Scheme. A senior investigative officer did carry out a review, however, but they found the decision to be legal and proportionate, and the outcome was likely to be similar toit had been dealt with at court, a Hampshire Constabulary spokesperson said. Chloe said: Itaposs the first time he has done it, but I donapost think this is just a random thing you just do. Heaposs probably done it before. I went to police becauseit happened to me, this could be the start of something worse. Chloe added: Itaposs unfair I am still having to deal with it, and heaposs got away with it. Sexual assault [and other sexual offences] is happening so much more often, nothing is getting done. There needs to be a change. A Hampshire Constabulary spokesperson said: As a force, we take all allegations of sexual offences very seriously, and we have specialist officers who provide a compassionate and professional response to victims. Investigations into these offences are among the most complex that our officers carry out and cautioning offenders is just one example of formal action open to the police. When considering how best to deal with someone for any offence, we consider many factors including the circumstances of the case, the victimaposs welfare and whether they support a prosecution through the courts, whether there has been an admission of guilt, the offenderaposs situation, and the ages of those involved. Our officers are professional decision makers and on a daily basis make decisions about how to achieve the best outcome, when to give a community resolution, a conditional caution or pursue a charge with the Crown Prosecution Service . We do take the victimaposs wishes into account. Officers are making decisions about whether it is fair and proportionate to give someone a criminal record for their first offence, when theyaposve accepted responsibility, offered to remedy the crime, is considered unlikely to reoffend, and can be given a sanction that deters further offending. Cautions for the most serious offences are only used in exceptional circumstances and after advice is sought from the CPS. story: Woman sues her boyfriend for not proposing to her after eight years togetherGertrude Ngoma,  attempted to sue her partner Herbert Salaliki, , who she shares a child with, after he failed to pop the question eight years into their relationshipThe couple were together for eight years before the court case Image: Getty ImagesByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Oct | commentsIf youaposve ever sat around waiting patiently for your other half to finally get down on one knee and pop the question, only for it never to happen, then youaposll know how frustrating it can be. That being said, the logical thing to do is to sit down with your other half to making sure that you do both want the same things andso, coming to a compromise on when you will take your relationship to the next level. One woman, however, has seemingly thrown logic out the window, instead opting to take her signicant other to court, for not proposing to her after eight years of dating. Gertrude Ngoma,  and Herbert Salaliki, , were together for almost a decade, and even share a child together, but sadly, their relationship turned sour after Herbert failed to follow through on his promise to propose. Feeling tired and frustrated of her other halfaposs lack of official commitment, Gertrude decided to take her beau to court and sue him for wasting her time, after he failed to deliver on the happy ever after she was waiting for.News website Tuko reports that Gertrude felt as though the father of her child was not serious enough about their relationship, despite the fact he had paid the dowry payment to her family, as is the tradition in their native Zambia. He had, however, not yet purchased the engagement ring.He has never been serious. That is why I bought him to court because I deserve to know the way forward and our future, she told the publication. Defending himself in court, Herbert said the reason he had not yet proposed was because he did not have the financial security to pay for a wedding, and argued that Gertrude had not been a doting partner and had not given him enough attention. The judge told the couple that reconciliation would be the best outcome for the pair. title: fossils extinct bony fish lived
story: Fossils of extinct bony fish that lived  million years ago discovered in ChinaThe frozen remains of three well preserved Peltoperleidus specimens were found in soil in Luoping, eastern Yunnan this monthIt is the first record of this fish to be found outside of Europe Image: PeerJByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Oct | comments Researchers have discovered fossils of an extinct  million-year-old bony fish in China.The remains of three well preserved Peltoperleidus specimens were found in soil in Luoping, eastern Yunnan this month.They are the oldest fossils of the fish to be found and the first record of this fish to be tracked outside of Europe.The fish was only previously known to live in Southern Switzerland and Italy.They are characterised by their distinctive scales, blunt snout and tiny but sharp teeth, the Daily Mail reports. The fossil was found by a research team at the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Yu Min, a paleontologist with the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, told the Global Times : It is also a sign provided to us to further explore the paleogeographic allocation and distribution of the genus since we see it has been discovered in China when previously we only knew it existed in Europe.This report comes after the fossilised remains of two new species of dinosaur that may have once roamed the south coast  million years ago were unearthed by fossil hunters on the Isle of Wight in September. The two carnivorous reptiles nicknamed hell heron and a riverbank hunter are thought to have been nine metres long– about the sameas a Stegosaurus – with skulls like crocodiles. Scientists say they relate to two new species of spinosaurid, a group of predatory theropod dinosaurs closely related to the giant Spinosaurus, StaffordshireLive reports.The first specimen has been named Ceratosuchops inferodios , which translates as the “horned, crocodile-faced hell heron”.With a series of low horns and bumps on the brow region, its hunting stye has been likened by scientists to a fearsome version of the modern-day bird. title: grieving parents find bag underwear
story: Grieving parents find bag of underwear in baby daughters coffin instead of bodyA bag containing black trousers and underwear belonging to another deceased person were found in a coffin instead of their daughter Emanuelle Costa Rosa. The undertaker had mixed up the plastic bag with her bodyThe coffin where the body of the baby Emanuelle Costa Rosa should be, full with dirty laundry Image: CENByLeigh Mcmanus:,  Oct | comments A funeral home has been accused of gross incompetence after two grieving parents found a bag containing underwear in their infant daughteraposs coffin, instead of her body.Emanuelle Costa Rosa died after being born prematurely on the same morning of October . During her wake, a bag containing black trousers and underwear was found instead of her body in the town of Turvo, in the Brazilian state of Santa Catarina. The clothes reportedly belonged to another deceased person in the morgue. Due to the mix-up, the girlaposs burial had to be postponed by a day, and took place on Tuesday, October .  The Instituto Virmond - Hospital Santa Tereza, in the city of Guarapuava, has pointed the finger of blame at the funeral home, which was not named in reports. The COO of the hospital, Michel Cunha, said: The body was prepared and duly identied. The funeral home was meant to take it to the wake. But the undertaker, on entering the morgue, came across a transparent bag with black clothes and no identication. And out of pure distraction, he convinced himself it was the baby and took it to the town asit were the baby. Meanwhile, the child remained in the morgue, wrapped in raffia and duly identied with tags. The parents only became aware of the mix-up after they removed the lid of the coffin during the wake to show their other daughter her sister.  Inside, they found the see-through plastic bag containing black trousers and underwear. Cunha said: We only found out about the funeral homeaposs mistake through social media and the news. We did a quick analysis and followed all the hospital protocols, but the funeral home committed a human error. The baby weighed  grams , far from what a pair of trousers and underwear would weigh. The funeral home was expected to make a statement on the incident. It is not clearthey have yet done so. She said in a podcast previously that she and Alex had been trying to conceive before his death. They had considered IVF because they were struggling, she said on her podcast Darling, Shine.  Bittersweet like none other, Iaposve never been more certain or excited about anything in my entire le, she wrote after saying she never imagined sheaposd be tackling pregnancy on her own. title: see inside aberdeens under the hammer ahead of its opening next week
story: One of Aberdeen’s beloved pubs, which closed in March last year, will reopen under new ownership next week following an extensive refurbishment. Under the Hammer has been taken over by independent hospitality operators, The McGinty’s Group, and will open on Friday November  at pm. The popular basement bar located on North Silver Street, just off Golden Square, will reopen with a stylish new look with a new hand-crafted bar and modern interiors with a nod to the venue’s heritage throughout.

and .dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__flex.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__image-wrap@media only screen and .dct-cta--subscribe.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__flex.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__image-wrap.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__image-wrap+.dct-cta__content@supportsor .dct-cta__flex:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup__dialog.dct-cta--signup__dialog--js-active.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__flex.dct-cta__image-wrap.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__image-wrap,.dct-cta--subscribe .dct-cta__content@media only screen and .dct-cta--subscribe--contained .dct-cta__flex.dct-cta--subscribe--contained .dct-cta__image-wrap@media only screen and @supportsor .dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remA single mother has spoken out about the state of her Aberdeen council flat which is damp and covered in mould # leaving her seven-month-old with breathing problems.Jacqueline Robertson moved into the council flat on Kemp Street three months ago with her son William.The -year-old explained that she had lived there for a couple of weeks before noticing the problems.The mould started at the windows of the top floor flat but has now spread to the walls and furniture.Even their clothes and her son#s toys have been affected by the fungus.She is now fearful to take any more furniture to her home.Miss Robertson said: #I had this black unit and I put all my son’s toys on it for a display. I moved it two days ago and the whole back of it was absolutely covered in mould, all the toys on it were covered in mould.#I actually have all my clothes in a box because I’m scared to take more furniture for it to get ruined and to have to replace it when I don’t have a lot of money.#I’m on benefits and I only get £ a month, so the stuff I do have is getting ruined.#Despite contacting Aberdeen City Council when she first noticed the mould, Miss Robertson#s home has still been plagued by the issue.The council visited the property once to inspect the problems.She said: #The man told me to just wipe it and handed me a leaflet. He came back the next day and painted over it # then it came back worse.#Meanwhile, no one has visited the property to check the gutters which are causing water to enter the top-floor flat.Having spoken with her neighbours, Miss Robertson discovered they also have a mould problem, just not as bad as her home.#I think they knew the problem was there before they moved me into the house,# she said.#It’s really not good to stay in, especially not with a child so young because you want everything to stay so clean.#The ceiling in her son#s room has cracked under the weight of the damp. Meanwhile, the bathtub has been sealed to the wall by electrical tape and the shower curtain has fallen down.Miss Robertson found mould on her bed.#It#s bringing me down, and I know it#s not my fault but I am embarrassed by it.# She said.#My biggest worry is my health and my son’s health. I’ve had a really bad cough and been getting really out of breath since I moved in and I’m normally in really good health.#I’ve even had to take my son to the doctor because his breathing got quite bad.#The mum has kept in touch with the council and emails them every day to get their attention.She cleans and keeps her windows open for at least two hours every day. Miss Robertson has noticed her heating bill is expensive from trying to warm the flat up for her son.#This is my first home, which is what’s upset me as well. I thought everything was going so good for me then it all just came crashing down like that.#An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “Works have been arranged to check over the roof and gutters and subsequently carry out any repairs required as a matter of urgency.#We will also arrange to visit Miss Robertson todayto identy any works that may be required inside the property following the external repair.”

title: angus macneil i certainly would not bet on the scottish government managing to hold a referendum
story: Events in politics may now mean for certain that a referendum on Scottish independence is blocked and the only avenue to ask the population the question on independence is at an election, says SNP MP for the Western Isles, Angus MacNeil. This month’s Supreme Court decision on blocking Scottish Parliament bills was a seismic event which could affect the independence process for Scotland for years to come.

title: honours-even-fjordhus-reivers
story: THE Fjordhus Reivers Ladies s were back in action against Grange s on Saturday.Reivers started off well, creating many great opportunities in the st quarter, which resulted in an early goal from Jessica Main.In the nd quarter, Reivers again had opportunities, but intensity dropped and the ball lsquoping-pongedrsquo up and down the pitch allowing Grange to put pressure on the Fjordhus defence.There were short corners, in the nd quarter for both teams, Reivers with the first one, thanks to some great passing from Rhona Gowans in the back line, through to Molly Darling, in midfield line, who was there to receive the ball and carry into the D, with the ball hitting a Grange playerrsquos foot.Grange then had multiple short corner opportunities, just on the half time whistle. But thanks to more great defensive work by Reivers players, Reivers were still - ahead at half time.The rd quarter, saw Grange get back into the game, this determination resulting in a goal, seven minutes in.They also had two more, short corners in the quarter but these were once again well defended by Reivers players Chloe Richardson, Emily Newlands, and Emma Pate to ensure, Grange didnrsquot go ahead.In the th quarter, Reivers, came back onto the pitch looking eager to prove a point. They had some great opportunities, with the energy levels of the whole team increasing, resulting in a short corner for Reivers.After a few missed opportunities, Reivers capitalised on the opportunity and a quick pass from Emma Pate to Chloe Richardson, saw Chloe do what she does best and score a fabulous goal.With only five-minutes remaining, Grange got themselves an important short corner. With some great defensive work by Reivers again, Grange just managed to flick the ball over many Fjordhus Reivers sticks and score the final goal of the game.This meant the match ended -. Overall some great, quick and skilful hockey by the Reivers Ladies who now sit second in the League.

title: asda-staff-take-part-sponsored-charity-walk
story: A GROUP of staff from Asda in Galashiels have raised more than pound for the lsquoTickled Pinkrsquo campaign following a sponsored walk.The eight women, one man and a dog left the store at am last Wednesday and walked to the Ship Inn in Melrose where they were rewarded with a buffet courtesy of T--.After refuelling, the group ed to a herorsquos welcome from friends and colleagues at the supermarket ndash having completed around , steps and -miles each.Asda community colleague Nola Milne told the Border : ldquoAsda has been in partnership with Tickled Pink for  years and we have a big fundraising month at our Galashiels store raising funds for this very worthy cause. Most of us have been affected by breast cancer either directly or indirectly and we want to show our support through ious activities throughout the month.ldquoAlong with this walk, we are having events in store such as raffles and games. We definitely collected over pound in our bucket during the walk today and we are still getting in donations.ldquoWe would like to thank Frances from T-- in Gala for kindly donating some sandwiches, sausage rolls and tray bake which she delivered to the Ship for us.ldquoAlso, thank you to The Ship Inn for accommodating us for our pit stop and doing us some pizzas and more water to keep us going ndash all this and a very kind donation.ldquoWe would also like to give a heart-felt thank you to the community for all the support we received during our walk- all the waves and beeps from passers-by gave us a real boost.Those taking part in the walk were Nola Milne, Haydee Lofthouse, Nikki Carlin, Shell Smith, Michelle Amos, Mel Turnbull, Peter Purves, Leigh Millar, Sheila Smith and, of course, Sasha the dog.The lsquoTickled Pinkrsquo campaign involves working with partners, Breast Cancer Now and CoppaFeel!, to raise vital funds for world-class research, support for those affected by breast cancer and to educate colleagues, customers and suppliers to be breast aware.Anyone wishing to donate can do so on the Virgin money page at https:bit.ly mJKuc

title: budget-today-budget-summary-impacts-scotland
story: Rishi Sunak delivered his autumn budget today in Parliament, detailing how the government plan to spend money over the coming months.It marks the second budget of the year, with the first taking place just seven months ago in March.With devolution, only certain aspects of the budget announcement apply to people in Scotland.When announcements are England specic,Scotlands overall spending budget will increase thanks to something called the Barnett formula.For example, the UK have proposed to spend pound. billion on dealing with the NHS England backlog, so Scotland will get around .% of this figure because Scotlands population is roughly .% of Englands population.Heres a breakdown of how the budget will impact people in Scotland...Will Scotland see a hike in minimum and living wages Yes - minimum and living wages are not devolved so all changes made by the UK government apply to Scotland.It means that from April  ,those on national living wage in Scotland will be paid pound. hour.The national minimum wage will also see rises:--year-olds will see increases frompound. to pound.to -year-olds will see increases from pound. to pound.Under swill see increases from pound. to pound.Apprentice Rate will increase from pound. to pound.Will the taper rate reduction to Universal Credit apply to Scotland - and what is it The taper rateis amount your benefit payment reduces asyour income increases.Currently p is takenoff your benefit for every extra pound earned after tax, with the rate set at %.In todays announcement, the chancellor confirmed this taper ratewould be reduced to p, a cut of %.This will benefit low-income families where the adults are in work by increasing their overall income.However, it wont impact families who are out of work, who recently faced the pound cut to universal credit which came into force earlier this month.Since benefits are reserved the Westminster and not devolved to Scotland, this taper rate reduction will apply to people in Scotland.Will Scotland get money to improve transport English cities will see money invested to improve transport infrastructure.Transport is a devolved matter, however Scotland will get
