money through the Barnett formula, which is what the UK government uses when they spend more money in England to keep spending more fair.Although Scotland will get money because England are spending more on transport, the Scottish government can do what they please with this money and do not necessarily need to use it for transport.Will NHS Scotland get more money Health is completely devolved, so announcements regarding funding for the NHS refer to NHS England only.However, Scotland will once again get money through the Barnett system, which they could choose to spend on the NHS.For example, during yesterdays Covid update, Nicola Sturgeon confirmed the Scottish government would spend additional money on NHS Scotland.Will the freeze on fuel duty continue in Scotland Fuel duty is a tax included in the price ofpetrol, diesel and other fuels used in vehicles or for heating.It is reserved to Westminster, meaning the freeze to the price of fuel duty will apply to Scotland.Will the money to control UK borders impact Scotland Foreign affairs are not devolved, so the UK government is in charge of Great Britains border control.This means that thepoundm to protect UK borders, including poundm for a new fleet of patrol boats, will apply to Scotland.pound million of levelling up fund allocated to ScotlandAccording to the UK government, this fund aims to invest in infrastructures which will improve every day le for people across the UK.This pound million allocated to Scotland will back projects in places including Aberdeen and Lewis, Rishi Sunak said in todays announcement.How much will the Scottish Governments budget increase Through the Barnett formula, there will be an increase to Scottish Governmentfunding in each year by pound. billion, according to the chancellor.Higher taxes on stronger alcoholic drinks - will it apply to Scotland Yes, alcohol duty is reserved to Westminster, so the announcement that alcohol dutywill increase on stronger alcohols such as fortied wine and higher volume red wines will apply to Scotland.A new lower rate of alcohol duty on draught beers and cider will also apply to Scotland, as willthe cancellation of theplanned increase in duty on spirits like Scotch Whisky, wine, cider and beer - which will come into action from midnight tonight.

title: coronavirus-borders-recorded-50-cases-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are currently  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash nine more than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: peebles-destruction-communal-garden-very-disturbing
story: THE destruction of a recreational area in the Borders has been ldquoshocking and very disturbing for residents, says a Tweeddale councillor.But Heather Anderson, of the SNP, says that there was no illegality in the developer removing the communal garden in Peebles as he owns the land.The developer had wanted to build two houses on the ground, but Scottish Borders Council rejected the plans as it had been earmarked for a play recreational area.The landowner appealed to the Scottish Government, but by the time an official visited, residents of Ballantyne Place had added slabs, shrubs and trees to the space.However, a bulldozer was used to remove the communityrsquos additions earlier this month, leaving everything in ldquoa big pile.:Borderers urged by council to prepare for lsquoheavy and persistentrsquo rainfallldquoBecause the owner owns that site, there was no illegality in him displacing the landscaping, said Ms Anderson, who confirmed that she had approached council officers to see what action could be taken.ldquoI also got officers to check whether the site was safe for the public, and they assured me that it was safe, but it was still a slightly shocking event that was captured on camera.The Tweeddale West representative added: ldquoWhat we now have to try and do is ensure that the residents of Ballantyne Place and that owner hopefully navigate a mutually agreeable solution to how to use that piece of land.The space had been used as an area for households to come together to enjoy barbecues.One resident, who does not want to be named, told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoWe set about clearing it from all the rubble and weeds. A good amount of people in the street got together and helped out. We got slabs, sand, shrubs and trees, which were donated by a local gardener. We thought wersquod make it presentable and nice.:A great shame: Public toilets to close after Peebles residents failed townldquoWe knew about the planning application, but none of us thought houses should be built on it. The key thing is, this is the only bit that is left for a recreational area. Wersquove hosted ious things on this space, including the kids doing a magic show and raising money for charity.The homeowner said that residents in Ballantyne Place ldquohad a fear that their communal garden would be ldquodestroyed.ldquoTheyrsquove uprooted trees and dumped them, said the resident. ldquoEverything has just been left in a big pile. Everyone is just gutted and upset ndash we had big plans for the space. It really brought us together, and the sad thing now is, therersquos nothing there now.The original development was granted planning permission on the basis that a play recreation area should be installed.:Background reports ordered into Borders man who admitted three assault chargesHowever, when the land was sold to the current developer, he lodged an application to build two houses on the ground.That was subsequently rejected by the council.The developerrsquos appeal was thrown out by the Scottish Government reporter who said the requirement for a play area should be protected, and this piece of land is the only place it could be located.The Peeblesshire Newscontacted the developer but had not received a response at the time of going to press.

title: spanish-activists-joined-borderers-21-mile-trek-kelso
story: ENVIRONMENTALISTS who are walking from Portsmouth towards Glasgow for the COP conference stopped in the Borders at the weekend.And they were joined by local activists.The group of ten Spanish activists are taking part in the Marcha A Glasgow to highlight the issue of climate change.On Sundaythe group, joined by two Borderers, walked  miles from Wooler to Kelso.:Fourteen flood warnings issued across Borders with further rainfall expectedldquoIt was absolutely terric, said Kate Prasher, a member of Extinction Rebellion Scottish Borders, who joined the walkers for  of their -mile trek, along with Kath McDonald.Kate, , told the Border that although the Spanish group may not spend the full two weeks of COP in Glasgow, their goal has been to highlight the climate crisis.She said: ldquoThey have made links with people across the country, from Portsmouth to here.ldquoThere is now a string of connections between people of all backgrounds.ldquoThese people have left their lives in Spain behind and they are literally walking for the sake of the climate.ldquoTo be part of that is a privilege.:John Lamont MP hits back at sewage vote misinformationOn Monday the Spanish group set off from Eccles to Lauder.Over the course of their ,km journey, the group has updated their followers with a series of blog posts about each of their stops.While in Kelso the group shared: ldquoA long and eventful day today saw us leave Wooler and up the Cheviot hills between the gorse and bracken, hauling ourselves up and down and then up again until the murmurs of discontent subsided when we reached the peak of Yeavering Bell which is  metres above sea level.ldquoHere the wind was vicious and almost blew us off our feet but we were rewarded with a panoramic view stretching from the North Sea across Northumberland to the Scottish Borders.ldquoOnce off the hills we picked up the B road which was almost as quiet as the mountains but much more conducive to completing the dayrsquos -mile walk before dusk.ldquoThe long, straight, quiet county road seemed to go on forever as we walked west toward the falling sun, finally turning northward to be greeted by local activists and a photographer from the local paper who led us into the beautul old town of Kelso where we drank whisky and listened to a bagpiper in the town square before heading to the local Friends Meeting House for dinner and folk music from local musicians.ldquoAs ever the food and hospitality was absolutely top notch, wherever we go we are treated like royalty.:Destruction of communal garden in Borders very disturbing, says councillorMs Prasher will join other activists from across Scotland in Glasgow on the weekend of November - where she will take part in a march and will help to display the Stitches for Survival banner ndash which a number of Borders knitters, crocheters and stitchers contributed to ndash on Glasgow Green.To follow the rest of the Marcha A Glasgow grouprsquos journey, visit: marcha-a-glasgow.net en home

title: darcy-graham-set-20th-cap-bt-murrayfield-saturday
story: FORMER Hawick player Darcy Graham has been selected for Scotlandrsquos opening match of the  Autumn Nations Series against Tonga at BT Murrayfield on Saturday  October ndash kick-off :pm.This will be the Edinburgh flyer Grahamrsquos th international appearance having earned his first cap coming off the bench against Wales in Cardf for the Doddie Weir Cup in November .He starts at full-back and is joined in the back three by Glasgow duo Kyle Steyn, who will add to his single cap won against France in the last match at BT Murrayfield played in front of crowds in March , and Rufus McLean who will make his first Scotland start.Joining McLean on Scotland debut will be clubmate Sione Tuipulotu who lines up with fellow Glasgow Warrior Sam Johnson as the centre partnership.Co-Captain and Lions scrum-half Ali Price teams up with Edinburghrsquos Blair Kinghorn at fly-half to form a brand new half-back pairing.In the pack fellow British  Irish Lions Zander Fagerson starts at tighthead prop with Hamish Watson at openside flanker, as they feature for Scotland for the first time since the South Africa tour this summer.Edinburgh Rugbyrsquos Jamie Ritchie, also named as Co-Captain, packs down on the blindside of the scrum which is anchored by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo Matt Fagerson at number eight.Youth and experience combine in the second row which sees Rob Harley earn his rd cap for Scotland and joined by Edinburgh lock Jamie Hodgson, who will win his first cap.Up front George Turner starts at hooker with Fagerson and with a debutant on the loose-head side in Edinburgh Rugbyrsquos Pierre Schoeman.Edinburgh Rugby provide forward replacements on debut in the form of lock Marshall Sykes and back-row Luke Crosbie.Glasgow Warriors half-back partners Jamie Dobie and Ross Thompson are the uncapped backs.Former Scotland Captain Stuart McInally is available off the bench alongside Glasgow props Jamie Bhatti and Oli Kebble in the front row, with backrow forward Nick Haining of Edinburgh completing the matchday squad.Scotland Head Coach Gregor Townsend said: ldquoAs a playing and coaching group we are looking forward to ing to international rugby over the coming four weeks in the Autumn Nations Series.ldquoThis week has been our first opportunity since the Six Nations to come together as a team, and our goal is to become a better team over the next month. Saturday will also be a huge occasion for a number of players in our squad who have the honour of playing for their country for the first time.ldquoTonga will be very dangerous opponents for us, as they pose a ferocious physical challenge in attack and defence. They performed very well on their last visit to Scotland and Irsquom sure they will be highly motivated to take the game to us once again.

title: excellent-performances-gala-harriers-scone-palace
story: A NUMBER of runners from Gala Harriers took part in the Scottish National Cross-Country Relays at Scone Palace on Saturday.Kirsty Rankinegot off to a great start over the fast .k course to hand over to Erin Grayin th. Erin had an excellent run, pulling the girls back to th, leaving U Isla Paterson for the final leg. This brought the girls home in a very well-deserved th. In this event, Gala also fielded an incomplete team ndash with Kacie Brownand Poppy Lunngetting their first taste of national relays and running very well at this level of competition.Next up were the boys. A total of  teams toed the starting line and Archie Dalgliesh set off for the Us, fighting his way through the field and handing over to U Zico Field in th. Zico had a strong run and pulled back a few places to th, leaving Ewan Christie for what was possibly the Gala run of the day. He charged through the field and held on for a fantastic th overall  The second Gala team ndash consisting of Charlie Dalgliesh, Ross Christie and Cameron Rankine ndash also ran strongly and finished th overall.The Senior and Masters teams raced over a scenic km loop.Three teams featured for Gala in the omens race. The A team were given a great start by Sara Green with a strong opening leg of : minutes. Fantastic support was then provided by Lizzie Macleish , Lisa Dalglieshand Charlotte Hendryfor a th place finish overall.On paper the W team looked to be well-balanced with strong runners in all positions and so it proved. Gill Lunn , Pamela Baillieand Katy Bardencombined for th place overall ndash just over  seconds outside of the medal spots.The highlight of the day for the Gala team was a bronze-medal winning performance from the W team. Terric performances from Julie Johnstone , Lindsay Dunand Carole Fortuneproved good enough for rd place.The M team of Gary Trewartha , Brian Aitchison , Graeme Murdochand Wayne Mcintoshgave their all and left the course happy and with a bronze medal around their necks. However, subsequent revisions to the results relegated the team to th place in the M category.Darrell Hastie led the senior mens team out in typically fast fashion with a : minute leg. The baton was then passed to Fergus Johnston , Paul Hendersonand Iain Buckley , resulting in th place overall. club.The forever-young Bob Johnson completed the teams efforts running a solid solo leg in :.

title: peebles-man-lost-father-covid-formed-ppe-company
story: AN INTERNATIONAL company formed by a Peebles man in the wake of the pandemic to manufacture vital PPE has sponsored local National Hunt Jockey Ryan Mania.Cameron lsquoCammyrsquo Young felt the brunt of the global pandemic early on when he tragically lost his father to COVID-.Further impacting him, his mother was then hospitalised only one month later but has since made a full recovery.Having seen first-hand the overwhelming effects of this disease, Cameron decided to put together a plan to make a dference.In just a few months, it became apparent that the lack of PPE in Scotland and hospitals all over the world was becoming a signicant problem and he decided to step in and be a part of the solution.He founded Envelicus Ltd an international firm focused on the manufacturing of Nitrile and Latex gloves.Utilizing a factory-direct model, Envelicus has established capacity contracts and partnerships with some of the best factories in the world for global production and distribution.The Envelicus mission is ldquoPutting gloves on the hands of the people who need them.With strong ties to the region, Envelicus decided to sponsor Borders jockey Ryan Mania.The pair met during their time as common riding principles in  and have remained good friends.

title: colleges-get-work-key-climate-actions
story: Throughout history, signicant change has taken strong leadership. We will see somewhere in the region of  world leaders in Glasgow next month for the COP climate change conference, and that will occupy the front pages for its duration.However, itrsquos clear that the scale of action needed in the face of catastrophic climate change requires strong collective leadership at every level. Where better to begin than education to relay the message of how urgently our behaviours need to change.With that in mind, Scotlandrsquos colleges are providing leadership on a strong collective front. Not only do they need to be the messengers, but they also need to pay attention to the message, with shts in their own working models and practices.Many colleges in Scotland have been working on this steadily. Following the Paris agreement at COP in , colleges have been making good progress in reducing carbon emissions. In fact, since reporting began in  . The sector has achieved an overall % reduction in emissions. This is better progress than the whole of the public sector, which has reduced by % over the same period.Clearly % is impressive but there is work to be done towards achieving the Scottish Government reporting expectations, and the sectorrsquos own statement of commitment, to achieve Net Zero climate emissions by  or earlier.Bringing together the current thinking and setting out a joint agenda, College Development Networkrsquos Climate Emergency Expert Group hosted the inaugural College Climate Change Conference, earlier this month.Held online with representatives of the college expert group and partners, it gave a strategic overview of the climate change actions that the college sector should be engaged in.It follows the development of the Scottish Colleges Statement on the Climate Emergency, which lists  key actions that colleges have committed to delivering.ldquoThe college sectorrsquos role in this is going to be huge, says Jim Metcalfe, Chief Executive of College Development Network . ldquoWe have a role to make sure that our own institutions, campuses, and staff and student travel is Net Zero. We have a role to provide the skills to ensure the economy can reform itself to be Net Zero ndash how we teach and train and develop people. And we have a role in how to influence change in our communities ndash we are crucial anchor institutions across the country that can influence the way our regional economies can change for the better.Skills development is something that is absolutely crucial in the contribution of colleges. The vocational courses that many offer, those that have an impact on our everyday lives will clearly need to change in line with green technologies as well as manufacturing and building practices.ldquoTo achieve Net Zero wersquoll need new green jobs, which in turn means wersquoll need to ensure we have people with the right skills to take up those jobs, says Dr Mike Cantlay OBE, Chair of the Scottish Funding Council.Providing an idea of scale, at the conference he pointed out that one change, the sht to electric vehicles, will require , people to be trained or retrained to support the new technology.ldquoThat means we have huge reskilling and upskilling tasks ahead of us. Through initiatives such as the National Transition Training Fund, colleges are already providing great opportunities for reskilling and upskilling ndash and these examples demonstrate the responsive-ness and agility of the college sector. But our success will rely on our ability to inspire future learners to consider these new career options, and I commend the work of colleges in this crucial task.Its clear that colleges are playing a crucial part in our rapidly changing landscape and as Angela Cox, Principal and CEO of Borders College, explained at the conference, colleges, perhaps more than ever are acting as catalysts of change.Also a lead Principal on the Climate Emergency within the College Principals Group, Angela Cox details some of the changes happening at Borders College.ldquoAll students at Borders college will complete a carbon literacy module at the start of their programme but this is only a small part of their development, she explains. ldquoHowever, that needs to be brought to le in their subject learning. A small but good example is a project with Bordersrsquo hairdressing students looking at the choice of dye products ndash synthetic versus organic and what happens when the waste product including peroxide is rinsed and flows into the water system.Angela Cox points to projects that are initiated by students, and through creating employer partnerships are also powerful catalysts for change. An example is a former Borders College plumbing student who invented a device to stop water leaks immediately while the fault was found. His company Kibosh now operates globally.She says, ldquoWe are also sharing our carbon literacy module with our schools and housing associations and supporting the delivery through a train the trainer approach. Over time this means that students progressing to the college already have the basics and our projects become more innovative and collaborative through our community partnerships.Angela Cox adds, ldquoColleges are in a unique and privileged position to take a leading role in achieving Net Zero. We have the power to influence the behaviours and values of our students, staff and communities. I am proud that Borders College is seizing the opportunity to help secure a sustainable future for the Scottish Borders and beyond.College staff and students have spent a considerable amount of time creating this new culture for colleges, where the consideration of climate impact isnrsquot a tick box but goes to the heart of everything they do.In November  Dundee and Angus College was invited to take part in the pilot of the College Learning for Sustainability Champions course, run by EAUC and Learning for Sustainability Scotland.Christine Calder, Academic Development Lead at the College explained at the conference how important it was for Dundee and Angus to be involved.ldquoOne lecturer from each of our  curricular departments attended the course. This gave us a real opportunity to know who a friend of sustainability was in each department.  lecturers, working with an average of  students. Thatrsquos  people directly affected. Thenwe add in the conversations that have happened in those studentsrsquo homes and with friends or the conversations that the lecturers had within their departments let alone their friends and families as well as students in other classes. Thatrsquos the ripple effect.Dr Katie Paget, Science Lecturer and Learning and Teaching Skills Mentor at Dundee and Angus College was one of the lecturers who was part of the pilot for the science team. She says, ldquoIn many ways the pandemic has brought the themes within the UNrsquos Sustainable Development Goalsinto the limelight, and this gives us a powerful opportunity.ldquoThis academic year we have embedded the SDGs into our Lecturer Professionalism Pathway. Within the course lecturers can reflect on, and share ways that they can embed such themes within their teaching and have the opportunity to try out ideas in a supportive environment.ldquoOur hope is that by weaving these into our curriculum with new lecturers during their early career, linking SDGs in their classrooms can become a foundation within their teaching, and not an extra.Its clear that the sector has put time and effort into creating a climate change strategy with clear goals and is working with a greater shared purpose than ever before.ldquoThe sector is now focused on operationalising those actions and achieving against that statement of commitment, on campuses and in teaching across the country as a sector, adds Jim Metcalfe, Chief Executive of CDN. ldquoIrsquom hopeful and aspirational about this agenda. ____________________________________________________________________Roadmap outlines path towards Net Zero futureWORKING towards the same ends takes collective knowledge and purpose. To that end a Climate Action Roadmap for colleges has been developed by the Climate Commission for UK Higher and Further Education, to support colleges at all stages of their progress towards Net Zero.The roadmap was developed closely with college leaders, students, and partners to ensure that it was relevant to every college, no matter what stage it hasreached on its sustainability journey.Itrsquos a tool that can be a useful gap analysis, to show where you are doing well, but identy where improvements are required. The roadmap alsofactors in cost and time commitments for each action, which helps in that planning.It covers all areas of the college, so you look at distinct areas in detail, such as leadership and governance, teaching and learning, estates and partnerships, and engagement.The Climate Action Roadmap illustrates clearly what an emerging college could look like. It helps colleges to tailor actions to match strategy. This is seen as an opportunity, in advance of COP to show how Scottish colleges are leading the way on climate change.From the date that every college commits to the roadmap, it has a full year to develop targets and show how those will be implemented.Workshops to develop the roadmap were carried out in June, attended by staff, and partners of Scotlandrsquos colleges. Billy Currie, Head of Corporate Services at Dumfries  Galloway College attended those workshops and says he could identy benefits for reviewing climate change plans immediately.Some colleges across the sector havebeen working in this area this since . Billy believes that one of the roadmaprsquos great strengths is its flexibility, where it can strengthen and consolidate the work that has already been done.At the College Climate Change Conference he explained, ldquoAt Dumfries  Galloway we carried out something of a progress review. We have used the Colleges get to work on key climate actions roadmap to reflect on our previous climate change action plan, to see where we could identy successes.ldquoWe could identy elements such as using renewable technologies in new builds, looking at our electric fleet vehicles, and identying partners for our student transport. We also have an established waste network with zerowaste goals for going to landfill.Billy Currie adds that an area that they could strengthen was governance. ldquoWe had already taken steps at Dumfries  Galloway in terms of setting our targets and annual reporting, both to the board and the cross-college Climate Action Group.ldquoBy using the roadmap we were able to declare a climate emergency, signed by the Principal, the Board Chair, and the Studentsrsquo Association President. ldquoThe declaration document commits the college to taking continued action on climate change matters. ldquoClimate change is now embedded into our systems and infrastructure strategies. We also have key performance indicators measuring what wersquore doing year on year ndash these are monitored by the Board, senior leadership and the climate action group.Billy Currie adds that working on awareness among staff and students, particularly in subject areas, is crucial to achieving the sustainable development goals.ldquoClimate change action is embedded at Dumfries  Galloway College, and we now have a revised plan, which is more focused because of the roadmap. As well as identying the key areas where we need to make changes, we can look at not only the college itself but how we fit in to the wider plan, regionally and nationally.

title: eyemouth-man-involved-two-domestic-bust-ups-borders
story: A MAN involved in two domestic bust-ups within the space of a month has been ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Aleksandrs Kravcovs, , was abusive to the woman at a party in Eyemouth on Christmas Eve and then followed it up by assaulting her a month later.Describing the first incident Depute fiscal Alison Atkins said: "The accused attended at the locus with a number of people on the evening of Christmas Eve."People were consuming alcohol and in good spirits."However as the evening progressed the accused became aggressive and wanted to go home and take his young daughter with him.:lsquoMajor incidentrsquo stood down but number of roads still lsquoaffectedrsquo by flooding"A witness and his partner both said this was not a good idea due to his level of intoxication."This caused the accused to become even more aggressive and was shouting and swearing in an aggressive manner."He was prevented from entering the daughters bedroom and the police were contacted."In January the fish processing factory worker got involved in another argument with his partner which escalated and resulted in him slapping her face and seizing hold of her by her arms.Ms Atkins said: "She was knocked to the ground. An older child heard the disturbance and came to assist her mother."He was very distressed and emotional."The police were called and saw bruises on the complainers left arm and a blooded mouth.PHOTO GALLERY:Flooding in the Borders following amber rain warning"She was offered but declined any medical attention."Defence lawyer Colin Severin said his client had been in a relationship for  years and have five children together.He added Kravcovs had not come to the attention of the authorities since the second incident last January.Sherf Donald Corke admonished him on the Christmas Eve incident.But he said the second offence was more serious as it was an assault to injury.The sherf imposed a Community Pay Back Order involving  hours unpaid work to be carried out over  months as an alternative to custody.After taking into account the partners views, Sherf Corke said a non-harassment order was not required.

title: nicola-sturgeon-update-today-time-watch-live
story: Nicola Sturgeon will join Jason Leitch to hold a media briefing today ahead of COP as Covid cases in Scotland continue to rise.It comes just days after the First Ministers latest update to Scottish Parliament, where she expressed slight concern over the number of hospitalisations in Scotland.With COP due to begin on Sunday in Glasgow, there have been warnings that Scotland could see a sharp rise in cases following the climate conference.On Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said she could not rule out introducing further restrictions in the futurerequired to curb case rates.The First Minister and national clinical director will be joined byPolice Scotland Chief Constable Iain Livingstone to discuss COP, which will take place from October  - November .Heres everything you need to know about the briefing, including what time and how to watch live...What time is Nicola Sturgeon speaking today The First Minister will host a media briefing at pm today alongside Jason Leitch and Iain Livingstone from Police Scotland.It will take place fromAtlantic Quay in Glasgow, with journalists asking questions both in person and via Zoom.How can I watch Nicola Sturgeons update today The media briefing is expected to be streamed on the Scottish Governments social media s including Twitter and Facebook.It is also expected to be available to watch on the Scottish Government website.What did Nicola Sturgeon say on Tuesday During Tuesdays briefing, Nicola Sturgeon warned that Covid hospitalisations had seen a slight rise, with infection now more prevalent in the older population.This is depsite Covid rates in Scotland being lower than England, Wales and Northern Ireland, as confirmed by the first minister during her statement.She also confirmed that from Sunday, fully vaccinated people travelling to Scotland from abroad would only be required to provide a lateral flow test within -hours of arrival, instead of a PCR test.Lateral flow test are around pound- cheaper than PCR tests, and this guidance is inkeeping with the UK government guidelines on international travel.

title: mundell-back-duty-water-firms-reduce-river-sewage
story: PEEBLESSHIRErsquoS MP has said he will now back an amendment calling for a legal duty to be placed on water firms to reduce the amount of sewage that ends up in rivers.Last week David Mundell, who represents Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale for the Conservatives, voted with his party on an amendment of the Environment Bill which did not include a proposal from the House of Lords to put a duty on ldquosewerage undertakers to take all reasonable steps to ensure untreated sewage is not discharged from storm overflows into inland and coastal waters.However, the UK Government has now said it will write into law that firms will have to make a ldquoprogressive reduction to the amount of sewage discharged into UK rivers and waterways ndash something Mr Mundell says he will support.:lsquoHeavy and disruptiversquo rain could impact Peebles as fresh warning issuedldquoRather than by means of the Lordsrsquo amendment, the government is instead proposing to place a direct legal obligation on water companies to reduce the impact of sewage discharges, said Mr Mundell. ldquoThis obligation will put it into law that water companies make progressive reductions in the adverse impacts of discharges from storm overflows.ldquoWater companies will be obliged by law to show a reduction in sewage overspills over the next five years.Although the Scottish Government oversees environmental issues in Scotland, the River Tweed flows from the Borders into Northumberland.On Tuesdaythe House of Lords voted in favour of the amendment from the Duke of Wellington asking that a duty be put on ldquosewerage undertakers to take all reasonable steps to ensure untreated sewage is not discharged from storm overflows into inland and coastal waters.:Photo gallery: Flooding in the Borders following amber rain warningThe amendment requires water firms to ldquodemonstrate improvement in the performance of sewerage systems and ldquosecure progressive reductions in the harm caused by untreated sewage discharges into inland and coastal waters.The Lords vote passed with  peers voting lsquocontentrsquo and  lsquonot contentsrsquo.The dukersquos amendment will now be debated by parliament at a later date.Amendment  of the Environment Bill means that the government will have to make a plan for how to tackle discharge from storm overflows by September , .The proposal made by the House of Lords which was not included in the amendment of the Environment Bill voted on last week asked that a duty be placed on ldquosewerage undertakers to take all reasonable steps to ensure untreated sewage is not discharged from storm overflows.:Spanish activists joined by Borderers on -mile trek to KelsoStorm overflows are designed to protect buildings from flooding during heavy rainfall.According to Surfers Against Sewage, across the UK untreated sewage was discharged into waterways , times last year.Mr Mundell added: ldquoWe all want to see action taken to protect our coastlines, waterways and rivers, including here in the Tweed valley where such a vital contribution is made to the le of the community.ldquoPlacing new legal obligations on water companies to reduce any impacts from discharges from storm overflows is the way to do it, and that approach will have my support.

title: black-history-month-lecturer-discovers-link-borders
story: ITS not everyday you find yourself on holiday and discover your name on the gates of your destination.However, this was the reality for Dr Melrose Stewart MBE when she visited the Borders recently.A physiotherapist and lecturer, Dr Stewart has worked as one of the experts on the multi award-winning Channel  series ldquoOld Peoplesrsquo home for  Year Olds.A black woman who was born in Jamaica and then moved to the UK when she was -years-old, she made the stop at her namesake, Melrose, while on holiday here in Scotland."It was absolutely wonderful," said Dr Stewart, "I think Melrose just set the scene, we arrived and it was a glorious day."I didnt know what to expect."It was absolutely beautul and I didnt expect to see my name on the entry to the town."But as well as enjoying the sunshine and the sights the area has to offer, Melrose had another reason to visit the town bearing her name ndash its connections with her ancestry.Dr Stewart added: "Id spoken to Sir Geoff Palmer [OBE, chancellor at Heriot-Watt University and human rights activist] ndash who is doing a lot of work in Scotland around the slave trade and the history of Jamaica and its connections with the slave trade. Id spoken with him a few times and he said Melrose has connections in Jamaica and Scotland."I wasnt too aware that there was a Melrose in Jamaica, but he said Melrose in the Borders is a lovely place to visit."Although she knows of no direct connection to the town ndash "I think my mother told me it was my sister who chose the name, I dont know where she got it from," ndash Melroseand Jamaica have a shared history.The local National Trust of Scotland attraction, Harmony House, will be known to many in the region.The house was built in  by Robert Waugh.Melrose said visiting Harmony House was a "seminal moment" in her trip, not only because of the link between Waugh and her name, but also how he profited from her ancestors.In the s Waugh used the profits he brought back with him from Jamaica, where he owned lime and pimento plantations ndash named Melrose and Mount Nelson ndash and slaves, to build his home in the Borders and the nearby chain bridge.Waugh was also financially compensated when slavery was abolished."He had built this house out of profits made from my ancestors in Jamaica," said Dr Stewart.She added: "But all in all, in such a short period, the couple of hours we spent there [Melrose], there was just so much to capture about my history and for me it was well worth a visit."Dr Stewart explained that she has been able to look back on her history up to the late s."Its very dficult as a black person to begin to trace your ancestry because names changed, there was lots of cruelty and all the things going on in terms of how iniduals were treated."And this is the sort of history ndash which is painful for all of us from Jamaica because I really dont know where my journey started. It was probably the west coast of Africa. Im not sure who bought my ancestors, how they arrived ndash its just something I started touching the tip of the iceberg really."As October marks Black History Month in the UK, Dr Stewart hopes that by addressing the connections we all have to slavery and Britains colonising history, we can have more open and honest conversations about race.She said: "I think everyone needs to know their history ndash I wasnt taught it at school ndash I knew nothing about my name and its connections with Scotland when I was growing up as a child in England."I came here when I was  so all of my secondary schooling was done here and so all of the history I have learnt has been me finding out for myself."And obviously things have moved on a bit since then ndash not much."I dont think people really know how to manage it [discussions on slavery]."Because of the sensitivities, people probably think, I didnt do it, its the people that went before me that did that."We need to have those sorts of discussions because you might not be personally responsible, but it helps explain in depth why were in the position we are in now."The last  months during the coronavirus pandemic have been marked with a number of events where the topic of race has been very prevalent ndash namely the death of George Floyd in America in March , which sparked worldwide Black Lives Matter protests.In the UK this brought about conversations on how we view commemorative statues, plaques and other memorabilia to figures known to have profited from the slave trade.Some call for the figures to be removed from their literalpedestals.The statue of Edward Colston, a slave trader, was famously toppled and thrown into Bristol Harbour in June last year and a statue of Winston Churchill in London was also defaced last year.But others feel the statues could remainmore is done to make their connections to slavery clearer."We hope that by learning about the past we dont repeat these atrocities in the future," said Dr Stewart."We just want history to be told as it was.""We can make it [learning about the slave trade] really interesting for children in schools."There are lots of interesting ways in which the curriculum can be changed, and should be changed, the narrative made factual from dferent perspectives."Especially in places like Melrose where they probably can even connect with a school in Melrose in Jamaica."Making connections is something I would strongly encourage, for children to have the conversation so they can share stories."You can imagine how dferent the children in Melrose in Scotland are from the children in Melrose in Jamaica ndash yet theres this strong connection."

title: coronavirus-borders-recorded-40-new-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There remain  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: massive-game-vale-raydale-park
story: VALE OF Leithen face arguably their biggest game in years this Saturday when they take on fellow Lowland League strugglers Gretna at Raydale Park.The Dumfries and Galloway side, who replaced manager Rowan Alexander with Stephen Hatfield last month, are currently six points ahead of Vale.New Vale head coach Grant Sandison is looking forward to the challenge after witnessing signs of encouragement against Edinburgh University in his first game in charge.After a string of heavy defeats, the club, with four new faces in the starting line-up, limited the students to three goals.But the Innerleithen side created a number of chances of their own and were unlucky to go in at half-time one goal down.Sandison told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoI was happy with the first-half performance against Edinburgh University."We set up to be organised and to stop conceding goals and I think we limited them to one shot before they scored from a direct free kick just before half-time. We created two or three good chances but in the second half we conceded early from a mistake and then ran out of steam but overall I was happy with the performance.ldquoWe had four players making their debut, Andrew Mackay, Ben Viola and Lewis Grahame who all signed from Penicuik and Ben Brady, who had just been released by St Mirren played as a trialist.ldquoBenpicked up an injury the second-half and had to go off. Hersquos had issues with his ankle all season and went over on it. He didnrsquot train on Monday night, so wersquoll see how he is for Saturday.ldquoWe have another three players lined up that we like the look of but whether they will be signed and available for Saturday, I donrsquot know right now. Hopefully one or two may be able to play.ldquoSaturday will be a massive game for the club. The Edinburgh Uni and Gretna games probably came a bit too early for us."It would have been betterwersquod had three or four weeks with the players first, but it is what it is. I watched Gretnarsquos Scottish Cup game against Berwick Rangers and have received some reports on them but they have a new manager so their style of play may have changed.ldquoBut Irsquove been delighted with the response of the players so far. There has been a good reaction and there was a real enthusiasm in training. I am really looking forward to the game and it would be great to claw back some points to bring back up the road.

title: covid-nicola-sturgeon-say-cop26-update-today
story: Nicola Sturgeon was joined by Professor Jason Leitch andPolice Scotland Chief Constable Iain Livingstone to give an update ahead of COP.During Tuesdays Covid update to Parliament, the First Minister warned that Covid hospitalisations were rising, with more cases among the older population.Amid warnings that case numbers could surgefollowing the climate conference, which will see over tens of thousands of people flock to the city, today the First Minister outlined how the government aimed to protect both citizens and those visiting.Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged that the summit would bring a certain level of disruption, due to the extremely high profile nature of the event.Heres what we learned from the update today.... Avoid unnecessary trips during the first few days of COPpossibleThe First Minister encourgaged people to avoid travelling across Glasgow and the central belt where possible, particularly in the first few days of COP.She said that this did not only apply to road travel, but also by rail, following the news that ScotRail workers will no longer be striking during the conference.If travel is necessary, the government advise planning journeys carefully.. Certain dates expected to be particularly busyAccording to the First Minister, the first Sunday, Monday and Tuesday of COP will be particularly busy as world leaders come together.Next Friday and Saturday will see large scale protests across the city, with Saturdays event expected to see up to , people march from Kelvingrove Park to Glasgow Green.. Measures taken to try to reduce Covid transmissionScottish government doing everything they can to mitigate the spread of Covid, according to the First Minister.Explainging that she understood why people may be wary, Nicola Sturgeon said that the government was working with the UN to try and minimise a surge in Covid followingthe conference.. Disruptionexperienced "for a purpose"The First Minister acknowledged the disruption to the people of Glasgow, and thanked residents for their patience.She added that the disruption was "for a purpose" with COP focussed on minimising global warming and climate change in the future.. Clear message to those intent on actually disruption the conferencePolice chiefIain Livingstone acknoweldged that the UN was encourgaing people to make their voices heard during the conference, and endorsed this message.However, he addedthat swt action would be taken against those intent on actually disrupting the Covid conference.Police Scotland said that physical interference would be required where protesters were preventing the conference from going ahead.. Be even more careful during COPJason Leitch encouraged people to continue following the remaining Covidrules in Scotland, and urged people to be even more careful over the coming weeks.When asked how emergency services will cope with the added demand and the navigation of protests, Jason Leitch said there was a "many layered" approach.He added that Scotland was "ready" and the health service was "prepared" for COP.. Nicola Sturgeon to co-host event with Boris JohnsonThe First Minister confirmed she would co-host an event on Tuesday afternoon with UK prime minister Boris Johnson.She also added that while the Scottish government and British government had some big dferences, they would work hard to come to the best outcome for the world over the coming days.

title: queen-advised-rest-next-two-weeks
story: The Queen has been advised by her doctors to rest for the next two weeks and only undertake ldquodesk-based duties, Buckingham Palace has announced.The development comes after the Queen underwent tests in hospital last week and cancelled a two-day trip to Northern Ireland.But the head of state has the ldquofirm intention of leading the nation in honouring the countryrsquos war dead on Remembrance Sunday on November .In a statement, Buckingham Palace said: ldquoFollowing on from their recent advice that the Queen should rest for a few days, Her Majestyrsquos doctors have advised that she should continue to rest for at least the next two weeks.ldquoThe doctors have advised that Her Majesty can continue to undertake light, desk-based duties during this time, including some virtual audiences, but not to undertake any official visits.ldquoHer Majesty regrets that this means she will be unable to attend the Festival of Remembrance on Saturday, November .ldquoHowever, it remains The Queenrsquos firm intention to be present for the National Service of Remembrance on Remembrance Sunday, on November .vw, px"The Queen appeared cheerful during a virtual presentation ceremony on Thursday. Buckingham PalaceThe -year-old monarch is said to be in good spirits, and during Friday afternoon recorded her Cop speech for the UN climate change conference which opens on Monday in Glasgow.Earlier this week, the head of state announced she would not be attending the evening reception for world leaders on the global eventrsquos opening day, and instead recorded the video message which will be played to delegates.There will be concern for the Queen given her advanced years but medics see the period of rest as a sensible precaution.The Queen appeared cheerful and in good humour when she hosted a virtual presentation ceremony on Thursday, awarding the Queenrsquos Gold Medal for Poetry  to poet David Constantine.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen pictured with Bill Gates during her last in-person event before being advised to rest Speaking from Windsor Castle during a video call, she joked with the writer at Buckingham Palace, saying about his award ldquoDo you put it in a cupboard It was announced last Wednesday the Queen had ldquoreluctantly accepted medical advice to rest and cancelled her trip to Northern Ireland that was scheduled to begin that day.But it later emerged she had stayed overnight in hospital when the Sun newspaper reported the monarch had been admitted to King Edwards VIIrsquos Hospital in central London on Wednesday.Buckingham Palace confirmed the head of state had undergone ldquopreliminary investigations during her first overnight stay at a medical facility in eight years..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Queen advised to rest for the next two weeks

title: queens-health-years-advised-rest-two-weeks
story: The Queen is known for her strong constitution and no-fuss approach to her infrequent illnesses.Her doctors have recommended she continue to rest for the next two weeks following the -year-old monarchrsquos overnight stay at King Edward VIIrsquos Hospital earlier this month, which was her first in eight years.She was treated at the private clinic for a nasty bout of gastroenteritis in , when she also stayed for one night.The sovereign was recently seen using a walking stick at a Westminster Abbey service in early October, the first time she has done so at a major event.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen with her walking stick During the coronavirus pandemic, the Queen retreated to Windsor Castle for her safety, where she was joined by the Duke of Edinburgh in lockdown.The couple were vulnerable to Covid- because of their advanced age, but were protected by the so-called HMS Bubble, their reduced household of about  staff.On January  , the then -year-old Queen and the -year-old duke received their coronavirus vaccinations, with Buckingham Palace taking the rare step of confirming what would usually have been a private medical matter, as the national rollout of the injections gathered pace.Philip had heart surgery in March , but ed to Windsor where he died a few weeks later in his sleep at the age of .In January , the Queen missed her annual visit to the Sandringham Womenrsquos Institute due to a slight cold.The year she turned , the monarch called time on her overseas travels, leaving long-haul destinations to the younger members of her family, but she still maintains a busy diary of events.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen at the Trooping the Colour, celebrating her official nd birthday The monarch still rides her Fell ponies at Windsor, and drives, mainly around her private estates.The Queen missed the christening of her great-grandson Prince Louis in July  but not because of illness.It was mutually agreed in advance by the monarch and the Cambridges that the Queen would not attend the celebration, which fell at the beginning of a busy week of engagements including the centenary of the RAF and a visit by US President Donald Trump.In June that year, the Queen pulled out of a service at St Paulrsquos Cathedral because she was feeling ldquounder the weather.In May , the head of state had eye surgery to remove a cataract.She was treated as a day patient and did not cancel any engagements nor appearances, but was spotted wearing sunglasses.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen at a garden party at Buckingham Palace in London in May  In November , the Prince of Wales led the nation in honouring the countryrsquos war dead on Remembrance Sunday at the Cenotaph.It was the first time that the Queen, as head of state, had watched the ceremony from a nearby balcony, and was seen as a sign of the royal family in transition and an acknowledgement of her age.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh observe the annual Remembrance Sunday Service at the Cenotaph memorial from a balcony in Whitehall Just before Christmas , the Queen and Philip both fell ill with heavy colds, forcing them to delay their trip to Sandringham by a day.The Queen was not well enough to attend the Christmas Day service at St Mary Magdalene church and also missed theNew Yearrsquos Day one.She later described it as a ldquoparticularly grisly mixture of cold and flu.She turned  in  and, the same year, used the ltratherthan stairs to enter Parliament for the State Opening, avoiding the  steps of the royal staircase at the Sovereignrsquos Entrance.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh walk through to the Robing Room, after using a lt, rather than stairs, at the State Opening of Parliament Buckingham Palace said the ldquomodest adjustment to arrangements were madefor ldquothe Queenrsquos comfort.The decision was attributed to the Queen suffering from knee pain.In , the Prince of Wales stood in for the Queen for part of the Order of the Bath service to avoid her having to make an extra journey up and down some steep steps in full regalia.In November , the Duke of Cambridge stepped in to represent the Queen at an investitureceremony after she suffered some ldquomilddiscomfort with her ankle after abusy weekend of engagements including theservice of remembrance at the Cenotaph.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen at the Cenotaph in  Her first hospital stay in  years came in  when she was  after she suffered symptoms of gastroenteritis and missed an engagement in Swansea when she was due to present St Davidrsquos Day leeks to the rd Battalion The Royal Welsh.On March  , she was admitted to King Edward VIIrsquos Hospital to be assessed.A week of engagements, including a two-day trip to Rome, was cancelled.The Queen spent one night in hospital and left thanking staff and smiling before being driven to Buckingham Palace to rest.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen leaves King Edward VIIrsquos Hospital in London in  It was thought her public appearances were back on track until Buckingham Palace announced on the morning of the Commonwealth Day Observance service on March  that she regrettably could no longer attend ldquoas she continues to recover following her recent illness.It was the first Commonwealth Day Observance service she had missed in  years, the last occasion being when she had flu in .The Queen, who placed great importance to her role as Head of the Commonwealth, did however attend the Commonwealth Reception at Marlborough House on the evening of March  to sign the new Commonwealth Charter.Buckingham Palace insisted it was just the ldquotail end of the symptoms and that her condition had not worsened.But the next day she cancelled her engagements for the rest of the week, with her son, the Duke of York, saying later that it was sensible not to risk her coming out, but that she was not ill.Her illnesses have been few and far between over the years.She has suffered from back pain, and also had operations to remove torn cartilage from both knees.She caught measles when Prince Charles was two months old in  and had to be separated from her baby son.The first time the Queen was actually admitted to hospital was in July  when she had a wisdom tooth extracted at the King Edward VII Hospital in central London.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen wears her plaster cast arm in a sling while visiting Anguilla The Queenrsquos no-fuss approach to injury and illness was perfectly illustrated in .She broke her left wrist when her horse tripped during a ride on the Sandringham estate in Norfolk.The break was not diagnosed until almost  hours later when her arm was X-rayed and set in plaster at a hospital.It was the first time she had fallen in many years and the Queen had simply brushed herself down, remounted her horse and trotted on back to Sandringham..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Queen us health over the years as she is advised to rest for two weeks

title: iopc-launches-investigation-officer-accused-removing-head-covering
story: The police watchdog has launched an investigation after an officer was accused of forcibly removing the religious head covering of a Sikh man while he was in custody.The Independent Office for Police Conductannounced the probe after a complaint was made against West Midlands Police.The IOPC said the complaint claims officersrsquo actions towards the Sikh man were ldquoracially motivated.It follows an incident at Perry Barr custody suite, just outside of Birmingham city centre, on Monday afternoon.WMP response to social media posts regarding incident in Perry Barr custody suite pic zZOrAOhXkmdash West Midlands PoliceOctober , In a statement, West Midlands Police said a video compilation was published on social media which ldquoinfers that one of the stills included shows a man having his turban forcibly removed and stamped on while in custody.Both the force and the IOPC have said the footage is inaccurate.Expanding further, a statement from West Midlands Police said: ldquoThe author has used an image from where giving an entirely misleading version of the events. The CCTV featured in this video is not connected to this incident.ldquoWe can confirm that a man in custody was asked to remove his patka to be searched. It was removed by an officer in a private room to search for anything that could be harmful to the man or our custody officers. The head covering fell to the floor at one point, but was immediately retrieved and at no point was it stamped on.It added all CCTV footage of the officerrsquos interactions with the man is being examined further and that it understands the religious signicance of head coverings in the Sikh faith.IOPC regional director Derrick Campbell said: ldquoThis incident has caused understandable unrest within the local community and I want to reassure everyone that this will be thoroughly and independently investigated.ldquoWe are now in possession of all the CCTV footage from the custody suite, which I have viewed myself. Our investigation will look at the actions of police during the incident to determine the facts.ldquoWhat I can say with absolute certainty at this stage, in direct response to questions I have received from members of the local community, is that the head covering was not stamped on at any stage.ldquoA  video shared on social media has caused signicant concern for many and I am appealing for calm while this is investigated. Rest assured we will be working hard to ensure the facts of what happened are brought to light and this matter is dealt with appropriately..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: IOPC launches investigation after officer accused of removing head covering

title: clocks-go-back-weekend---time
story: Its that time of year again - the clocks will go back this weekend marking the officialend of British Summer Time .Between Saturday night and Sunday morning, we will gain an extra hour,meaning it will be lighter in the mornings but darker in the evenings.Clocks changes always take place on the weekend to try and limit disruption to everday le.Heres what you need to know about when the clocks will change, what time and why they go back...When do the clocks change this weekend The clocks will go back in the early hours ofSunday October .They go back on the same weekend every year, with the change always taking place on the last Sunday of October.: Does my iPhone automatically update the time What time will the clocks change this weekend The change to the clocks will comeinto effect around am on Sunday.It means we are reverting back to GMT, which stands for Greenwich Mean Time and is thestandard time against which time zones in other areas of theworldare measured.Meanwhile, BST stands for British Summer Time and is the time zone referenced when the clocks go forward in spring.The BSTis GMT+ hour.Why do the clocks change The principal reason we change the clocks is to get the most out of the daylight.The first clock change was introduced by the German government in  during the first worldwar as a means of saving energy - the longer the daylight hours lasted, the less electricity required.Do we get an extra hour of sleep Yes! The good newsabout the clocks going back is we get an extra hour inthe day - or an extra hour to sleep!When will the clocks go forward in  The clocks might only just be going back, but you may already be wondering when they will go forward again...We have a wee while to wait, with the next clock change scheduled for March , when they will go forwardin order to make the most of the long hours of daylight.Like in autumn, the change will take place on a Sunday to avoid too much disruption.Next years change will take place on Sunday March  , marking the start of BST.The clocks going forward means we lose an hour, however we gain this back every autumn when they go back again.

title: winter-solstice-shortest-day-year-2021
story: As the winter months roll in, the nights are drawing longer and the days shorter - meaning thewinter solstice is just around the corner.The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year in the UK when we have the fewest hours of daylight.The good newsis that after its over, the days continuously get longer until the summer solstice in June.Heres what you need to know about the shortest day in the UK in ...When is the winter solstice in  The winter solstice will take place on Tuesday December  .During this day, the northern hemisphere will only see around hours  minutes of daylight.Why does the winter solstice happen The winter solstice occurs in the UK when the north pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the sun.While it only happens once a year in the UK, it happens twice a year across the globe, once in the northern hemisphere and once in the southern hemisphere.The term winter solstice actually refers to the exact moment the earth is tilted furthest away from the sun, however it is also sometimes used to describe the day this occurs.During the winter solstice in the northern hemisphere, the further north you travelthe darker it will be.On December  , the north pole will remain dark for the entire day.From this day onwards, the days will gradually grow longer until the summer solstice six months later, following which the days will again begin to shorten.When is summer solstice The next summer solstice will take place on Tuesday June   in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day of the year.Summer solstice is when the earth is tilted closest to the sun and is the opposite of the winter solstice.

title: scottish-fish-shops-need-visit-britains-best-revealed
story: The best chippies in Britain have been revealedand numerous Scottish joints have made it onto the list!There is nothing quite like a fish supper, and the National Federation of Fish Fryers yearly guide to quality fish and chips is here to help you seek out the finest across the UK.Named in the guide are Scottish chippies, includingBritains most northerly fish and chip shop.With the weekend just around the corner, here are Scotlands best fish and chip shops as according to the National Federation of Fish Friers...Where are Scotlands best fish and chip shops Frankies Fish and ChipsBrae, ShetlandLocated in Shetland, Frankies Fish and Chips boasts the title of the UKs most northerly chippy. With sea views over Busta voe, you can enjoy fish, chips, seafood, homemade cakes, teas and coffees.Moores Fish and Chip ShopKing Street, Castle Douglas, DumfriesMoores serves traditional Scottish fish and chips as well as pies, burgers, kebabs and ice cream.Lows Traditional Fish and ChipsUnit , Westhill Shopping Centre, WesthillUnite  , Berryden BusinessPark, AberdeenSo good it has two branches on the list! This -year old award winning family company serves fresh food and offers vegan and coliec options.Scrabster Seafood BarThe Harbour, Scrabster, Caithness, HighlandThis fish and chip shop works with local fisherman in Scrabster to sell seasonal and sustainable fish, shellfood and seafood.Sea Salt and SoleStation Road, Dyce, AberdeenThis family owned fish shop takes pride in selling locally sourced produce.The Eating PlaiceHigh Street, Alness, Ross-shireLocated in Alness, The Eating Plaice is "committedto providing the best food and drinkexperience in your own home".The Fish HooseMain Street, Thornton, FeAll produce from the multi award winning Fish Hoose is sourced sustainably.The House of BruarBy Blair Atholl, Pitlochry, PerthshireThe House of Bruaris a famous Scottish institution, and now it has added fish and chips to its ranks.The AshvaleNumerous venues across AberdeenshireWith over -years of award winning experience, the Ashvale certainly knows what its doing when it comes to fish and chips.The Fish WorksThe Promenade, Largs, North AyrshireAnother family run business, husband and we duo Ross and Tfany have over -years experience in the industry, with their chippy offering great views of Firth of Clyde.The Real Food CafeTyndrum, PerthshireThis roadside diner is the perfect stop off for not only fish and chips, but also breakfast, lunch, dinner, homebaking, tea and coffee.The Waterfront ChipShopShore Street, Anstruther, FeA traditional fish shop that uses their very own family recipe to batter the fresh fish and assures "you wont be disappointed".The Wee ChippyShore Street, Anstruther, FeAnstruther is famous for its fish and chips: just down the road from the The Waterfront Chip Shop is The Wee Chippy, where you can purchase freshly fried fish to order from the family business.

title: nicola-sturgeon-update-today-time-watch-live
story: Nicola Sturgeon will join Jason Leitch to hold a media briefing today ahead of COP as Covid cases in Scotlandcontinue to rise.It comes just days after the first ministers latest update to Scottish Parliament, where she expressed slight concern over the number of hospitalisations in Scotland.With COP due to begin on Sunday in Glasgow, there have been warnings that Scotland could see a sharp rise in cases following the climate conference.On Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said she could not rule out introducing further restrictions in the futurerequired to curb case rates.The first minister and national clinical director will be joined byPolice Scotland Chief Constable Iain Livingstone to discuss COP, which will take place from October  - November .Heres everything you need to know about the briefing, including what time and how to watch live...What time is Nicola Sturgeon speaking today The first minister will host a media briefing at pm today alongside Jason Leitch and Iain Livingstone from Police Scotland.It will take place fromAtlantic Quay in Glasgow, with journalists asking questions both in person and via Zoom.How can I watch Nicola Sturgeons update today The media briefing is expected to be streamed on the Scottish Governments social media s including Twitter and Facebook.It is also expected to be available to watch on the Scottish Government website.What did Nicola Sturgeon say on Tuesday During Tuesdays briefing, Nicola Sturgeon warned that Covid hospitalisations had seen a slight rise, with infection now more prevalent in the older population.This is depsite Covid rates in Scotland being lower than England, Wales and Northern Ireland, as confirmed by the first minister during her statement.She also confirmed that from Sunday, fully vaccinated people travelling to Scotland from abroad would only be required to provide a lateral flow test within -hours of arrival, instead of a PCR test.Lateral flow test are around pound- cheaper than PCR tests, and this guidance is inkeeping with the UK government guidelines on internationaltravel.

title: scotland-rugby-channel-watch-scotland-v-tonga-weekend-autumn-series
story: Scotlandwill play Tonga this weekend at Murrayfield stadium in the first match ofautumn internationals series .As October draws to a close, the rugbyseason is well and truly underway, with the match between the teams their first head to head since .It was Scotland who proved triumphant at their last encounter, scoring five tries to beat Tonga - at Kilmarnock.The odds on paper are tipped in Scotlands favour: of the four meetings with Tonga, Scotland have won three.In front of a home crowd at Murrayfield, the team will look to extend this track record to four wins, as the autumn internationalseries gets underway.Heres what you need to know about Saturdays Scotland match against Tonga...Kick-off time for Scotland v Tonga match this weekend The Scotland v Tonga match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday October at :pm.It marks the start of the autumn international series, which will last throughout November.How to watch Scotland v Tonga live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at :pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhat is the line-up for the Scotland v Tonga match Scotland TeamForwardsPierre SchoemanGeorge TurnerZander FagersonJamie HodgsonRob HarleyJamie Ritchie Hamish WatsonMatt FagersonBacksAli Price Blair KinghornRufus McLeanSam JohnsonSione TuipulotuKyle SteynDarcy GrahamReplacementsStuart McInallyJamie BhattiOli KebbleMarshall SykesLuke CrosbieNick HainingJamie DobieRoss Thompson

title: covid-nicola-sturgeon-say-cop26-update-today
story: Nicola Sturgeon was joined by Professor Jason Leitch andPolice ScotlandChief Constable Iain Livingstone to give an update ahead of COP.During Tuesdays Covid update to Parliament, the first minister warned that Covid hospitalisations were rising, with more cases among the older population.Amid warnings that case numbers could surgefollowing the climate conference, which will see over tens of thousands of people flock to the city, today the first minister outlined how the government aimed to protect both citizens and those visiting.Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged that the summit would bring a certain level of disruption, due to the extremely high profile nature of the event.Heres what we learned from the update today.... Avoid unnecessary trips during the first few days of COPpossibleThe first minister encourgaged people to avoid travelling across Glasgow and the central belt where possible, particularly in the first few days of COP.She said that this did not only apply to road travel, but also by rail, following the news that ScotRail workers will no longer be striking during the conference.If travel is necessary, the government advise planning journeys carefully.. Certain dates expected to be particularly busyAccording to the first minister, the first Sunday, Monday and Tuesday of COP will be particularly busy as worldleaders come together.Next Friday and Saturday will see large scale protests across the city, with Saturdays event expected to see up to , people march from Kelvingrove Park to Glasgow Green.. Measures taken to try to reduce Covid transmissionScottish government doing everything they can to mitigate the spread of Covid, according to the first minister.Explainging that she understood why people may be wary, Nicola Sturgeon said that the government was working with the UN to try and minimise a surge in Covid followingthe conference.. Disruptionexperienced "for a purpose"The first minister acknowledged the disruption to the people of Glasgow, and thanked residents for their patience.She added that the disruption was "for a purpose" with COP focussed on minimising global warming and climate changein the future.. Clear message to those intent on actually disruption the conferencePolice chiefIain Livingstone acknoweldged that the UN was encourgaing people to make their voices heard during the conference, and endorsed this message.However, he addedthat swt action would be taken against those intent on actually disrupting the Covid conference.Police Scotland said that physical interference would be required where protesters were preventing the conference from going ahead.. Be even more careful during COPJason Leitch encouraged people to continue following the remaining Covidrules in Scotland, and urged people to be even more careful over the coming weeks.When asked how emergency services will cope with the added demand and the navigation of protests, Jason Leitch said there was a "many layered" approach.He added that Scotland was "ready" and the healthservice was "prepared" for COP.. Nicola Sturgeon to co-host event with Boris JohnsonThe first minister confirmed she would co-host an event on Tuesday afternoon with UK prime minister Boris Johnson.She also added that while the Scottish government and British government had some big dferences, they would work hard to come to the best outcome for the world over the coming days.

title: leader october 8 2021
story: Well done to Emily Bennie and Ross Conner for their recent musical achievements.Emily has achieved the ARSM diploma, designed to give promising musicians an opportunity to demonstrate performance skills after grade eight, which is considered by many musicians to be the pinnacle of achievement.What makes it even more impressive is the fact she achieved it while also working towards her National , Higher and Advanced Higher exams.And Ross won his silver award after competing again some of the best young pipers in Scotland, with just  competing places up for grabs.Ross well and truly earned his spot, having won numerous competitions and awards over recent years.As well as his musical pursuits, Ross participates in many events in and around Campbeltown to raise funds for charity and has recently become a volunteer crewman on the Campbeltown leboat.Ross and Emily#s successes don#t come easily both have dedicated years of commitment to their talents and are thoroughly deserving of these fantastic accolades. They have bright futures ahead of them.Kintyre has a long and ied musical heritage and it#s people like Ross and Emily who are keeping it alive and no doubt inspiring others to do the same.

title: harper scores second mull rally win 19 years after his first
story: The Mini JCW WRC driver was delighted to top the podium,  years on from his maiden  win.Daniel said: #It’s been a long wait for this second win and I think that actually makes it better than the first one. I always, always wanted to win driving a Mini.#As always, this has been a fantastic event – but it’s been tricky. The weather’s never straightforward and we took a bit of a gamble on Saturday morning, taking a slick when we thought it would dry up a bit. That’s what this rally’s all about. It’s great to be back after missing last year # due to Covid # and we’ll be back next year.#The Englishman was the last non-Muileach to take victory on what was a typically challenging all-asphalt event. Local hero and winner last time out Paul MacKinnon retired from the lead when his Ford Fiesta Rally MkII suffered an engine problem on Saturday afternoon.The second leg of the event was a heart-breaker for local fans with Dervaig’s John MacCrone also departing after an engine issue in another Fiesta Rally MkII following the Mishnish Lochs  test.For the first time in its history, the Mull Rally was a round of the British Rally Championship and the arrival of the nation’s finest and fastest drivers was a source of immediate action. Matt Edwards, chasing a hat-trick of BRC titles, was one of the first victims of the event, sliding off the road on the third corner of the opening stage.Having recovered from signicant damage to the right-rear of his Volkswagen Polo GTI R, the Welshman’s recovery drive to move up  positions to fth at the finish – setting a string of fastest times and breaking stage records along the way – was one of the stories of Saturday.Edwards’ countryman Osian Pryce was, however, the BRC master of Mull. Running a sister Volkswagen from the Mel Evans Motorsport team, Pryce delivered the perfect drive to score maximum points and a superb second place.Happy to have furthered his lead at the top of the BRC standings, Pryce said: #This is what I came here for.#It’s been a dficult rally, having to try to manage the pace and everything from around three corners in has been quite tough on roads I don’t know and in a car which hasn’t given me complete confidence. But we’re here.#Will I come back  Definitely. We heard a lot about this place and, like I said before, I don’t know why it’s taken me so long to come up here.#William Creighton was another star BRC performer, finishing an outstanding eighth to score maximum junior points in the British series.Mark Constantine, Vauxhall Corsa Kyle White, Peugeot  R William Creighton, Ford Fiesta Rally, and David Bogie, Ford Escort, also celebrated class success on the island, with Bogie’s sensational third overall meaning Eddie O’Donnell, Ford Escort, picking up the class D award.The Beatson’s Building Supplies Mull Rally is, of course, more than just a motorsport event. It represents an annual pilgrimage for thousands of marshals, team personnel and fans. The island’s , population is doubled during rally week.Absent from the calendar last season, island businesses were delighted to see the Beatson’s Building Supplies Mull Rally back.Sarah Fraser opened The Little Bespoke Bakery in August last year and worked tirelessly to fuel everyone through rally week.#It’s been an amazing week,# said Sarah.#We’ve had such a busy week, with the recce and the rally itself. I’m from a rallying family myself, so I understand the appeal of the sport and it’s been so nice to meet folk from all over the place.#In terms of the business, the rally offers a welcome extension to what’s already been a really busy season. We know the winter means things will quieten down a wee bit, so knowing we’ve got an event like this is a huge boost. All of that said, it’ll be quite nice to get some sleep next week – it’s not often that we’re open until two o’clock in the morning!#Sleep is something clerk of the course Andy Jardine and his team are looking forward to after another stellar event.Andy said: #What can I say  I’ll start by thanking more than  volunteers who give up their time to come here and allow us to run this great event. We couldn’t manage without them.#We’ve had a good clean rally this year. There have been some small issues, but nothing this superb team couldn’t cope with.
