story: It comes just seven months after the first budget of the year was announced in March, and will coincide with the conclusion of the spending review.Various plans have already been leaked to the press, including a hike in minimum wage and investment in transport, however more will be unveiled later today.The chancellor will also use the budget to reveal any cuts or increases to tax, which will directly impact how much money we have to spend.Heres what you need to watch about todays announcement...The autumn budget  will be announced on Wednesday October  to MPs in the House of Commons at around :pm.This will coincide with the conclusion of the spending review, which the Chancellor is expected to announce at a similar time.: Whats the dference between spending review and budget The autumn budget will be broadcast live on most majornewschannels, includingBBC Two during Politics Live, which will start at :am.You can also watch it online at Parliament LiveTV.A number of plans have already been leaked from the autumn budget, including:

title: budget-today-budget-summary-impacts-scotland
story: It marks the second budget of the year, with the first taking place just seven months ago in March.With devolution, only certain aspects of the budget announcement apply to people in Scotland.When announcements are England specic,Scotlands overall spending budget will increase thanks to something called the Barnett formula.For example, the UK have proposed to spend pound. billion on dealing with the NHS England backlog, so Scotland will get around .% of this figure because Scotlands population is roughly .% of Englands population.Heres a breakdown of how the budget will impact people in Scotland...Yes - minimum and living wages are not devolved so all changes made by the UK government apply to Scotland.It means that from April  ,those on national living wage in Scotland will be paid pound. hour.The national minimum wage will also see rises:The taper rateis amount your benefit payment reduces asyour income increases.Currently p is takenoff your benefit for every extra pound earned after tax, with the rate set at %.In todays announcement, the chancellor confirmed this taper ratewould be reduced to p, a cut of %.This will benefit low-income families where the adults are in work by increasing their overall income.However, it wont impact families who are out of work, who recently faced the pound cut to universal credit which came into force earlier this month.Since benefits are reserved the Westminster and not devolved to Scotland, this taper rate reduction will apply to people in Scotland.English cities will see money invested to improve transport infrastructure.Transport is a devolved matter, however Scotland will get money through the Barnett formula, which is what the UK government uses when they spend more money in England to keep spending more fair.Although Scotland will get money because England are spending more on transport, the Scottish government can do what they please with this money and do not necessarily need to use it for transport.Health is completely devolved, so announcements regarding funding for the NHS refer to NHS England only.However, Scotland will once again get money through the Barnett system, which they could choose to spend on the NHS.For example, during yesterdays Covid update, Nicola Sturgeon confirmed the Scottish government would spend additional money on NHS Scotland.Fuel duty is a tax included in the price ofpetrol, diesel and other fuels used in vehicles or for heating.It is reserved to Westminster, meaning the freeze to the price of fuel duty will apply to Scotland.Foreign affairs are not devolved, so the UK government is in charge of Great Britains border control.This means that thepoundm to protect UK borders, including poundm for a new fleet of patrol boats, will apply to Scotland.According to the UK government, this fund aims to invest in infrastructures which will improve every day le for people across the UK.This pound million allocated to Scotland will back projects in places including Aberdeen and Lewis, Rishi Sunak said in todays announcement.Through the Barnett formula, there will be an increase to Scottish Governmentfunding in each year by pound. billion, according to the chancellor.Yes, alcohol duty is reserved to Westminster, so the announcement that alcohol dutywill increase on stronger alcohols such as fortied wine and higher volume red wines will apply to Scotland.A new lower rate of alcohol duty on draught beers and cider will also apply to Scotland, as willthe cancellation of theplanned increase in duty on spirits like Scotch Whisky, wine, cider and beer - which will come into action from midnight tonight.

title: johnnie-meechans-miracle-recovery-nearly-dying-covid-19
story: Johnnie Meechan, a -year-old fundraising father-of-five, was diagnosed with a neuroendocrine tumour, commonly known as NET, in .Since his diagnosis, Johnnie has blogged about his battle with cancer and his ongoing fundraising efforts on his lsquoJohnniersquos Journeyrsquo social media pages.He told the Courier of his horric ordeal with Covid after spending a ldquohorrendous eight days in hospital last month ndash and urged people to take the virus seriously and get vaccinated.Johnnie, who is double-vaccinated, said: ldquoAt the beginning of September, I tested positive for Covid after my family had the virus one by one.ldquoIt started with my eldest son and I was the last to get it, which was surprising because I have a weak immune system, but it gave me the opportunity to look after my family first.ldquoI was OK for a few days until I went to bed one night and my we couldnrsquot wake me the next morning.ldquoAn ambulance was called as I slipped in and out of consciousness.Johnnie was rushed to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and upon arrival was informed by two doctors that his organs were failing.He was delivered the devastating news that he would ldquonot live to see the next day.He said: ldquoThe night I arrived, the doctor said to me every organ was failing.ldquoI wouldnrsquot see the next morning andI did it would be a miracle.Johnnie also claimed that he did not have a choice about not being assigned resuscitation.ldquoMy family were distraught and were firmly under the impression I was going to die that evening, he added.ldquoI wasnrsquot able to speak to my we during that time as I could hardly breathe for the first few days.ldquoYou donrsquot just go in and tell someone: lsquoLook, yoursquore dead so it doesnrsquot matter what we do, you donrsquot have a hope in hell.rsquo I just donrsquot accept that my imprint, my le, my story does not go around that mould. I never accepted it, I pushed through.Johnnie praised the hard work of medical staff in the hospital who he said were ldquoworking against a wave that they have no way of stopping.He added: ldquoIt feels like they are patching wounds that continue to bleed.ldquoItrsquos like a bed and breakfast, except most donrsquot come out.Johnnie was hit with another devastating blow once he left hospital.While reading over his discharge letter, Johnnie discovered that he had battled severe sepsis during his stay.Due to his treatment, Johnniersquos pancreas was ldquopumped full of steroids and he left hospital needing to inject himself with insulin twice a day.ldquoI went in mildly diabetic needing only one tablet a day, he said. ldquoNow, I have to inject insulin twice a day and I check my blood five times a day.Johnniersquos friend William Turner recently cycled Mont Ventoux in France and raised pound, for Johnniersquos Journey.He said: ldquoGiven Johnniersquos weakened immune system, it was a worry for all of us when Covid got into the house and spread through the family.ldquoIt sounds like Johnnie had to fight back from the brink to beat it and we are all very relieved he did.ldquoHis experience on the Covid ward sounded horrendous and mirrored a lot of what my dad had told me when he was in last year.ldquoIrsquom glad he was able to find that extra push to get through it and home again in the circumstances.ldquoJohnnie often talks of his thoughts that any illness is potentially his last so it always creates massive worry.ldquoThe NHS staff deserve praise for their work in constant dficult circumstances and with limited resources.Johnnie added: ldquoIrsquove got a young family and my time might come sooner than most, but I am not going out like that, no way.ldquoI was fighting to get home to my family to see them again, to bring a message to people, one Irsquove preached myself many times that Covid is real.ldquoPeople will sit and argue that theyrsquove read this and that, but they donrsquot know nothing.ldquoWhen yoursquore sitting in a hospital room sucking on a ventilator waiting to die, then you can tell me I donrsquot want your ventilator, I donrsquot want your vaccines. Then yoursquoll know.Johnnie has since urged his followers to get vaccinated and understand that the virus is real.He added: ldquoItrsquos heartbreaking up there, we sit oblivious for the most part unless directly affected.ldquoIf I wasnrsquot double vaccinated I wouldnrsquot be here, itrsquos that simple.ldquoPlease get vaccinated. Itrsquos not just about your own beliefs, you are risking thousands of lives.ldquoWhen it does come knocking, and it will, Irsquod bet my left leg yoursquod sell your soul for the protection and ventilators required to live.ldquoLe gets ripped out your hands without an ounce of warning ndash it can and will happen to anyone.ldquoChoose le whilst itrsquos there.Dr Tracey Gillies, medical director, NHS Lothian, said: ldquoBeing admitted to hospital at any time can be a distressing and disorientating time for any patient, especiallythey are very unwell."If Mr Meechan has any concerns or questions, he should contact us directly to discuss further.

title: claim-self-catering-now-lifestyle-holiday-choice-bid-made-flat-used-holiday-let
story: The growing popularity of Airbnb properties and domestic holidays are being used to argue the case for a three-bedroom property in the village to be used as a holiday let.Felicity Rabbitte has applied to East Lothian Council for a retrospective change of use for the flat in Marine House, on Muirfield Drive and she has pointed to recent surveys of tourists to make her case.Referring to an Airbnb study which estimated its listings alone generated .million visitors in , averaging  visitors a year for every short-term let, she said that, while her property did not use the Airbnb , the evidence showed a change in attitude to self-catering. She said: ldquoSelf-catering is not a budget thing now, itrsquos much more about a lestyle trip ndash people want their own private space and clients want to be able to work in their flats.ldquoPeople are now more particular. Itrsquos about lestyle, cooking, and private and flexible space.And in her statement applying for the change of use for the flat, she said that a survey commissioned by East Lothian Council had revealed that half of all overnight visitors to the county stayed in caravan parks or rented flats or houses.She said that recent surveys of visitors to East Lothian highlighted the need for more flexible accommodation to encourage them to stay.She said: ldquoItrsquos about the tourism industry ndash driving and growing it, people spending money in the economy.ldquoHotels cannot support the volume of people visiting the area. There has to be more accommodationtourism is going to continue to grow and itrsquos great for the local economy.The application for change of use is being considered by officers and is available to view on the councilrsquos planning portal.

title: east-lintons-phone-box-covered-climate-emergency-messages-weekly-vigils-planned
story: Climate Action East Lintonhas renovated the phone box, on East Lintonrsquos High Street, ahead of the COP climate change conference in Glasgow.Members of the community and primary school were invited to write messages, which can now be viewed in the windows of the phone box, in time for COPrsquos launch on Sunday.To promote the initiative, CAEL members also dressed in clothing from the s ndash when the phone box was erected ndash to the s, when mobile phones came into use.CAEL members are meeting East Lothianrsquos MSP Paul McLennan on Saturday at am.A spokesperson for the group, whose vision is for the East Linton area to become ldquoa carbon-neutral, resilient community in balance with nature, said: ldquoAt a time where so many feel powerless and unable to have our voices heard, this is a way in which community voices can come together and share their depth of feeling.ldquoKey messages will be taken to Glasgow on banners and subsequently sent to politicians.Additional activities are planned, including weekly vigils in The Square. The vigils, which take place -pm this Saturday and also on November  and , are for quiet contemplation and the chance for people to come together. There will also be a community presence at the phone box from am to pm tomorrow , Saturday and Sunday.

title: bells-silenced-much-day-knox-academy
story: Pupils and staff at the secondary school will start November with a reduced number of school bells.The decision was taken following a consultation in the school.Benefits of a lsquono bells minimal bellsrsquo policy was said to include better time management and reduction in anxiety for youngsters with additional support needs.Sue Cook, headteacher at the school, confirmed that the month-long trial would start on Monday.She said: ldquoFollowing this month, we will carry out an evaluation to seewe retain this.ldquoDuring this time, we will only have a bell to mark the start of the school day, the end of break, lunch and end of the day.ldquoTimekeeping by staff and pupils will be paramount to making this successful and is a great le skill to have.

title: haddington-farmers-market-stallholder-thanks-public-money-help-save-cows
story: A combination of loss of income due to the global pandemic and a run of wet weather left Brenda Leddy, of Stichill Jerseys, Kelso, unable to meet the costs of repairing her cowshed.The -year-old decided to launch a fundraiser.She said: ldquoI was totally overwhelmed by peoplersquos generosity and especially in Haddington.ldquoI have been selling my Jersey cream, butter, clotted cream, cheese and dairy desserts at Haddington Farmersrsquo Market for about  years now and I have got to know so many people who have become loyal customers over that time.Brendarsquos cows are the only herd of their kind in the Borders.She will be back at the farmersrsquo market, on Court Street, this Saturday.The market, which runs from am to pm, has been a staple of the social calendar for more than  years and regularly attracts hundreds of visitors.Brenda added: ldquoDuring Covid, things were very tough financially.ldquoFarmersrsquo markets are my main source of income and they were all closed for months during the pandemic.ldquoHowever, like most farmers, my costs still continued ndash feed, vet bills, overheads, etc.ldquoWhen the cowshed needed repairing, it was the last straw.ldquoPerhaps foolishly, I decided to soldier on and try and save the Jersey cows.ldquoThrough the East Lothian Courier, I just wanted to say a big thank you to all those who have supported me.ldquoFor example, a customer handed me an envelope at the farmersrsquo market which I didnrsquot open until I got home. I just sat down and wept at the sheer generosity of this gt.To visit the fundraising page, go to gofundme f save-our-boarder-jersey-cows

title: dunbear-sculpture-lit-green-ahead-start-cop26
story: The five-metre-high steel sculpture of a brown bear was designed by Andy Scott, who also designed The Kelpies, and was unveiled in  as the focal point for the area to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store.The sculpture is a tribute to John Muir, the Dunbar-born naturalist and conservationist who emigrated to the USA. He travelled extensively in the country, helping to form the Sierra Club which has gone on to be one of the largest environmental organisations in the world.Now, the sculpture will turn green ahead of the conference, which starts on Monday.Ken Ross, from Hallhill Developments Limited, which has plans to transform the area into a low-carbon mixed-use development, said: ldquoBeing in such a prominent position at the gateway to Dunbar, the stunning DunBear sculpture provides the perfect opportunity to commemorate key events such as COP, one of the most important global meetings ever to take place in the UK.ldquoIt is also fitting that it should be part of our low-carbon community of DunBear Park, which through signicant investment will adopt the latest low-carbon technology, with renewable heat and power generated onsite, delivering on our ambitious goal to be an exemplar low-carbon development.ldquoThe DunBear not only celebrates the work of one man but also reminds us we can each make a positive contribution to climate change and reduce global warming for future generations.

title: clocks-go-back-weekend---time
story: Between Saturday night and Sunday morning, we will gain an extra hour,meaning it will be lighter in the mornings but darker in the evenings.Clocks changes always take place on the weekend to try and limit disruption to everday le.Heres what you need to know about when the clocks will change, what time and why they go back...The clocks will go back in the early hours ofSunday October .They go back on the same weekend every year, with the change always taking place on the last Sunday of October.: Does my iPhone automatically update the time The change to the clocks will comeinto effect around am on Sunday.It means we are reverting back to GMT, which stands for Greenwich Mean Time and is thestandard time against which time zones in other areas of theworldare measured.Meanwhile, BST stands for British Summer Time and is the time zone referenced when the clocks go forward in spring.The BSTis GMT+ hour.The principal reason we change the clocks is to get the most out of the daylight.The first clock change was introduced by the German government in  during the first world war as a means of saving energy - the longer the daylight hours lasted, the less electricity required.Yes! The good news about the clocks going back is we get an extra hour inthe day - or an extra hour to sleep!The clocks might only just be going back, but you may already be wondering when they will go forward again...We have a wee while to wait, with the next clock change scheduled for March , when they will go forwardin order to make the most of the long hours of daylight.Like in autumn, the change will take place on a Sunday to avoid too much disruption.Next years change will take place on Sunday March  , marking the start of BST.The clocks going forward means we lose an hour, however we gain this back every autumn when they go back again.

title: winter-solstice-shortest-day-year-2021
story: The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year in the UK when we have the fewest hours of daylight.The good news is that after its over, the days continuously get longer until the summer solstice in June.Heres what you need to know about the shortest day in the UK in ...The winter solstice will take place on Tuesday December  .During this day, the northern hemisphere will only see around hours  minutes of daylight.The winter solstice occurs in the UK when the north pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the sun.While it only happens once a year in the UK, it happens twice a year across the globe, once in the northern hemisphere and once in the southern hemisphere.The term winter solstice actually refers to the exact moment the earth is tilted furthest away from the sun, however it is also sometimes used to describe the day this occurs.During the winter solstice in the northern hemisphere, the further north you travel the darker it will be.On December  , the north pole will remain dark for the entire day.From this day onwards, the days will gradually grow longer until the summer solstice six months later, following which the days will again begin to shorten.The next summer solstice will take place on Tuesday June   in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day of the year.Summer solstice is when the earth is tilted closest to the sun and is the opposite of the winter solstice.

title: scottish-fish-shops-need-visit-britains-best-revealed
story: There is nothing quite like a fish supper, and the National Federation of Fish Fryers yearly guide to quality fish and chips is here to help you seek out the finest across the UK.Named in the guide are Scottish chippies, includingBritains most northerly fish and chip shop.With the weekend just around the corner, here are Scotlands best fish and chip shops as according to the National Federation of Fish Friers...Frankies Fish and ChipsBrae, ShetlandLocated in Shetland, Frankies Fish and Chips boasts the title of the UKs most northerly chippy. With sea views over Busta voe, you can enjoy fish, chips, seafood, homemade cakes, teas and coffees.Moores Fish and Chip Shop King Street, Castle Douglas, DumfriesMoores serves traditional Scottish fish and chips as well as pies, burgers, kebabs and ice cream.Lows Traditional Fish and ChipsUnit , Westhill Shopping Centre, WesthillUnite  , Berryden Business Park, AberdeenSo good it has two branches on the list! This -year old award winning family company serves fresh food and offers vegan and coliec options.Scrabster Seafood BarThe Harbour, Scrabster, Caithness, HighlandThis fish and chip shop works with local fisherman in Scrabster to sell seasonal and sustainable fish, shellfood and seafood.Sea Salt and SoleStation Road, Dyce, AberdeenThis family owned fish shop takes pride in selling locally sourced produce.The Eating Plaice High Street, Alness, Ross-shireLocated in Alness, The Eating Plaice is "committedto providing the best food and drink experience in your own home".The Fish Hoose Main Street, Thornton, FeAll produce from the multi award winning Fish Hoose is sourced sustainably.The House of BruarBy Blair Atholl, Pitlochry, PerthshireThe House of Bruaris a famous Scottish institution, and now it has added fish and chips to its ranks.The AshvaleNumerous venues across AberdeenshireWith over -years of award winning experience, the Ashvale certainly knows what its doing when it comes to fish and chips.The Fish Works The Promenade, Largs, North AyrshireAnother family run business, husband and we duo Ross and Tfany have over -years experience in the industry, with their chippy offering great views of Firth of Clyde.The Real Food CafeTyndrum, PerthshireThis roadside diner is the perfect stop off for not only fish and chips, but also breakfast, lunch, dinner, homebaking, tea and coffee.The Waterfront ChipShop Shore Street, Anstruther, FeA traditional fish shop that uses their very own family recipe to batter the fresh fish and assures "you wont be disappointed".The Wee Chippy Shore Street, Anstruther, FeAnstruther is famous for its fish and chips: just down the road from the The Waterfront Chip Shop is The Wee Chippy, where you can purchase freshly fried fish to order from the family business.

title: nicola-sturgeon-update-today-time-watch-live
story: It comes just days after the first ministers latest update to Scottish Parliament, where she expressed slight concern over the number of hospitalisations in Scotland.With COP due to begin on Sunday in Glasgow, there have been warnings that Scotland could see a sharp rise in cases following the climate conference.On Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said she could not rule out introducing further restrictions in the futurerequired to curb case rates.The first minister and national clinical director will be joined byPolice Scotland Chief Constable Iain Livingstone to discuss COP, which will take place from October  - November .Heres everything you need to know about the briefing, including what time and how to watch live...The first minister will host a media briefing at pm today alongside Jason Leitch and Iain Livingstone from Police Scotland.It will take place fromAtlantic Quay in Glasgow, with journalists asking questions both in person and via Zoom.The media briefing is expected to be streamed on the Scottish Governments social media s including Twitter and Facebook.It is also expected to be available to watch on the Scottish Government website.During Tuesdays briefing, Nicola Sturgeon warned that Covid hospitalisations had seen a slight rise, with infection now more prevalent in the older population.This is depsite Covid rates in Scotland being lower than England, Wales and Northern Ireland, as confirmed by the first minister during her statement.She also confirmed that from Sunday, fully vaccinated people travelling to Scotland from abroad would only be required to provide a lateral flow test within -hours of arrival, instead of a PCR test.Lateral flow test are around pound- cheaper than PCR tests, and this guidance is inkeeping with the UK government guidelines on international travel.

title: scotland-rugby-channel-watch-scotland-v-tonga-weekend-autumn-series
story: As October draws to a close, the rugby season is well and truly underway, with the match between the teams their first head to head since .It was Scotland who proved triumphant at their last encounter, scoring five tries to beat Tonga - at Kilmarnock.The odds on paper are tipped in Scotlands favour: of the four meetings with Tonga, Scotland have won three.In front of a home crowd at Murrayfield, the team will look to extend this track record to four wins, as the autumn international series gets underway.Heres what you need to know about Saturdays Scotland match against Tonga...The Scotland v Tonga match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday October at :pm.It marks the start of the autumn international series, which will last throughout November.Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at :pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmScotland TeamForwards Pierre Schoeman George Turner Zander Fagerson Jamie Hodgson Rob Harley Jamie Ritchie  Hamish Watson Matt FagersonBacks Ali Price  Blair Kinghorn Rufus McLean Sam Johnson Sione Tuipulotu Kyle Steyn Darcy GrahamReplacements Stuart McInally Jamie Bhatti Oli Kebble Marshall Sykes Luke Crosbie Nick Haining Jamie Dobie Ross Thompson

title: covid-nicola-sturgeon-say-cop26-update-today
story: During Tuesdays Covid update to Parliament, the first minister warned that Covid hospitalisations were rising, with more cases among the older population.Amid warnings that case numbers could surgefollowing the climate conference, which will see over tens of thousands of people flock to the city, today the first minister outlined how the government aimed to protect both citizens and those visiting.Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged that the summit would bring a certain level of disruption, due to the extremely high profile nature of the event.Heres what we learned from the update today...The first minister encourgaged people to avoid travelling across Glasgow and the central belt where possible, particularly in the first few days of COP.She said that this did not only apply to road travel, but also by rail, following the news that ScotRail workers will no longer be striking during the conference.If travel is necessary, the government advise planning journeys carefully.According to the first minister, the first Sunday, Monday and Tuesday of COP will be particularly busy as world leaders come together.Next Friday and Saturday will see large scale protests across the city, with Saturdays event expected to see up to , people march from Kelvingrove Park to Glasgow Green.Scottish government doing everything they can to mitigate the spread of Covid, according to the first minister.Explainging that she understood why people may be wary, Nicola Sturgeon said that the government was working with the UN to try and minimise a surge in Covid followingthe conference.The first minister acknowledged the disruption to the people of Glasgow, and thanked residents for their patience.She added that the disruption was "for a purpose" with COP focussed on minimising global warming and climate change in the future.Police chiefIain Livingstone acknoweldged that the UN was encourgaing people to make their voices heard during the conference, and endorsed this message.However, he addedthat swt action would be taken against those intent on actually disrupting the Covid conference.Police Scotland said that physical interference would be required where protesters were preventing the conference from going ahead.Jason Leitch encouraged people to continue following the remaining Covidrules in Scotland, and urged people to be even more careful over the coming weeks.When asked how emergency services will cope with the added demand and the navigation of protests, Jason Leitch said there was a "many layered" approach.He added that Scotland was "ready" and the health service was "prepared" for COP.The first minister confirmed she would co-host an event on Tuesday afternoon with UK prime minister Boris Johnson.She also added that while the Scottish government and British government had some big dferences, they would work hard to come to the best outcome for the world over the coming days.

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.Wersquove enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: green-scotland-can-read-investigation
story: From big-name polluters to Scotlandrsquos most deteriorating rivers and lochs, The Heraldrsquos exclusive, week-long investigation kicks off on Tuesday, October , to answer some of the crucial questions in the ongoing climate crisis.Hot off the back of the successfullsquoWho Runs Scotland rsquo series in July, no stone will be left unturned in The Herald and The Ferretrsquos joint bid to uncover wrongdoing, stimulate debate, and generate discussion.This special series will run in print and online all of this week, exclusively to our subscribers.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today.

title: cop26-glasgow-news-updates-free-herald
story: Here at The Herald, we have been preparing for the summit for months. Well have reporters inside the SEC, and others on the streets of Glasgow ready to bring you the most up to date news from all across the city.Each day, well have experts from across the environmental sphere in our Voices Live section, promising analysis and opinion on the biggest issues of the day.And as a subscriber, you have access to our wide iety of newsletters - including our dedicated COP daily briefing. As the conference gets underway, our reporters will give registered users and subscribers a digest of whats to come throughout the day, and the biggest updates from the ground.A subscription will give you access to our unrivalled COP coverage as well as a number of unmissable perks.With that subscription, yoursquoll see % fewer adverts on our websiteand have unlimited access to all our stories, including premium articles.This means you will be able to readThe Heralds online coverage from our award-winning team uninterrupted.Itrsquos our job to make sure The Herald is your go-to site to keep you up-to-date.But as a Herald subscriber, you will also have access to exclusive "Premium" articles. title: letters-doesnt-snp-want-uks-money
story: Aberdeen has been given pound million for a large development as part of the UK Governmentrsquos Budget Scotland since devolution", The Herald, October . The SNP described it as smoke and mirrors. Future generations need to look closely at the SNP reaction to UK spending. It would rather the UK didnrsquot fund projects within Scotland as it highlights the benefit of being part of the UK.The SNP would rather continue wasting money on overseas offices than help those of us here who are desperate for Aberdeen to get a new lease of le. What future do younger generations want for Scotland  A flashy office in Brussels or investment in their cities, making them places they want to spend time Jane Lax, Aberlour.TIME TO CANCEL DEVOLUTION JUST when is the SNP going to grow up and abandon its tiresomely childish tactics  The Chancellor has given Scotland around pound billion extra money over the next three years. The SNPs response to this windfall is predictably to complain. This policy of decrying anything from Westminster as a slight against devolution or similar charges, designed to garner support for independence, is infantile.Perhaps the next referendum put to Scots voters ought to be whether to cancel devolution rather than seek independence. The rather large amount of public money saved by dissolving an under-achieving Holyrood with its huge infrastructure and running costs could be better spent where in Scotland, such as giving it to our local councils instead. They would use the money more wisely and effectively.Dr Gerald Edwards, Glasgow.SUNAK HEADING FOR NO LEAKS to the media and spin set the scene for positive Budget reviews to aid Rishi Sunakrsquos political ambitions. Yet under Mr Sunak as Chancellor, the reality is that the UK economy will have the highest taxation for  years, coupled to high inflation and substantial borrowing.Cuts to future GDP growth are linked to Brexitand Covid- , while large swathes of us now face a real squeeze on our living standards. He has also made the Prime Minister look foolish, with a freeze on fuel duty and a drop in air passenger dutyjust as delegates are arriving for COP . He could easily have made travel by electric aircraft free of duty and doubled it for fossil fuel planes a carrot for green transport and a stick for polluters.Will Mr Sunak soon be PM  He must be favourite, given the absurd ldquopositivity toward him in the Tory media, while doubts about ldquosocialist Boris Johnson, by the same media, are growing.GR Weir, Ochiltree.BUDGET WILL DETER ENTERPRISEBY expanding the state and raising the tax burden to postwar levels this Tory Budget evoked uncomfortable memories of the era of rationing. The Chancellor pledged that every government department would receive an above-inflation spending increase ndash an extra pound billion in public service spending. To pay for such largesse, the tax burden will rise by the end of this parliament to well over one-third of our GDP.This is the kind of high-tax, high-spending economy with low productivity and average public services which would make Gordon Brown blanch. The belief that we can tax our way to wealth has not been borne out in my span of four score years. In fact I have more sympathy with Nigel Lawsonrsquos dictum: ldquoIncome or property belongs to the people who earn it and the case has to be made for taxing it away.This Budget along with previously-announced policies of raising corporate taxation, national insurance contributions and freezing income tax personal allowances will deter enterprise. Britain is plunging down the tax competitiveness rankings and is now nd out of an index of  nations. As social benefits such as the health service get steadily worse, I doubtldquotaxing and intervening is really the way to go.Dr John Cameron, St Andrews.THE DEATH OF LOCAL INCOME TAXFOR once I agree with Peter Russellthat power should be devolved ldquoback to regional authorities and or regional consortia of service providers hellipempowered to raise a Regional Income Tax and act as a major tool of redistribution. However,this is to be done letrsquos do it on an honest basis.First, Mr Russell displays his central belt prejudice by suggesting ldquoGreater Glasgow be first, followed by Edinburgh and Lothians and Fe. What about the rest of Scotland  There well might have to be ied arrangements in parts of Scotland, but surely the approach cannot ignore large parts of our country. And how much local democracy would be lost through the creation of ldquoGreater Glasgow  Secondly, his claim that ldquothe SNP first came to power in  on an explicit manesto commitment to scrap the Hated Council Tax and to replace it with a Local Income Tax , is correct as far as it goes, but omits a crucial detail. LIT had to be given up because Gordon Brownrsquos Government threatened to hold back the council tax rebate, worth about pound million,Scotland changed its system of local taxation. If Mr Russell wants to understand the failure to implement local income tax, he would do well to look to his own party.Mr Russellrsquos proposals are interesting, particularly as local government is in serious need of reform after the gerrymandered system bequeathed to us by the Major government. If, though, LIT could be frustrated in , how is Regional Income Tax likely to fare in  with the current Westminster Government It must therefore be understood that even though such reform lies within the powers of the Scottish Parliament, the chances of success of any scheme will demand the sanction of the London Government.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.PENALISED BY TAX CONFUSIONRORY Mair is quite right to draw attention to officialese disempowering ordinary people .It reminded me of the growing numbers of ordinary people who have to carry out self-assessment for their taxes, whose means are too modest to secure the services of an accountant and therefore risk making a mistake and being penalised. Or those who have been given more flexibility with their pension accruals but no way of knowing what their best option might be. The free government advice is not specic enough, the online pages confusing and full of technical terms, and gone are the days of asking your friendly bank manager for that sort of advice as not only is the manager unlikely to be in the local branch , but bank staff are constrained by law as to the advice they can give."Consult your financial adviser" is the mantra. Do those repeating it not realise that most people do not have such a thing  There must be thousands of people with no idea how to find a financial adviser or how much they would cost , and so are cast adrt and left floundering. As a consequence, there must be many who take the wrong decisions, or, even worse, dont do anything, because there is no affordable way of finding out what the right options for them might be.In the meantime the better-off can afford to pay for expert advice on taxes, pensions and investments, as they have always done, secure in the knowledge that they will secure the best s.Somebody must be making money out of all this confusion and inertia, but sadly it is not the people who could most do with it.Jane Ann Liston, St Andrews.WHY FLOODING WAS INEVITABLEI WAS not surprised to see localised flooding in ious areas of Glasgow. On my way home on Wednesday nightthere was a deluge of water running down Springburn Road to the Hawthorn Street off-ramp where a massive lake had appeared. It looked like none of the gullies drains on the east side of Springburn Road were taking any water.Judging by pictures in the media of Great Western Road, Balgrayhill Road and other locations, I wonder when these locations were visited by a gully cleaner, remember them  Too many kerbside drains appear full to the top with mud stopping the water flowing away into the drains. Perhaps this is yet another example of a lack of spend on roads maintenance.Douglas Jardine, Bishopbriggs.Read more: This was a Budget that was bad for Scotland

title: letters-glasgow-daft-agree-hosting-cop26
story: In due course, I have no doubt, the upsides for Glasgow and Scotland, including boosts for hotels, restaurants, the tourist industry generally and international publicity, will eventually be weighed in the balance with the downsides, some of which have already evidenced themselves.These downsides include effects on the NHS with a signicant number of hospital appointmentsbeing amended and many staff and patients likely to find their journeys more problematic the demands and pressures on Police Scotland suggest that there will be less resource available for dealing with law enforcement generally the opportunity presented to trade unions to put extra pressure on the employers of their members with regard to wages and other conditions of employment the serious disruption caused to commercial and other road traffic the loss of direct tuition at places of further education with students being directed to work online, and concern about the potential Covid implications of such a substantial number of attendees delegates arriving from countries all over the world.The selection of Glasgow took place some time ago and I appreciate that someone has to do it. However, there have been moments when one is left wondering whether or not those who were looking after the interests of Glasgow during the selection process fully considered and took into account all the implications of hosting such a signicant international event for the communities of the Glasgow area.Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.THE EVERYDAY WASTE OF ENERGYI WONDER to what extent COP or indeed the anti-climate change movement is addressing the issue of energy waste and unnecessary energy usage  Instead of searching for ways to keep up with an apparently ever-increasing demand for energy should they not be seeking ways to encourage a reduction in energy consumption Now that the winter-time dog-walking regime is in place I am becoming aware yet again of the ever-increasing number of houses with unnecessary and often garish under-eaves lighting that serve no useful purpose, routinely unoccupied but fully illuminated rooms, totally superfluous year-round fairy-lights, not to mention illuminated trees, for Petes sake . Do people really need widescreen televisions that take up an entire wall  Does a household really need more than one television, a home cinema, microwave ovens, electronically-operated garage doors, dishwashers and every appliance under the sun you can think of  And as for SUVs and hot tubs...We are told that sending an email is more energy-efficient than sending an item by post but how many totally unnecessary, not to say pointless, emails and texts and social media messages are fired back and forth nowadays  Do people not realise that they use energy  Probably not.Sad to say, but the human race, at least the industrialised, commercialised west, is too egocentric and regards itself to be too entitled, to even consider that these things are adding to the current crisis. And as for giving them up ndash no chance.C Fleming, Kirkintilloch.HEAT PUMPS ARE JUST THE JOBI READ Colin Gunnrsquos letter re heat pumpswith incredulity. Having seen the price of oil head skywards, we installed a heat pump  years ago to directly replace an oil boiler. The heat pump comes on for an hour in the morning to heat the water ndashrequired as we also have solar thermal. It is also programmed to come on for an hour in the morning and an hour in the evening, boththe temperature in the house falls below tolerable levels. At no time is it required to be on for  hours.It is absolute codswallop to say it takes a complete day to heat the house, the mind boggles.Steve Barnet, Gargunnock.GLASGOW, YOU CAN SAY THAT AGAINGLASGOW is a word we will hear spoken with accents strange from across the world: but how should we hear it here PM Johnson and his ilk will give us both barrels with the posh Glahsgeu . We will recognise the more common Glahsgo with its iants Glazgae  eh . Of course we will hear Glezgie and Glesgae, yet whatever version is chosen please let us lose the dour mumble through clenched teeth. Surely we should be confident enough to deliver our great city with clarity, pride and confidence.Thomas Cross, Glasgow.A POMPOSITY OF PROFESSORSINTERESTING to read the explanation of the ious ways that the title of doctor is bestowed on iniduals by your correspondents . As a humble member of one of the professions supplementary to medicine we always felt disadvantaged in the hierarchy when it came to salary negotiations. My curiosity has been aroused by the number of professors that have emerged during the pandemic and wonder how you achieve this status  In my day a professorship was a relatively rare accolade, or maybe it is just another ruse to rise in the salary hierarchy Many years ago visiting France with some pals I was astonished when we associated with a group who all seemed to be professors, only to be told thatrsquos how you address a teacher.Thomas Law, Sandbank, Argyll and Bute.

title: eagles-announce-edinburgh-date-part-50-year-anniversary-tour
story: The world-famous rock band has announced an exclusive three dates in the UK with Edinburgh hosting the only Scottish date.The BT Murrayfield Stadium will host the American giants on Wednesday June , , as they are joined by country outfit Little Big Town in the , capacity stadium.On their -year anniversary the Eagles will be playing their usual hits including ldquoHotel Calornia, ldquoOne of These Nights, ldquoLe in the Fast Lane, ldquoDesperado, and many more.Support act Little Big Townrsquos newest album lsquoNightfallrsquo has also recently propelled their letime global streams to a colossal . billion.:Amy MacDonald and Bow Anderson to perform at Scottish Music Awards Following front man Glenn Freys death in January , the Eagles re-formed in , with Glenns son Deacon Frey and Vince Gill sharing lead vocals for Freys songs.Founding member Don Henley will alsowith Joe Walsh and Timothy B.Schmit.During their last visit to Scotland, the Eagles sold out the Hydro, but ahead of it they issued a ban on fans recording footage duringthe concert. Mobile phones were allowed into the venue, but those going to the show were warned they cant record.However, a similar ban has yet to be announced that applies to the  date.As the best-selling American band of the s, and one of the top-selling acts of all time, the Eagles have sold more than  million albums worldwide, scored six number one albums and topped the singles charts five times. They have won six GRAMMY Awards and were also inducted into the Rock  Roll Hall of Fame in .Tickets for the concertwill go on sale from am on Friday November  atLiveNation.

title: charismatic-figure-first-ever-female-rgi-president
story: Died: August , .EVELYNE ANDERSON, who has died aged , was born in Paris but took Glasgow and the Scottish art scene to her heart when she married Ronnie Anderson in . In  she made history as the first-ever woman President of the Royal Glasgow Institute in its -year history.Charismatic, glamorous and gregarious, she arrived from a background of Parisian cafe society and late-night jazz clubs, determined to lead a colourful le. ldquoShe was a force of nature she always wanted to make things happen, says her daughter Valerie.Music and art played a central role in Evelynersquos le. For her, being surrounded by art was a necessity. ldquoIf I have paintings around me and I have music, Irsquom all right. They are essential to survive. They touch me and I need them, she once said. She had a huge collection of art, and when the walls were full she turned to sculpture.Evelyne was a council member of the Royal Glasgow Institute of the Fine Arts for several years from  onwards. Former president Kenneth Christie remembers: ldquoShe was initially reluctant to take on the role of President in  but, as expected, she went on to lead the RGI for two terms with her unique blend of humour, wisdom and tact, hugely appreciated by the members and, indeed, all who knew her.She could be formidable when needed, especiallya disagreement arose at board meetings. She was also involved with the Society of Scottish Women Artists and was the second female member of the Glasgow Arts Club, braving the male chauvinists there. I wish I could tell her of my personal experience in  when the Arts Club told me they could allow my husband membership so that I could ldquoput my foot over the door. You can imagine my reply.Romance brought her to Scotland. Long before dating sites, she met her husband-to-be the old-fashioned way. A friend had married a Scot and so invited Evelyne to visit. At one dinner party she met Ronnie Anderson, of the Teacherrsquos whisky family. A few months later they were married, and the chic, fun-loving, gregarious Evelyne moved to a specially architect-designed s flat roofed house in the depths of rural Ayrshire.ldquoIt must have been quite a shock for Evelyne but she put up with it for seven years till we moved to the family house in Milton of Campsie, Ronnie recalls. ldquoHowever, she really blossomed when we eventually settled in Glasgowrsquos West End, near friends, art galleries, museums, theatre, concerts and the opera.Both had been married before. Evelyne had a daughter Valerie, and Ronnie, a son, Giles. Seven years later they had a daughter, Josephine. Evelyne loved babies and small children and delighted in her seven grandchildren. With her exuberant hugs, noisy kisses, songs and belly laughs, she made the perfect gran.She had begun le as Evelyne Socquet-Clerc, and never lost her strong French accent. She was just four when the Nazis invaded Paris. Her father, who worked for the French Resistance and was well aware of the dangers involved, sent his three children and her mother out of the city. Evelyne remembered how cold she was as she and her siblings travelled for days on foot.Maybe her early experiences made her into such a good, appreciative and supportive person, because she had a group of lelong women friends, who remember how she could often and easily turn coffee mornings into champagne mornings.Artists such as John Cunningham, Archie Forrest, George Devlin, John Boyd, Christine MacArthur, Norman Edgar, Connie Simmers, Glen Scouller and many others were also friends, as was Gordon Mitchell, convenor of the RGI. Norrie Kirkham painted her portrait and David Donaldson gave her pictures. ldquoEvelyne liked to buy and sell, her husband told me. ldquoShe bought an Alex Goudie still-le of decanters, appropriate for my family connection with Teacherrsquos whisky.Her elder sister, Jeanne Socquet-Clerc, was a big influence. Jeanne had even left home in Paris under disapproving eyes, to follow her career as a painter. Their parents were strictly old-fashioned, believing in conservative professions: secretarial college, not opera. Ever afterwards, Evelyne was determined to support the arts. She and Ronnie were keen concert-goers and members of the Royal Scottish National Orchestra circle. She also supported a couple of Conservatoire students.In later le, and even after the onset of dementia, music and song were hugely important to her. She had done several years of professional classical voice training in Glasgow and loved her singing lessons. ldquoShe got a tremendous amount of joy from learning to sing and finding her voice, says Josephine.Evelyne loved being on stage and in  was involved in Scottish Operarsquos Memory Spinners outreach programme for dementia sufferers. She and her carer attended one rehearsal a week for eight weeks, culminating in a performance with a live orchestra and singers from Scottish Opera in a performance of Die Fiederamaus in the companyrsquos production studios.Surrounded by paintings, to the end she enjoyed conducting music on Spoty from her hospice bed. With the help of technology her family were able to have Evelyne singing at her own funeral, and along with family movie clips and photos gave everyone a touching memorial that I am sure she would have loved. The touching video can be viewed online at http:www.cmtv.biz Evelyne.Evelyne Anderson was a uniquely charismatic figure, able to galvanize others in support of the arts, beloved by all who knew her. We need more people like her. She is survived by Victoria, Josephine and Giles, and her grandchildren.CLARE HENRY

title: scotland-rugby-channel-watch-scotland-v-tonga-weekend-autumn-series
story: As October draws to a close, the rugby season is well and truly underway, with the match between the teams their first head to head since .It was Scotland who proved triumphant at their last encounter, scoring five tries to beat Tonga - at Kilmarnock.The odds on paper are tipped in Scotlands favour: of the four meetings with Tonga, Scotland have won three.In front of a home crowd at Murrayfield, the team will look to extend this track record to four wins, as the autumn international series gets underway.Heres what you need to know about Saturdays Scotland match against Tonga...The Scotland v Tonga match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday October at :pm.It marks the start of the autumn international series, which will last throughout November.Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at :pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmScotland TeamForwards Pierre Schoeman George Turner Zander Fagerson Jamie Hodgson Rob Harley Jamie Ritchie  Hamish Watson Matt FagersonBacks Ali Price  Blair Kinghorn Rufus McLean Sam Johnson Sione Tuipulotu Kyle Steyn Darcy GrahamReplacements Stuart McInally Jamie Bhatti Oli Kebble Marshall Sykes Luke Crosbie Nick Haining Jamie Dobie Ross Thompson

title: covid-nicola-sturgeon-say-cop26-update-today
story: During Tuesdays Covid update to Parliament, the first minister warned that Covid hospitalisations were rising, with more cases among the older population.Amid warnings that case numbers could surgefollowing the climate conference, which will see over tens of thousands of people flock to the city, today the first minister outlined how the government aimed to protect both citizens and those visiting.Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged that the summit would bring a certain level of disruption, due to the extremely high profile nature of the event.Heres what we learned from the update today...The first minister encourgaged people to avoid travelling across Glasgow and the central belt where possible, particularly in the first few days of COP.She said that this did not only apply to road travel, but also by rail, following the news that ScotRail workers will no longer be striking during the conference.If travel is necessary, the government advise planning journeys carefully.According to the first minister, the first Sunday, Monday and Tuesday of COP will be particularly busy as world leaders come together.Next Friday and Saturday will see large scale protests across the city, with Saturdays event expected to see up to , people march from Kelvingrove Park to Glasgow Green.Scottish government doing everything they can to mitigate the spread of Covid, according to the first minister.The first minister acknowledged the disruption to the people of Glasgow, and thanked residents for their patience.Police chiefIain Livingstone acknoweldged that the UN was encourgaing people to make their voices heard during the conference, and endorsed this message.However, he addedthat swt action would be taken against those intent on actually disrupting the Covid conference.Police Scotland said that physical interference would be required where protesters were preventing the conference from going ahead.Jason Leitch encouraged people to continue following the remaining Covidrules in Scotland, and urged people to be even more careful over the coming weeks.When asked how emergency services will cope with the added demand and the navigation of protests, Jason Leitch said there was a "many layered" approach.He added that Scotland was "ready" and the health service was "prepared" for COP.The first minister confirmed she would co-host an event on Tuesday afternoon with UK prime minister Boris Johnson.She also added that while the Scottish government and British government had some big dferences, they would work hard to come to the best outcome for the world over the coming days.

Itrsquos worth checking in every few months just to see what theyrsquove got on tap.Progressive players may be disappointed by their jackpot sizes, however, as theyrsquore capped atpound,.BEST SLOTS SITES FAQSIs It Legal to Play Slots Online That will depend on where you live, as dferent places have dferent laws regarding online gambling. You should check your local laws before setting up an account anywhere.Also, keep in mind that the laws of your jurisdiction arenrsquot the only thing you need to worry about. Your financial institutions may not do business with slot sites, so you should also check with your bank to make sure that you donrsquot get into hot water with them.Can I Trust Slot Sites If you find a reputable online casino, it will be as trustworthy as any gambling house yoursquoll find in Vegas. That being said, not all UK slot sites are reputable, so herersquos what you should look for before you put money down:Are Online Video Slots Rigged As long as you find a reputable casino that has titles from reputable providers, then the games shouldnrsquot be rigged.However, donrsquot make the mistake of assuming that any casino games are beatable just because theyrsquore not rigged. The casinos have to make money somehow, and the odds will always be in their favor.That being said, some slots offer better odds than others. Look for a gamersquos -to-playerpercentage. This will tell you just how big of an edge the house has, andyou can find a title with a high RTP, you can really stretch your gaming budget.Are Online Slots Hard to Play That depends on the slot game you pick. Some slots are almost exactly like the one-armed bandits of yesteryear: they have single reels with clearly-defined ways to win and lose.However, some modern slots are extremely complex, with multiple reels, bonus rounds, and literally thousands of ways to win. While they can be intimidating to novice users, they can also be incredibly fun, and the added complexity makes it less likely that yoursquoll get bored with them quickly.The good news is that many sites have the option of taking practice rounds, allowing you to play the slot without risking any money. This allows you to get the hang of the more complicated games without losing an arm and a leg in the process.At the end of the day, though, you should play whichever games you want to play. If that means sticking to the classic machines and leaving the newfangled ones alone, then thatrsquos perfectly fine.Can I Play Online Slots on My Mobile Device Yes, almost all UK slot sites support mobile play nowadays. The quality of that play will y, however.A few sites have dedicated apps for iOS, Android, or both. These apps usually make for a smoother gaming experience, but theyrsquore still relatively rare in the online gaming industry.Most online casinos require you to play on your browseryoursquore playing on a mobile device, and that experience can y wildly. Some are just as good as playing on your desktop, while others restrict the number of games or features you can use.If you plan on playing quite a bit on your mobile device, itrsquos worth your time to shop around and find a site that offers a high-quality gaming experience.What is RTP and How Does It Affect Me RTP stands for ldquo to player, and it expresses how much money you can expect to win playing a given site. Itrsquos usually described as a percentage, soyou see a machine that has a % RTP, that means that you can expect to win  cents for every dollar you bet.The higher a machinersquos RTP, the more of your money you can expect to get back when you play. Notice we didnrsquot say you could win mdash yoursquore not going to come out ahead in the long run on any slot. Casinos have to make money, after all.If you want to find out exactly what a given machinersquos RTP is, then the best way to do that is Google the name of the machine plus ldquoRTP. This should lead you to the answer, but not all providers list the RTP of their games, so itrsquos not foolproof.What is Volatility in Terms of Online Slots Volatility is closely related to RTP, and it describes how much money you can expect to win and how often. For example, a highly volatile machine wonrsquot pay out very often, but when it does, you can expect to win more money than you would on a machine with less volatility.A progressive jackpot is the ultimate example of a high-volatility option. It can take forever for someone to hit it, but when they do, the payout makes up for all the time they spent trying.Low volatility isnrsquot necessarily better than high volatility mdash itrsquos all a matter of personal preference. Some people prefer to win as often as possible, eventheir wins are on the small side. Others are okay with long dry spells, provided that the occasional wins are big enough to make the wait worthwhile.Are Some Slots ldquoLooser Than Others Yes and no. The idea of a loose slot mdash one that pays out way more than others mdash is largely a myth. Yoursquore not going to find a magical machine that will help you get rich, as theyrsquore all designed to favor the house in the long run.On the other hand, RTP and volatility go a long way towards describing a given slotrsquos looseness. A low-volatility slot with high RTP may seem loose compared to others, in that yoursquoll win on it a lot more than you will others.At the end of the day, wersquod advise you not to pay too much attention to the idea of loose slots. Yoursquore better off picking slots that you enjoy, or seeking out those with the volatility level that you prefer.Is There a Secret to Beating Slot Machines That depends on what you mean. If yoursquore looking for a code or hack that lets you get rich by cheating the machines, yoursquore not going to find it. The casinos and slot developers make too much money to leave loopholes like those lying around.On the other hand, there are some things you need to do in order to win certain bets. For example,you want to hit a jackpot, then you need to bet the max every time. If you donrsquot, yoursquoll never hit a huge payout mdash simple as that.Now, itrsquos important to understand that betting the max wonrsquot make you more likely to win a jackpot than everyone  whorsquos also betting the max. It simply means that you have no shot of hitting a jackpot without betting that way.Is There a Best Time to Play Online Slots This idea is based on an old myth that casinos rigged their slots to pay out more at certain times of the day. These times were usually when the casino experienced the most traffic the idea was that, by articially causing the slots to pay out more while more people were watching, more players would test their luck on slot machines .Therersquos no truth to this, of course. Your odds of winning are the same no matter what time of day you play, so donrsquot worry about trying to pinpoint the golden gambling hour or anything like that.The bottom line is that the best time to play is whenever you feel like playing.Whatrsquos the Best Way to Make Money Playing Online Slots The first thing you need to understand is that you probably wonrsquot make money playing slots. Itrsquos not like poker, where a player with enough skill can earn enough from it to make a living.That means that, rather than asking yourself how to make money at online slots, you should ask yourself how you can make your money last as long as possible. There are ways to stretch your gambling buck,yoursquore shrewd and willing to work at it.The best way to make your money last is by taking advantage of all the promotions that ious online casinos offer. Simply put, the more money you have, the longer you can play mdash so why not use the free money that they hand out That means being sure to use deposit bonuses when you sign up, and check out each sitersquos loyalty program. Many give frequent players extra financial incentives to keep playing, including occasionally handing out cash funds! Donrsquot be afraid to shop around and take advantage of many dferent bonuses, either.Beyond that, itrsquos mainly a matter of playing machines with a high RTP and being smart about managing your bankroll. You may not get rich playing slot machines, but therersquos no reason why you have to dig yourself into a financial hole, either.Are Slot Machines Addictive All forms of gambling can be addictive to people who are predisposed to having a problem, but it certainly seems as though playing slots online can be especially habit-forming.According to a study performed in Rhode Island, people who become addicted to slots move from ldquosocial to ldquopathological gambling  times faster than those who have issues betting on horse racing.Part of the problem is the instant nature of the slot machine. Because the game decidesyou win or lose in seconds, you can play hundreds of times every hour, giving your brain a little jolt of dopamine and adrenaline every time you press the spin button.Online gambling has also been shown to be more addictive than brick-and-mortar betting. The issue is that the virtual casino is always only a few clicks away, which makes it easier to gamble mindlessly and incorporate wagering into your daily le.None of this is said to discourage you from playing online slots games. Theyrsquore a lot of fun mdash but they can also be dangerous, so be careful. If you suspect you have a problem, seek help immediately.How Big Are Slot Jackpots That depends on the slot, as well as whether you mean ldquoregular jackpots or ldquoprogressive jackpots.Each slot has a dferent max payout these can range from a few hundred times the max bet to tens of thousands of times bigger than the max bet. As a general rule, the larger the jackpot each machine offers, the more volatility it will offer as well.Progressive jackpots, on the other hand, can theoretically be limitless. The way they work is they keep growing until somebody hits them, so the longer it takes for someone to get lucky, the larger the jackpot will grow. It works a lot like the lottery in that sense.Yoursquoll see progressive jackpots ranging from five figures all the way into the millions. As with the lottery, the larger the jackpot becomes, the more interest gamblers will take in it, so progressive jackpot slots will explode in popularity when the payout becomes massive enough.What Are Slot Tournaments and How Do They Work Slot tournaments are events where multiple players play a certain title for a set amount of time. At the end of that time period, the player with the most wins takes home the lionrsquos share of the prize pool.Other players can win prizes as well, as the rules will y from tournament to tournament and site to site.Slot tournaments can be incredibly fun, but they require you to play the same game for long periods of time in order to win. As a result, theyrsquore not for everyone.How Do I Get Money On and Off Slots Sites Each site has certain banking options it uses. These can include credit cards like Visa or MasterCard, e-wallets like Neteller, or traditional bank wires. Some even accept cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin.Be sure to read the fine print before you hand over your financial information, though. Some levy fees on their transactions, and others have caps on how much you can deposit or withdraw at a time.Is One Banking Method Better Than the Others As a general rule, no. However, since all sites have their own rules and regulations regarding the financial institutions they do business with, some may offer rewards or penalties for using a particular banking method.For example, many sites in the UK are trying to encourage their players to use Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.
